questions.text: A study was conducted to determine the different cell types and their functions in the central nervous system. One cell was identified using a special stain called glial fibrillary acid proteins (GFAP). These cells were found to have long foot processes. Which of the following is a function of the cell described?

choices.text: Production of myelin sheath in the central nervous system.

questions.solution:
The cells described in the question are most likely Astrocytes. Astrocytes are glial cells that are found in the grey matter of the central nervous system. Astrocytes have long foot processes, and they produce a protein called glial fibrillary acid proteins (GFAP), which can be used to immunostain astrocytes.  

The astrocytes are the most abundant glial cells in the central nervous system. The foot processes of the astrocytes contribute to the blood-brain barrier. Also, astrocytes are responsible for removing and recycling excess neurotransmitters. Finally, astrocytes are involved in the regeneration and repair after neuronal injury.  


Option Analysis

✅ Contribute to the blood-brain barrier  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Production of cerebrospinal fluid  :
Incorrect: Ependymal cells produce cerebrospinal fluid, and these cells line the ventricles. However, it does not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Production of myelin sheath in the central nervous system.  :
Incorrect: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin sheath formation in the central nervous system. However, they do not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Transmission of nerve impulses  :
Incorrect: Neurons are responsible for transmitting nerve impulses. They do not stain with GFAP.  
❌ Phagocytosis:
Incorrect: Microglial cells are phagocytosing cells of the central nervous system. These cells do not stain with GFAP.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for an annual examination. The patient feels well and has no complaints. Over the past year, she has been sexually active with three male partners and does not use barrier contraception. A speculum exam is performed, and a specimen is collected using a cytobrush. Pap smear testing reveals cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. Which of the following best describes the normal histology of the region of the cervix from where this sample was obtained?

choices.text: Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells
Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cells

questions.solution:
The cervical canal can be divided into three regions. The endocervix is closer to the uterus, and is lined by columnar epithelial cells. The ectocervix is continuous with the vagina, and it is lined by mature squamous epithelial cells. Where the squamous epithelium of the ectocervix and the columnar epithelium of the endocervix meet, there is a line called the squamocolumnar junction (also termed the transformation zone).  

It is at the transformation zone where cellular metaplasia and dysplasia most often take place, and therefore a Pap smear specifically samples tissue from the squamocolumnar junction. Metaplasia occurs when a stressor, such as acidity of the vaginal canal during reproductive years, causes replacement of one cell type by another. In the cervix, columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. Metaplasia is reversible once the stressor is removed.    

In contrast, dysplasia occurs when fully differentiated cells are replaced by immature cells with varying shape and nuclear morphology, as demonstrated by the koilocytes in this question stem, with their enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. Mild dysplasia is reversible. However moderate or severe dysplasia is irreversible, and if not monitored, it can progress to cervical cancer.  

Option Analysis

❌ Squamous epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Squamous epithelial cells are found in the ectocervix, which is continuous with the vagina. A Pap smear is obtained at the transformation zone, where dysplasia most frequently happens.   
❌ Cuboidal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Cuboidal epithelial cells are often found in organs with secretory, absorptive, or excretory functions. These include the pancreas, kidneys, and parotid glands. Simple cuboidal epithelium is also present on the outer surface of the ovaries. However, cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix.  
❌ Columnar epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Columnar epithelial cells are found in the endocervix, which is closer to the uterus. Koilocytes (epithelial cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos) and cervical dysplasia are more likely to be present at the transformation zone, rather than the endocervix.  
✅ Transition from squamous to columnar epithelial cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transition from squamous to cuboidal epithelial cells:
Incorrect: Cuboidal epithelial cells are not present in the cervix. Therefore, there would be no region in the cervix wherein squamous epithelial cells are replaced by cuboidal epithelial cells.

A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with his parents due to knee pain. During the past few months, the patient noticed a non-painful bump on the right knee that has progressively grown in size. Last week, he fell on the same location and endorses pain at the site. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a bony bump is noted on the right knee with overlying lacerated skin and crusted blood. The patient is able to bear weight without pain. The range of motion is full, strength is 5/5, and sensation is intact. A CT of the knee is obtained and shown below:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

The patient is prepared for surgery. Which of the following is most likely to be found on pathohistological examination of this patient’s lesion?

choices.text: Haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue
Sheets of primitive small round cells

questions.solution:
This patient has an osteochondroma (exostosis), a benign overgrowth of cartilage. It typically arises in the metaphysis of long tubular bones, especially near the knee. Osteochondromas can be sessile or pedunculated, ranging from 1 to 20 cm in size. The cap consists of benign hyaline cartilage which appears as a disorganized growth plate that eventually undergoes endochondral ossification, with new bone-forming at the inner part. It occurs in individuals at ages 10-30 and is more common in men. Clinically, it may cause pain if it impinges the surrounding tissue or nerve. It can occur as a single lesion or multiple as part of the multiple hereditary exostoses syndrome. Rarely, osteochondromas progress to chondrosarcoma. Most osteochondromas can be observed but symptomatic ones are cured via an excision.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with osteoid osteoma, a benign bone producing tumor. In adolescents, osteoid osteomas often arises in the cortex of the femur or tibia. On histology, it is well-circumscribed and composed of haphazardly interconnecting delicate trabeculae with surrounding fibrovascular tissue. Osteoid osteoma appears on imaging as a central nidus surrounded by a sclerotic bone rim.  
❌ Malignant cells producing woven bone:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with osteosarcoma, the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone. The tumor produces an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. Osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, with a first peak seen in persons younger than 20 years of age and a smaller peak in older adults. Radiographs usually show a destructive, mixed lytic and sclerotic mass with reactive subperiosteal bone formation. This bone formation leads to the elevation of the periosteum and characteristic appearance known radiographically as Codman’s triangle (not pathognomonic).   
✅ Chondrocytes and hyaline cartilage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sheets of osteoclasts:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with giant cell tumor of bone (osteoclastoma), a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor seen in young adults. It typically arises in the epiphyses of long bones and may produce pain that mimics arthritis. X-ray typically shows an expansile lytic lesion sometimes described as a “soap bubble” appearance. Grossly, they appear as red-brown masses with areas of cystic degeneration. Microscopically, it consists of sheets of osteoclast-type giant cells.  
❌ Sheets of primitive small round cells :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Ewing sarcoma, a highly malignant tumor that accounts for approximately 10% of primary malignant bone tumors. It commonly affects children, 5 to 15 years of age. The tumor usually arises in the diaphysis of long bones. Symptoms include bony pain, tissue swelling, fever, fatigue, weight loss, anemia and pathologic fractures. On x-ray, it is seen as a large lytic lesion with significant periosteal reaction deposited in an “onion-skin” or "moth-eaten" fashion. On histology, small sheets of malignant cells are seen.

A 45-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with abdominal pain. The patient reports worsening abdominal pain with associated vomiting occasionally after eating. The patient reports a 15-lb (6.8 kg) weight loss over the past 2 months. Vital signs demonstrate a temperature of  37°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin man in no acute distress. There is tenderness to palpation in epigastrium as well as abdominal distension with ascites. 2+ peripheral edema of the lower extremities is noted. Auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. Laboratory results are notable for hypoalbuminemia. The patient undergoes endoscopy which shows prominent rugae in the gastric fundus. A gross pathologic specimen from a patient with the same condition is demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Histologic analysis of the gastric mucosa is most likely to demonstrate which of the following features?

choices.text: Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell atrophy
Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell hyperplasia
Metaplasia of the esophagus with columnar epithelium and goblet cells

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette presents with progressively worsening abdominal pain, weight loss, and hypoalbuminemia. Additionally, the gross pathologic specimen reveals hypertrophied rugae, concerning for Ménétrier disease.

Ménétrier disease is an acquired pre-cancerous condition that results from hyperplasia of mucosal epithelial cells, although the specific pathologic mechanisms are poorly understood. Histologically, specimens will reveal loss of deep glandular components and parietal cell atrophy. Excess protein-containing mucus production results in hypoproteinemia and hypoalbuminemia. The resultant decrease in oncotic pressure can cause edema, pleural effusions, and ascites.    

Diagnosis is based on visualization of hypertrophic rugae during endoscopy and histologic evaluation. Patients with the disease are typically treated supportively with a high protein diet and serial endoscopic examinations to screen for the development of gastric carcinoma.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diffuse glandular atrophy and metaplasia:
Incorrect: Chronic gastritis is either due to autoimmune etiologies or H. pylori. In either case, histologic examination will demonstrate glandular atrophy and metaplasia. Gross examination may reveal loss of rugae as opposed to the hypertrophy seen in Ménétrier disease.   
❌ Rugal hypertrophy with parietal cell hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a neuroendocrine gastrin-secreting tumor that results in hypertrophy due to the increased hyperplasia of parietal cells with subsequent acid production.   
❌ Mucin-filled cells with peripheral nuclei :
Incorrect: Diffuse gastric cancer presents with signet cells on histology. Gross specimens will demonstrate a stomach wall that is grossly thickened and leathery, termed linitis plastica.   
❌ Metaplasia of the esophagus with columnar epithelium and goblet cells:
Incorrect:  The gastroesophageal junction is implicated in Barrett esophagus. This metaplastic process occurs when stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium and   goblet cells due to uncontrolled acid reflux.

A 77-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several month history of epigastric abdominal pain, weight loss, fatigue, and early satiety. The patient's medical history is notable for a 20-pack-year smoking history, recurrent peptic ulcer disease, coronary artery disease, and hypertension. The patient’s H. pylori stool antigen assay is positive. The patient undergoes endoscopy with biopsy and the following image is obtained:  



 Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is most likely to be observed on histologic analysis?

choices.text: Irregular tubular structures and dysplasia projecting through the muscularis mucosa
Mucinous cells floating in an abundant extracellular mucin pool
Large gastric folds with elongated pits and cystically dilated gastric glands
Prominent rugal folds and hypertrophic parietal cells

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has a history concerning for previous peptic ulcer disease, H. pylori infection, and an endoscopic image concerning for malignancy. Intestinal gastric carcinoma is described morphologically as irregular, with an uneven base, asymmetric edges and a disrupted or moth-eaten appearance with heaped up margins, which is consistent with the endoscopic image presented.  

Risk factors for intestinal gastric adenocarcinoma include diets high in nitrosamines (a component of smoked foods), smoking, and chronic H. pylori infection. The disease usually results from long standing untreated peptic ulcer disease or gastritis. Over time, chronic inflammation promotes gastric atrophy which progresses to metaplasia, dysplasia, and then eventually to carcinoma. As the cancer invades the gastric lining, it invades the muscularis mucosa, projecting to the outer layer of the stomach lining.  

Option Analysis

✅ Irregular tubular structures and dysplasia projecting through the muscularis mucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mucinous cells floating in an abundant extracellular mucin pool:
Incorrect: This histologic description is that of diffuse gastric cancer, which is primarily composed of signet ring cells. This type of gastric cancer is more commonly related to genetic predisposition, as opposed to environmental risk factors.   
❌ Foamy macrophages in lamina propria :
Incorrect: Whipple disease is due to intestinal infection with Tropheryma whipplei. This disease results in malabsorption, and cardiac, neurologic and arthritic symptoms, which are absent in this patient. The endoscopy image shows a gastric ulcer, as opposed to an intestinal ulcer, making this diagnosis unlikely as well.   
❌ Large gastric folds with elongated pits and cystically dilated gastric glands:
Incorrect: Ménétriers disease is a rare disease characterized by large rugal folds, decreased acid production, and protein loss. The treatment for this disease is gastrectomy due to the increased risk of developing gastric carcinoma.   
❌ Prominent rugal folds and hypertrophic parietal cells:
Incorrect: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is characterized by parietal cell hyperplasia due to a gastrin secreting tumor. The disease results in the generation of multiple peptic ulcers and prominent rugal folds due to mucosal hyperplasia.

A 65-year-old woman comes to the office following abnormal results found on screening mammography. Medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin. She is otherwise healthy. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a solid non-tender mass is palpated in the upper right quadrant of the right breast. A non-tender, fixed axillary lymph node is also palpated. The nipple and areola appear normal. A core needle biopsy reveals the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arises from which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
This patient had an abnormal mammogram screening, followed by a core-needle biopsy that is consistent with the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma, the most common type of breast cancer. Breast cancers are classified according to their morphology, as well as whether they have penetrated the basement membrane. The most common types of breast cancer includes invasive ductal carcinoma (70%) and invasive lobular carcinoma (10% to 15%). The term lobular or ductal is a bit of a misnomer, as both arise from the terminal duct lobular unit. Ductal carcinoma spreads to the ducts, while lobular carcinoma spreads to the lobules.  





Option Analysis

❌ Breast stroma:
Incorrect: Lesions that arise from the breast stroma (interlobular tissue) include fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumor. However, this patient’s presentation implies invasive disease (palpable, fixed lymph node), in addition to the histological picture, which is consistent with invasive ductal carcinoma.   
❌ Lactiferous duct:
Incorrect: Paget's disease of the breast is an extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and the contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. Other lesions that may arise from the ducts include intraductal papilloma, abscess, or mastitis. This patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.    
❌ Lactiferous sinus:
Incorrect: The sinuses are an extension of the lactiferous duct and are the location in which milk accumulates. Clogged ducts, galactoceles, intraductal papillomas, abscesses and mastitis may arise from this area.  
✅ Terminal duct lobular unit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lobules :
Incorrect: There are no breast lesions that arise from the lobules themselves. Lobular carcinoma in situ or invasive lobular carcinoma both arise from the terminal duct lobular unit and spread to the lobules.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a left breast mass. She first noticed it a few months ago, and since then, it has progressively grown in size. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2, for which she takes metformin. She does not smoke, drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a smooth, well-defined, firm and mobile mass is noted in the left breast. There is no associated pain, and the rest of the physical examination is within normal limits. Biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arises from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a smooth, well-defined, firm and mobile mass which requires further investigation. Her biopsy results show connective tissue and cysts with “leaf-like” lobulations, confirming the diagnosis of phyllodes tumor.   

Breast tissue is composed of mammary gland tissue, fibrous and fatty tissue, blood and lymph vessels, and nerves. The functional unit of the breast is the lobule, a glandular tissue that is lined with alveolar cells that secrete milk surrounded by myoepithelial cells that propagates it. The lobules are supported by a specialized intralobular stroma. The rest of the breast consists of the interlobular stroma, which is made of adipose and connective tissue.  



Lesions that arise from the interlobular stromal tissue include phyllodes tumor and fibroadenoma. Phyllodes tumor is an uncommon fibroepithelial breast tumor with a diverse biological manifestations ranging from benign fibroadenoma to distant metastasis. It accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers and mostly occurs in women with a median age of 43 years.    



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Paget's disease of the breast is an extension of underlying ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts, and contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. There is no breast cancer that arises from the skin of the nipple, and this patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ B:
Incorrect: The sinuses are an extension of the lactiferous duct and are the location in which milk accumulates. Clogged duct, galactocele, intraductal papilloma, abscess and mastitis may arise from this area. However, this patient’s presentation and histology results favor another diagnosis.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Terminal duct lobular units, also known as lobules, are epithelial structures within the breast that produce milk during lactation. These areas can give rise to conditions such as fibrocystic changes, lobular carcinoma in situ/invasive, and ductal carcinoma in situ/invasive. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

A 29-year-old man comes to the clinic due to headaches and feeling unstable. Over the past 6 months, the patient gradually has been falling more frequently. He has also been experiencing constant headaches which are worse in the morning. He denies any trauma and does not use alcohol illicit drugs. Medical history is notable for pheochromocytoma, treated with surgery 6 months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, he has difficulty ambulating or standing with feet close together. An MRI is obtained and shown below:  
 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    
Histopathological analysis of this patient's lesion would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The constellation of pheochromocytoma and a new cerebellar tumor is suggestive of von Hippel-Lindau disease. von Hippel-Lindau disease is an inherited, autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by a variety of both benign and malignant tumors. The pathogenesis involves a mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3 which encodes for a protein responsible for the degradation of the transcription factor hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF). In the absence of normally functioning protein, there is a high level of HIF that facilitates the expression VEGF and other growth factors, resulting in a stimulus for tumor growth.  

Patients with von Hippel-Lindau disease may present with hemangioblastomas throughout the central nervous system, clear cell renal cell carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, endolymphatic sac tumors, serous cystadenomas and neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas, and papillary cystadenomas of the epididymis or broad ligament.  

Hemangioblastomas are benign, highly vascular tumors of the central nervous system. Symptoms occur due to compression of adjacent neural structures, bleeding, or paraneoplastic complications. Hemangioblastomas appear on MRI as an enhancing nodule linked to a cyst within the cerebellum or as or a homogeneously enhancing lesion in the spinal cord (not pathognomonic). On histology, the lesion consists of thin-walled vessels, and interspersed stromal cells with a vacuolated, PAS-positive, lipid-rich cytoplasm. These stromal cells express inhibin, which can serve as a diagnostic marker.  



Option Analysis

❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological slide is consistent with a Schwannoma, a tumor of Schwann cell origin that grows along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, it stains positive for S-100 and is characterized by a biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells, alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas. 
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture is consistent with an ependymoma, a tumor that arises from the glial cells lining the ventricular system. It most commonly occurs in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. On histology, cells form characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes. This patient’s MRI shows a mass in the cerebellum, making another underlying diagnosis more likely. 
✅ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture is consistent with an oligodendroglioma, a tumor of oligodendrocyte origin that often grows in the frontal lobes. On histology, cells have round nuclei with a clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance, and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. 
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture is consistent with a meningioma, a tumor of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grows in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma (extra-axial) and often has a dural attachment (“tail”). On histology, the tumor is composed of spindle cells that are concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and have characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old African-American woman comes to the emergency department with weight gain, swelling, and low urine output. Over the past two weeks, the patient’s legs and arms have become swollen, and she has gained 15 lb (6.8 kg) without any changes in diet or activity level. Recently, the patient feels like she is urinating much less than normal. She reports a streptococcal throat infection three months ago for which she completed a course of antibiotics. Since then, the patient has had joint pains in her hands and noticed transient rashes on her face. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 155/96 mmHg. Physical examination shows abdominal distention, pitting edema throughout her arms and legs, and crackles are heard at the lung bases on auscultation. Laboratory investigations reveal the following:  

 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Sodium   132 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   4.2 mg/dL 
 Urea nitrogen   65 mg/dL 
 Anti-dsDNA  Positive 
 Urine  
 Erythrocytes  100/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Protein, total   3.8 g/day 
 Sediment   Erythrocyte casts 
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on kidney biopsy?

choices.text: “Wire looping” of capillaries with subendothelial C3 deposits on electron microscopy
Crescent-shaped areas of fibrin with inflammatory cell infiltrate
“Tram-track” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane
Segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis with effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy
Enlarged hypercellular glomeruli with subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy

questions.solution:
Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (also called diffuse lupus nephritis) is the most common glomerular disease found on renal biopsy in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient is presenting with weight gain from edema caused by the low intravascular oncotic pressure due to renal protein losses. The patient’s history raises suspicion for SLE: she is female, African-American, in her reproductive years, with arthralgias, photosensitivity, and renal dysfunction. The positive anti-dsDNA test provides serologic evidence of SLE. The 24-hour urine protein is in the nephrotic range, as is often seen in acute presentations of lupus nephritis. The high blood pressure and RBC casts on urinalysis suggest concomitant nephritic syndrome.

An estimated one-half of all patients with SLE will develop significant kidney disease. Although there are numerous subtypes of SLE-associated renal disease based on biopsy findings, the most common is diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. Light microscopy of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis shows > 50% glomeruli involvement (a.k.a. “diffuse”), with cellular proliferation leading to thickening of the glomerular capillary walls (a.k.a “proliferative”) that causes a “wire looping” appearance as shown:    

 

Immunofluorescence reveals a granular pattern, and electron microscopy shows subendothelial or intramembranous IgG-based immune complex depositions. Lupus nephritis is treated with immunosuppressive therapies.  

Option Analysis

✅ “Wire looping” of capillaries with subendothelial C3 deposits on electron microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.
❌ Crescent-shaped areas of fibrin with inflammatory cell infiltrate:
Incorrect: Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis is typically associated with Goodpasture syndrome, granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and microscopic polyangiitis. Prognosis is poor, with renal function rapidly deteriorating in days to weeks. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with another diagnosis.
❌ “Tram-track” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane:
Incorrect: Membrano-proliferative glomerulonephritis causes a mixed nephritic and nephrotic syndrome, classically associated with hepatitis B or C infection. The “tram-track” appearance is caused by mesangial ingrowth and basement membrane splitting. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with another diagnosis.
❌ Segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis with effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy:
Incorrect: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in African-Americans and Hispanics. It is often idiopathic or associated with other conditions including HIV, sickle cell disease, heroin abuse, and massive obesity. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with another diagnosis.
❌ Enlarged hypercellular glomeruli with subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy:
Incorrect: Acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is most frequently seen in children and occurs 2-4 weeks after a group A streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or skin infection). Patients present with peripheral and periorbital edema, tea-colored urine, and hypertension. However, PSGN would not account for the patient’s proteinuria, arthralgia, intermittent facial rash, or positive anti-ds DNA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office due to a neck lump. The patient reports no symptoms, weight loss, dysphagia, or voice changes. She does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. On physical examination, there is a fixed non-tender nodule in the left thyroid lobe. Serum TSH is within normal limits, and ultrasound shows a 2.5 cm solid mass. A fine-needle biopsy is obtained and shows varying degrees of follicles and microfollicles. A decision is made to perform thyroid lobectomy. Which of the following pathohistological findings will confirm the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer?

choices.text: Pink material with Congo red stain

questions.solution:
This patient has a fixed, non-tender thyroid nodule and normal TSH levels, which raises concern for malignancy. The fine needle aspiration shows varying degrees of normal follicles, which can indicate follicular adenoma or follicular carcinoma. The only way to distinguish follicular carcinoma from adenoma is by demonstrating capsular invasion after surgical excision of the entire lesion.  

Follicular thyroid carcinoma accounts for 12% of all cases of thyroid cancers. Peak incidence is between ages 40 and 60 years and 3 times more common in women. Risk factors include a history of radiation exposure during childhood, thyroid cancer in a first-degree relative, or positive family history of a thyroid cancer syndrome. The condition is associated with RAS mutations and PAX8-PPAR-γ translocations.  

Many cases are discovered incidentally on routine physical exams or radiologic imaging. The histologic features vary from normal, well-differentiated follicles and colloid (good prognosis) to poorly differentiated solid growth, with an absence of follicles, nuclear atypia, and extensive vascular and/or capsular invasion (poor prognosis). Follicular thyroid cancer is unique to carcinomas as it exclusively spreads via hematogenous dissemination (usually lymphatic spread). A definitive diagnosis requires histologic evaluation after surgery and the identification of tumor capsule and/or vascular invasion, since a fine-needle aspiration cannot properly observe the capsule.  

Option Analysis

❌ Concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: This finding is consistent with psammoma bodies, a unique finding of papillary thyroid carcinoma. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eye”) and nuclear grooves.
❌ Hürthle cells:
Incorrect: Hürthle cells, or oxyphil cells, are large polyclonal cells with abundant oxyphilic cytoplasm. These cells can be seen in a variety of conditions including Hürthle cell adenoma and carcinomas, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, and Hashimoto thyroiditis. While Hürthle cell carcinomas were previously thought to be a variant of follicular thyroid cancer, they are not characteristic of classic follicular thyroid cancer.
❌ Pink material with Congo red stain:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with medullary carcinoma, a parafollicular “C-cell” tumor that produces calcitonin. On histology, it appears as sheets of cells in an amyloid stroma, which turn red when stained with Congo red.
❌ Marked nuclear atypia:
Incorrect: Nuclear atypia, which refers to the abnormal appearance of the cell nucleus, can be seen in reactive changes, pre-neoplastic changes, or malignancy. Marked nuclear atypia is, in most cases, considered an important indicator of malignancy. However, the finding is nonspecific and would not confirm the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer.
✅ Capsular invasion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of recurrent bloating and diarrhea. The symptoms began 2 months ago. During this time, she has had bulky and foul-smelling stools with no visible blood as well as an unintentional 9-lb weight loss. In addition, the patient has had a pruritic rash on her arms, which she attributes to “sensitive skin.” Past medical history is notable for vitiligo and hypothyroidism, which is well controlled with levothyroxine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. Large patches of hypopigmentation are seen. There are multiple tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the patient’s elbows and dorsal forearms bilaterally. Further evaluation of this patient’s gastrointestinal tract is likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Atrophic mucosa with loss of villi and crypt hyperplasia
Periodic-acid Schiff positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa
Breakdown of intestinal crypt epithelium with infiltration of neutrophils
Nodular collections of macrophages and giant cells in the intestinal epithelium

questions.solution:
This adolescent female is presenting with signs and symptoms of celiac disease, such steatorrhea, weight loss, and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, patients with celiac disease are predisposed to various autoimmune conditions, which may explain her previously diagnosed vitiligo and hypothyroidism.

 Endoscopy with subsequent biopsy of the small intestine is essential for the diagnosis of celiac disease. It would likely demonstrate villous atrophy (black arrow) and crypt hyperplasia or elongation (yellow arrow). These findings occur since in patients with celiac disease or chronic inflammation, there is increased apoptosis of intestinal cells. In an attempt to replace the lost cells, the number of regenerative cells within the crypts of the small intestines increases, leading to crypt hyperplasia. Over time, there is an inability to keep up with the constant apoptosis, and villous atrophy ensues.  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Atrophic mucosa with loss of villi and crypt hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Periodic-acid Schiff positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa:
Incorrect: Patients with Whipple disease will have periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) positive macrophages in the small intestine mucosa. The condition is caused by infection with the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It most commonly presents in males between 30-60 years of age. Although Whipple disease can cause diarrhea and abdominal pain, it also tends to manifest with arthritis and cardiac symptoms (e.g. vascular insufficiency).
❌ Normal intestinal architecture:
Incorrect: Normal intestinal architecture can be seen in patients with lactose intolerance. Lactose intolerance may present with symptoms similar to those of celiac disease, such as bloating and diarrhea. However, this patient’s weight loss, dermatitis herpetiformis, and history of other autoimmune conditions (e.g., vitiligo, hypothyroidism) would not be explained by lactose intolerance alone. 
❌ Breakdown of intestinal crypt epithelium with infiltration of neutrophils:
Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis (UC) occurs due to dysregulation of the colonic epithelium. The abnormal epithelium is more permeable to intestinal bacteria, which subsequently activate immune cells such as macrophages, neutrophils, and T-cells. Crypt abscesses (infiltration of neutrophils) are characteristic of UC. However, UC commonly presents with bloody diarrhea and would not account for this patient’s symptoms.
❌ Nodular collections of macrophages and giant cells in the intestinal epithelium:
Incorrect: Crohn disease is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are composed of macrophages and giant cells, in the intestinal wall. Crohn disease presents with non-contiguous lesions and therefore results in nodular collections at various points throughout the digestive system. Although Crohn disease may result in chronic diarrhea, it would not adequately explain this patient’s cutaneous findings.

questions.text: A 78-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department following sudden-onset weakness in his right arm and inability to speak for twenty four hours. The patient’s daughter states she initially became concerned when he dropped his cup of coffee while walking to the kitchen table last night. The daughter states he has had a similar episode in the past that resolved spontaneously. He has a history of hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and visibly frustrated by not being able to speak. Physical examination reveals 2/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity. He follows written and verbal commands but is unable to speak or write. MRI of the head demonstrates ischemic changes in the cerebral territory supplied by the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following histopathological findings are most likely to be observed in this patient’s brain at the present time?

choices.text: Eosinophilic neuronal cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei

questions.solution:
This patient suffered from an ischemic stroke, as suggested by his focal neurologic deficits and corroborating MRI findings. In the hours, days, and weeks following an ischemic stroke, there are several histopathological changes that occur in the area of infarction. The first histopathological changes appear after 12 to 24 hours, although irreversible damage actually begins after five minutes of hypoxia. The following describes the histopathological timeline following an ischemic stroke:

  •  12-24 hours: Neurons appear red with eosinophilic cytoplasms and loss of Nissl substance, which is a large granular body found inside neurons, and pyknotic nuclei. Red neurons are indicative of irreversible damage.  
  •  24-72 hours: Necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration. 
  •  3-5 days: Infiltration of microglial cells (macrophages of the brain) which phagocytose damaged neurons.  
  •  1-2 weeks: Reactive astrocytes migrate to the site of infection, resulting in gliosis. Vascular proliferation (formation of new capillaries) also occurs around the area of necrosis.  
  •  > 2 weeks: Scar tissue forms to fill the infarcted space. 
Macroscopically, after one week to one month, microglial cells that contain hydrolytic enzymes digest the dead neuronal cells into a soft, purulent substance of dead immune cells--termed liquefactive necrosis. After approximately one month, the brain tissue is replaced by a cystic cavity surrounded by a glial scar.  

Option Analysis

❌ Astrocytic and vascular proliferation:
Incorrect: Astrocytic and vascular proliferation occurs one to two weeks following an ischemic stroke, not within 24-hours.
❌ Glial scar formation:
Incorrect: After an ischemic stroke, astrocytic proliferation results in the formation of a closely connected firm meshwork, termed a gliotic scar. Formation of this glial scar occurs after two weeks, when astrocytes are able to enter the ischemic, damaged region of the brain following vascular proliferation.
❌ Neutrophilic and microglial infiltration:
Incorrect: Neutrophils move into the ischemic, damaged area of the brain in the first 48-72 hours following onset of symptoms. During this time, liquefactive necrosis occurs due to neutrophil lysosomal enzyme release.
✅ Eosinophilic neuronal cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ No observable histopathological changes:
Incorrect: Under a microscope, the first histopathological changes following an ischemic stroke appear after 12 to 24 hours, although irreversible damage actually begins after five minutes of hypoxia.

A 52-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of intermittent abdominal cramps and diarrhea for the past 2 months. He has had 4-5 bowel movements per day containing small-volume stools that are mixed with blood and mucus. Review of systems reveals a 5.9-kg (13-lbs) weight loss, fatigue, and loss of appetite. He also experiences pain and tenderness in the right knee that responds to indomethacin. The remainder of the history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness in the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. Laboratory results are as follows:


 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.7 mg/dL 
 Platelets  290,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes  13,200/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  120 mm/hr 
 
Colonoscopy shows erythematous and edematous bowel wall mucosa extending from the rectum to the sigmoid colon with small shallow ulcers throughout the involved region. Biopsy of the involved tissue sample will most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa
Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris

questions.solution:
This patient has constitutional symptoms (fatigue, weight loss, loss of appetite), chronic bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps. Laboratory findings of anemia, increased ESR and leukocytosis, together with colonoscopy findings of continuous inflammation and ulceration in the rectum and sigmoid colon, are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).  UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation of the rectum that may extend in a proximal and continuous fashion to involve other parts of the colon. Clinically, the condition presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.  Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Microscopic features suggestive of ulcerative colitis include:  
  •  Mucosal and submucosal inflammation (Figure A): Due to diffuse, chronic infiltrates in the mucosa and lamina propria. 
  •  Crypt abscess (Figure B): Clusters of neutrophils and pus within crypt epithelium. 
  •  Formation of pseudopolyps (Figure C): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps. 
  •  Basal lymphoid aggregates (Figure A): Prominent lymphoid aggregates located at the border of the submucosa. 
  •  Paneth cell metaplasia (arrows in Figure D): Occurs exclusively in affected mucosa and is a useful marker of IBD.


Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Figure C (Retrieved from: flickr.com



Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)

Option Analysis

❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Caseating granulomas are aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with central necrosis that are usually seen on histopathology of intestinal tuberculosis. Although chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea are the presenting symptoms, a history of travel to an endemic area or exposure to infected individuals is usually present.
✅ Inflammation limited to the mucosa and submucosa:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thickening of the muscularis mucosae:
Incorrect: Thickening (hypertrophy) of the muscularis mucosae causes stricture formation which narrows the intestinal lumen. It is a complication of long-standing Crohn disease, diverticulitis, or malignancy. It is not seen in patients with ulcerative colitis.
❌ Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris:
Incorrect: Pseudomembranes of fibrin and inflammatory debris are seen in C. difficile infection that clinically presents with watery diarrhea and low-grade fever. This infection is associated with antibiotic therapy (e.g.,clindamycin, quinolones, penicillins). Toxic megacolon is a potential complication. Bloody diarrhea is unlikely.
❌ Distended macrophages in lamina propria:
Incorrect: Distended macrophages in the lamina propria are pathognomonic of Whipple disease. The condition is a multisystem progressive disease presenting with joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and central nervous system involvement. Endoscopy usually shows a normal appearing mucosa.

questions.text: A study is conducted on the lungs to determine the lung response to injury. According to the study, right after inducing lethal damage to lung tissue, certain types of cells in the alveoli start proliferating and producing new cells that replace the damaged alveolar cells. These cells are most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
The alveoli are the major site of gas exchange in the lungs. They have thin walls with adjacent capillary vessels to allow for maximal exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the alveoli and red blood cells.  

The walls of the alveoli are made of 2 types of cells, i.e. type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes. Type 1 pneumocytes, which make up to 95% of the surface area of the alveoli, have a thin wall and a flat elongated nucleus. They are thin to allow maximal gas exchange. Type 2 pneumocytes, on the other hand, make up only around 5% of the surface area of the alveoli and are characterized by their cuboidal appearance. They have 2 major functions  

  1. They responsible for surfactant production  
  2. They are the regenerative cells for both type 1 and type 2 pneumocytes after pulmonary injury.  

The final type of cells that can be found in the alveoli are the alveolar macrophages. Alveolar macrophages act as defense cells and engulf any foreign particles that enter the alveoli.  


Option Analysis

✅ Type 2 pneumocytes  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Type 1 pneumocytes  :
Incorrect: Type 1 pneumocytes are not capable of regeneration and repair. Type 2 pneumocytes act as stem cells for both type 1 and 2 pneumocytes after alveolar injury.  
❌ Pulmonary macrophages  :
Incorrect: Pulmonary macrophages help in clearing the infection and debris but do not act as a stem cell precursor for alveolar pneumocytes  
❌ Goblet cells  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are not found in the alveoli, and they do not act as a stem cell precursor for pneumocytes.  
❌ Clara cells  :
Incorrect: Clara cells, also known as club cells, are only found in the bronchioles and are not present in the alveoli. These cells can act as a progenitor for club cells and epithelial cells in the bronchioles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks gestation comes to the clinic due to abnormal facial hair growth. The patient has received consistent prenatal care and takes prenatal vitamins regularly. At the first prenatal appointment, ultrasound confirmed a twin intrauterine pregnancy with 2 normal fetal heartbeats. The patient’s medical history is unremarkable. Menarche was at age 14, and the patient’s menstrual cycle occurred every 28 days, lasting for 3-4 days. During the past few weeks, the patient noticed hair growth on her chin, upper lip, and abdomen. She has also experienced mild abdominal discomfort, which she assumed to be normal. Vitals signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, dark hair is noted on the face and abdomen. Pelvic examination reveals bilateral adnexal masses. Abdominal ultrasound shows a normal twin intrauterine pregnancy and bilateral multiseptated cystic adnexal masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman with a twin pregnancy is presenting with a new onset of hirsutism and bilateral complex adnexal masses, a presentation consistent with theca lutein cysts.  

Theca lutein cysts are a type of follicular cyst, characterized by hypertrophy and luteinization of the theca interna layer. Their growth is stimulated by high levels of β-hCG or due to hyper-sensitivity to β-hCG. Therefore, it is associated with gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestation, and ovarian hyperstimulation (such as in ovulation induction therapies). The cysts are usually asymptomatic but may lead to maternal virilization, hyperemesis gravidarum, preeclampsia, or thyroid dysfunction. Treatment is usually conservative; since postpartum women have declining levels of β-hCG, spontaneous regression occurs.



Option Analysis

❌ Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):
Incorrect: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is characterized by bilateral, enlarged ovaries with multiple small follicular cysts classically seen in a woman who is obese, anovulatory, and hirsute. While this woman has some of these features, there is no mention of obesity and her menstrual cycle has been normal prior to pregnancy, making another diagnosis more likely.
✅ Theca lutein cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Follicular cysts:
Incorrect: Follicular cysts (also known as physiologic cysts) occur when rupture fails to occur during ovulation, and instead, the follicle continues to grow. Although benign, it may lead to hemorrhage or ovarian torsion. Follicular cysts are not associated with hirsutism or twin pregnancy. On ultrasound examination, follicular cysts are thin-walled, smooth, and unilocular.


❌ Corpus luteal cysts:
Incorrect: Corpus luteal cysts arise when the corpus luteum fails to involute and progressively enlarge following ovulation. Of note, a corpus luteum cyst is always seen in early intrauterine pregnancy and therefore called physiologic or functional. Although benign, it may become hemorrhagic, painful or lead to ovarian torsion. Corpus luteum cysts may appear simple or complex with internal debris on ultrasound.  


❌ Ovarian hyperthecosis:
Incorrect: Ovarian hyperthecosis is a condition seen typically in postmenopausal women and characterized by the presence of islands of luteinized theca cells that are scattered throughout the ovarian stroma instead of being restricted to the surrounding of the cystic follicles (as occur in PCOS). This results in an increased production of androgens. Patients may present with progressive acne and hirsutism, clitoral enlargement, male-pattern baldness, deepening of the voice, male habitus, and insulin resistance.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the office due to a neck lump. She is otherwise healthy, and medical history is unremarkable. She does not use tobacco, excessive alcohol, or illicit substances. The patient has not noticed any weight loss, but she does endorse some changes in her voice lately. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a fixed, non-tender nodule occupying the right thyroid lobe. Laboratory testing shows normal TSH levels. Ultrasound is obtained and reveals a 2.5 cm, hypoechoic nodule with increased central flow. Fine-needle biopsy is performed and shows the following:

Wikimedia Commons

This finding can also be seen in which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a non-tender, fixed thyroid nodule as well as vocal changes, which raises concern for a possible thyroid malignancy. The ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic nodule with increased central flow, indicating it is a vascular lesion and further increasing the suspicion that it is a malignant lesion. Finally, fine needle biopsy reveals a classic picture of thyroid papillary carcinoma with psammoma bodies and “Orphan Annie eyes.” There are 4 conditions associated with psammoma bodies, including meningiomas, papillary thyroid carcinoma, mesothelioma, and papillary serous carcinoma of the ovary and endometrium.  

Papillary thyroid cancer is the most common type of thyroid carcinoma (80% of cases). Exposure to ionizing radiation in childhood is a significant risk factor. Other risk factors include RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations. Histologically, the tumor is composed of papillae, which are finger-like projections. The cells lining the papillae contain central clearing of the nucleus (“Orphan Annie eyes”) and nuclear grooves (dark indentations within the nucleus). In addition, concentric calcifications termed psammoma bodies are often seen. The tumor usually spreads to cervical lymph nodes but carries a good prognosis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Ovarian carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect: Sarcoidosis is associated with granulomatous inflammation, a type of chronic inflammation that results in granuloma formation. A granuloma is a focus of epithelioid cells surrounded by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes. This histological picture is consistent with psammoma bodies, not a granuloma.
❌ Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A:
Incorrect: Multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN2A) is associated with parathyroid hyperplasia, medullary thyroid carcinoma (parafollicular C cells), and pheochromocytoma, none of which are associated with psammoma bodies.
❌ Schwannoma:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, Schwannomas are positive for S-100 and are characterized by a biphasic architecture: Antoni A (dense hypercellular areas containing spindle cells) alternating with Antoni B (hypocellular myxoid areas). However, Schwannomas are not associated with psammoma bodies.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is typically seen in patients who smoke, and it presents as a central mass. On histology, keratin pearls and intercellular bridges may be observed. However, it is not associated with psammoma bodies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office due to a neck mass. The patient first noticed it a few months ago while shaving, but he did not seek medical care at that time. He also describes worsening weakness, abdominal pain, and constipation. Medical history is insignificant other than appendectomy at age 16. On physical examination, a painless lump is noted on the left lobe of the thyroid. Multiple painless cervical lymph nodes are also noted. The rest of the physical examination is normal. TSH levels are within normal limits. PTH and calcium levels are elevated. Ultrasound is performed and reveals a solid and hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications. Which of the following features is most likely to be seen on fine-needle biopsy?

choices.text: Varying sizes of follicles filled with colloid
Crowded tall, columnar cells forming papillae without fibrovascular cores
Sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma
Cells with central clearing and interspersed concentric calcifications
Pleomorphic and spindle-shaped anaplastic cells invading local structures

questions.solution:
This patient has a painless thyroid nodule and enlarged lymph nodes, elevated PTH and calcium levels, constipation, and abdominal pain, as well as ultrasound findings suspicious for malignancy. This presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A) syndrome, a hereditary condition presenting with parathyroid hyperplasia (hypercalcemia), medullary thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. The abdominal pain and constipation are likely due to elevated calcium levels.  

Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland, which produce calcitonin. The majority of cases are sporadic, while the rest are hereditary as part of the MEN syndrome. In most cases of MTC, the disease has already metastasized by the time of diagnosis.  

Common presenting signs include detectable cervical lymph nodes, dysphagia, or hoarseness. Distant metastases may occur in the liver, lungs, bones, and less commonly the brain and skin. Serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are elevated in MTC. MTC is associated with RET proto-oncogene mutations that result in constitutive activation of the RET tyrosine kinase receptor. On histology, the tumor is characterized by sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma that stains positive with Congo red.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Varying sizes of follicles filled with colloid:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with follicular carcinoma, a malignant proliferation of thyroid follicles. The same features can be seen in follicular adenoma. The only way to distinguish between follicular adenoma and carcinoma is to examine the surrounding capsule for signs of invasion. However, this patient is presenting with signs of hypercalcemia, which favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Crowded tall, columnar cells forming papillae without fibrovascular cores:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. However, Graves disease typically presents with signs of hyperthyroidism, including periorbital edema, exophthalmos, diarrhea, tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, and arrhythmias. Moreover, in Graves disease, TSH is likely to be low rather than normal.
✅ Sheets of polygonal cells in an amyloid stroma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cells with central clearing and interspersed concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with papillary carcinoma, the most common type of thyroid cancer. On histology, it appears as papillae (finger-like projections) lined by cells with central clearing (“Orphan Annie eyes”) and nuclear grooves. Psammoma bodies, which are concentric calcifications, are also seen. However, this patient is presenting with signs of hypercalcemia, which favors another diagnosis.
❌ Pleomorphic and spindle-shaped anaplastic cells invading local structures:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with anaplastic carcinoma. This highly malignant and aggressive tumor, often seen in elderly patients, invades local structures and presents with compressive symptoms such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and respiratory compromise. This patient is young and has no signs of compression, which favors a different diagnosis.

A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to sudden-onset confusion and headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia due to noncompliance with medications. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 205/140 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is dyspneic. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. Laboratory results are obtained and shown below:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum 
 Creatinine   1.9 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen  50 mg/dL 
 Urine  
 Erythrocytes  8/hpf 
 Leukocytes  2/hpf 
 Protein  3+ 
 Sediment   None 
Which of the following histologic findings would likely be seen if this patient’s renal artery was biopsied?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension now presents with extremely high blood pressure (>180/120) and signs of end-organ damage (e.g., confusion, headache, blurry vision). Along with the laboratory results (i.e., elevated creatinine and hematuria), this presentation is consistent with malignant hypertension, also known as hypertensive emergency.  

 Hypertensive emergencies are often the result of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, which is characterized by concentric thickening (“onion skinning”) of the arteries and arterioles due to smooth muscle proliferation. In hypertensive emergency, these changes are acutely accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arteriolitis), which are more pronounced in the kidney. The result is a marked narrowing of renal arterioles and small arteries, which causes significantly reduced blood flow and subsequent ischemia, resulting in acute kidney failure.   

Arteriosclerosis literally means “stiffening of the arteries,” and the differences between different types of arteriosclerosis are shown in the table below:  



Option Analysis

❌  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons :
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts hyaline arteriosclerosis, a condition that is associated with essential hypertension and diabetes mellitus. The condition is characterized by protein deposition and luminal narrowing. The proteins are seen as pink, hyaline, amorphous material under the microscope. Although this patient may have some degree of hyaline arteriosclerosis, this sudden-onset hypertensive emergency more likely resulted in hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis. 
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts Mönckeberg sclerosis (medial calcific sclerosis), an uncommon condition which leads to calcification of the internal elastic lamina and media. Usually the condition is asymptomatic and is found as an incidental finding on imaging.
✅ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histology slide depicts a complex atheroma, characteristic of atherosclerosis. It usually affects elastic arteries and large- and medium-sized muscular arteries, due to build up of cholesterol plaques. Although this patient probably has concomitant atherosclerosis, this severe hypertension will likely manifest as hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis in the renal arteries.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to acute flank pain and hematuria that began 3-hours ago. He has had several similar episodes in the past 2 years. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Family history is notable for the patient’s father experiencing similar symptoms. Intravenous hydration, analgesia, and potassium bicarbonate are administered, and the patient’s condition resolves within a few hours. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on urinalysis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute flank pain and hematuria, which are common symptoms of nephrolithiasis. In light of similar episodes in his father, the most likely diagnosis is hereditary cystinuria.  

Hereditary cystinuria is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by a defect in the proximal convoluted tubule cystine-reabsorbing transporter, leading to cystinuria. Since cystine is a poorly soluble amino acid, it precipitates to form stones. This defect also results in poor reabsorption of the amino acids ornithine, lysine, and arginine.  

Symptoms typically begin in childhood. Diagnosis can be made by identifying a positive family history of cystinuria, analyzing the kidney stone after it has been expelled, or identifying hexagonal cystine crystals on urinalysis. A cyanide-nitroprusside test can be used when the stone is not available for analysis and crystals are not visualized in the urine. The addition of cyanide-nitroprusside to urine with cystine induces a purple color change.  

Treatment consists of high fluid intake, dietary modification (low sodium and protein intake), and urinary alkalinization (potassium bicarbonate). In patients who fail initial therapy, thiol-containing drugs such as tiopronin or D-penicillamine, can be used. In cases where large stones form, surgical intervention may be necessary.


Option Analysis

✅ Retrieved from:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with uric acid crystals, which can be rhomboid or rosette shape. Uric acid stones can be found in conditions that lead to increased uric acid production (e.g., gout, myeloproliferative disorders) as well as chronic diarrhea (due to bicarbonate loss). In contrast, this patient has no history of such conditions.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) stones, which have a coffin lid shape. These stones can be found in the setting of infection by urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter. In contrast, this patient has no history of urinary tract infections.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with calcium oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone. They present with envelope-shaped or dumbbell-shaped crystals. These stones can be found in conditions such as ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn disease). This patient’s medical history and family history favor another diagnosis.
❌ Retrieved from::
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with calcium  oxalate stones, the most common type of kidney stone. They present with envelope-shaped or dumbbell-shaped crystals. These stones can be found in conditions such as ethylene glycol (antifreeze) ingestion, vitamin C overconsumption, hypocitraturia, and malabsorption (e.g. Crohn's disease). This patient’s medical history and family history favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to irritability and severe nausea and vomiting for the past day. His parents state that he has been eating less than usual for the past week. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. On physical examination, horizontal nystagmus is present, and limb movement is uncoordinated. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain is obtained and shown below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons    
Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histologic evaluation of the mass?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a pilocytic astrocytoma, given the presentation with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g., nausea, vomiting), nystagmus, and imaging showing a cystic and solid lesion in the cerebellum. Additional symptoms of pilocytic astrocytoma include headache, torticollis, difficulty coordinating movements, and visual complaints.  

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a benign low-grade tumor that commonly arises in the cerebellar hemispheres and around the third ventricle, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. It is the most common primary brain tumor in childhood, although it is occasionally seen in older individuals as well. On imaging, it is composed of both cystic and solid components.  

On histology, it stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and shows eosinophilic corkscrew fibers (Rosenthal fibers), as seen below.  



Option Analysis

❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture depicts a schwannoma, a tumor of Schwann cell origin. It typically grows along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, it stains positive for S-100 and is characterized by biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas. Patients present with sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. The location and cystic components of this patient’s tumor as seen on imaging, as well as his cerebellar symptoms, favor the diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture depicts an ependymoma, a tumor that arises from glial cells lining the ventricular system. It most commonly occurs in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus due to impairment of normal ventricular flow. Histology shows characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes. The location and cystic components of this patient’s tumor, as seen on imaging, favor the diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.
✅ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons   :
Incorrect: This histological picture depicts a craniopharyngioma, the most common childhood supratentorial tumor. The tumor is derived from remnants of Rathke’s pouch (ectoderm). Visual symptoms (e.g. bitemporal hemianopsia) and endocrine abnormalities are common. Calcifications may be seen on imaging. Light microscopy shows keratin pearls and cysts filled with cholesterol crystals (“motor oil”-like). The location and cystic component of this patient’s tumor, as seen on imaging, favor the diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This histological picture depicts a meningioma, a tumor of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grows in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma. The tumor may have a dural attachment (“tail”). Histology shows spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications). The location and cystic component of this patient’s tumor, as seen on imaging, favor the diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma. 
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons :
Incorrect: This histological picture depicts an oligodendroglioma, a rare tumor of oligodendrocyte origin that tends to grow in the frontal lobes. Histology shows cells with round nuclei and clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance, and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. Calcifications may also be seen on imaging. The location and cystic component of this patient’s tumor, as seen on imaging, favor the diagnosis of pilocytic astrocytoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is noncontributory. There is no family history of cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, and a 5-mm polyp is found in the rectosigmoid colon. The polyp is biopsied, and subsequent microscopic analysis is performed. Histology shows non-dysplastic epithelial proliferation with serrations only at the epithelial surface and cellular proliferation confined to the lower portion of the crypts. It is determined that the polyp has minimal malignant potential. Which of the following best describes the histological subtype of this polyp?
questions.solution:
Colonic hyperplastic polyps are the most common epithelial proliferations seen on colonoscopy. They are usually located in the rectosigmoid region. The formation of these lesions is not completely understood, but they are thought to be the result of decreased epithelial cell turnover and delayed shedding of surface epithelial cells, which leads to a “pileup” of goblet cells. This excess of goblet cells ultimately causes the hyperproliferation seen in the basal portion of the crypts, while the luminal surface has a superficial serrated architecture. An image of a hyperplastic polyp is shown below.  

Although hyperplastic polyps have little malignant potential, it is important to distinguish them from serrated polyps, which are histologically similar and have malignant potential. The most useful histologic feature that distinguishes serrated polyps from hyperplastic polyps is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base. In contrast, hyperplastic polyps demonstrate serrated architecture confined to the epithelial surface.

Image reproduced from Flickr



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperplastic:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serrated:
Incorrect: Although hyperplastic polyps and sessile serrated polyps are similar on microscopy, it is important to note that in serrated polyps, there is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base. This patient’s polyp demonstrates serration only at the epithelial surface. Furthermore, the polyp was determined to have minimal neoplastic potential, whereas serrated polyps have a high risk of progressing to cancer. 
❌ Adenomatous:
Incorrect: The three types of adenomatous polyps are villous, tubular, and tubulovillous. This patient’s polyp, which showed serration confined to the epithelial surface as well as cellular proliferation in crypts, is suggestive of a different subtype. Additionally, adenomatous polyps have significant malignant potential, whereas this patient's polyp has only minimal potential. 
❌ Hamartomatous:
Incorrect: Hamartomatous polyps are made up of tissue elements that are normally found at that site but are growing in a disorganized mass. Histological analysis of this patient’s polyp is more consistent with a different subtype. 
❌ Inflammatory pseudopolyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory pseudopolyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. These polyps are commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease. However, the histological characteristics of this patient’s polyp are more consistent with those of a hyperplastic polyp.

questions.text: A group of investigators are studying the cells of the seminiferous tubules of the testes. Which of the following best describes the function of the cell labeled 7 in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The cells labeled 7 in the histological image shown above are Leydig cells in the seminiferous tubule. Leydig cells are large, round, or polygonal cells with round nuclei and often have an eosinophilic cytoplasm because of the lipid droplets that they typically contain. It secretes testosterone in the presence of the luteinizing hormone (LH).  

Other cells of the seminiferous tubule include spermatogonia (labeled 4) and Sertoli cells (labeled 5). The spermatogonia are the undifferentiated germ cells that are mainly found along the periphery of the germinal epithelium, against the basement membrane. They maintain the germ cell pool and produce primary spermatocytes. Sertoli cells, on the other hand, are large columnar cells with pale, euchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli. These cells provide nutrition and mechanical support for the spermatogenic cells. Sertoli cells also secrete two hormones - activin and inhibin - which provide positive and negative feedback to the pituitary gland for follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Produce primary spermatocytes  :
Incorrect: Primary spermatocytes are produced by spermatogonia, which are labeled 4 in the figure.  
❌ Produce mullerian inhibiting factor  :
Incorrect: Mullerian inhibiting factor is produced by the Sertoli cells which are labeled 5 in the figure.  
❌ Regulates spermatogenesis  :
Incorrect: Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubule regulate spermatogenesis, which is labeled 5 in the figure.  
✅ Secretes testosterone  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Secretes androgen binding proteins  :
Incorrect: Sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubule secrete androgen-binding proteins.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department due to a seizure. The patient's wife reports that during the past 3 weeks, he has been complaining of headaches. She also notes that he has been “acting strange” and has had difficulty walking over the past few days. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. Physical examination shows the patient has postictal confusion but is responsive. The patient dies two days later secondary to respiratory arrest despite appropriate interventions. An autopsy is performed, and gross examination of the brain is shown below:  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

Histopathological examination of this patient’s lesion is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Concentrically arranged spindle cells in a whorled pattern with areas of calcifications
Hypercellular areas of spindle cells alternating with hypocellular myxoid areas
Large abnormal lymphocytes infiltrating perivascular spaces
Thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma
Pleomorphic tumor cells surrounding an area of central necrosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation (seizures associated with progressive headache, weakness, and personality changes occurring rapidly over the course of several weeks), in addition to the characteristic gross morphology seen on autopsy, is consistent with the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme (GBM).   

GBM, or grade IV astrocytoma (astrocyte origin), is a highly malignant primary brain tumor with an approximately 1-year median survival. On histology, the tumor stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and is characterized by “pseudopalisading” pleomorphic tumor cells bordering central areas of necrosis, hemorrhage, and/or microvascular proliferation. On gross morphology, tumors are often large, poorly defined, and have areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.  On imaging, GBM is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion, because the contrast-enhancing tumor cells form a ring to surround the necrotic center, which does not take up contrast. The tumor can cross the corpus callosum, leading to a midline shift and causing a mass effect
.

Option Analysis

❌ Concentrically arranged spindle cells in a whorled pattern with areas of calcifications:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with meningiomas, which are common, typically benign tumors of arachnoid cell origin. Meningiomas are extra-axial (external to brain parenchyma) and may have a dural attachment. This patient autopsy shows an intra-axial tumor with central necrosis and hemorrhage, which favors the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.
