❌ Hypercellular areas of spindle cells alternating with hypocellular myxoid areas:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with a Schwannoma, a tumor of Schwann cell origin. It commonly arises at the cerebellopontine angle, involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII, but it can occur along any peripheral nerve. Patients present with sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. This patient’s autopsy shows an intra-axial tumor in the cerebral hemispheres with central necrosis, which favors the diagnosis of glioblastoma multiforme.   
❌ Large abnormal lymphocytes infiltrating perivascular spaces:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with primary central nervous system lymphoma, a rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma seen most commonly in immunocompromised patients (e.g. HIV). Typical locations include the corpus callosum, periventricular white matter, and basal ganglia, presenting as either solitary or multiple lesions. This patient is immunocompetent with a characteristic lesion on autopsy, which favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Thin-walled capillaries with minimal intervening parenchyma:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with hemangioblastoma, a tumor of blood vessel origin. These tumors most often arise in the cerebellum and are associated with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. This patient’s tumor morphology and location favors another diagnosis.   
✅ Pleomorphic tumor cells surrounding an area of central necrosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy, drowsiness and vomiting. His parents state he had been complaining of progressive headaches and worsening vision for the past several months. Height, weight and head circumference are at the 50th percentile for age. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears drowsy. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. A brain MRI shows a lesion in the fourth ventricle with dilated ventricles. A stereotactic biopsy is performed, and the hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained sample is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
The progressive symptoms of hydrocephalus (lethargy, nausea, vomiting), the location of the tumor (4th ventricle), and the characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes in the biopsy specimen all point to an ependymoma.   

Ependymomas are invasive primary brain tumors that arise from the glial cells lining the ventricular system. Most commonly they occur in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. Ependymomas have the potential to disseminate throughout the central nervous system (CNS). Similar to medulloblastoma, the tumor can send metastasis to the spinal cord; however, on histology, the tumor is distinguished by perivascular pseudorosettes, not Homer-Wright rosettes (as seen in medulloblastoma). Pseudorosettes are neoplastic cells arranged around a blood vessel, while Homer-Wright rosettes are instead arrangements of small blue cells around a central core.  

Resection and adjuvant radiation therapy are the mainstays of treatment, except in very young patients. Chemotherapy is used only in very young children, patients with bulky residual disease, and recurrent or refractory tumors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Craniopharyngioma:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas, while common, would be located in the pituitary fossa. Patients may present with bitemporal hemianopsia due to compression of the optic chiasm. Calcifications are often seen on imaging. On light microscopy, keratin pearls and cysts filled with cholesterol crystals (“motor oil”-like) are expected. The location and histology findings of this patient’s tumor favors another diagnosis.  
✅ Ependymoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Medulloblastoma:
Incorrect: Medulloblastomas are poorly-differentiated, highly-malignant tumors seen exclusively in children. These tumors commonly arise from the cerebellum and are characterized by Homer-Wright rosettes on histology. Common symptoms are ataxia, slurred speech, nystagmus, positive Romberg sign, and intention tremor. This patient’s imaging and histological findings favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Pilocytic astrocytoma:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common pediatric primary brain tumor, is a benign low-grade tumor that usually arises in the cerebellar hemispheres or around the third ventricle. On imaging, cystic and solid components can be seen. Under light microscopy, it stains positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and shows eosinophilic corkscrew fibers (Rosenthal fibers). The location and histology findings of this patient’s tumor favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Oligodendroglioma:
Incorrect: Oligodendrogliomas are malignant tumors that generally occur in adults. They are rare tumors of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. On histology, cells have round nuclei with clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. Calcifications may also be seen on imaging. The location, patient age, and histology findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of frequent urination. Over the past few months, he has been waking up to urinate multiple times every night. He has noticed that his pants have become loose around the waist even though he has not made any changes in his diet. Past medical history is significant for essential hypertension. Family history is significant for a sister with systemic lupus erythematosus, and the mother has toxic diffuse goiter. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. BMI is 41 kg/m2. Physical examination shows the following skin findings over his neck and axillae:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

If pancreatic biopsy was performed, which of the following would most likely be seen?

choices.text: Atypical nuclei with intracytoplasmic mucin production
Nests and ribbons of cells with intervening stroma
Lymphocytic infiltrate of islets of Langerhans
Small serous cysts surrounded by collagenous stroma

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic symptoms of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) including polydipsia, polyuria, acanthosis nigricans (as seen in the image) and weight loss, all occurring over age forty. Diabetes mellitus is a condition in which glucose cannot be properly moved from the blood into the cells, which leads to high levels of glucose in the blood and not enough of it inside cells.  



In T2DM, the body makes insulin, but the tissues are unable to respond to it, which is called insulin resistance. Once insulin resistance happens, the pancreatic beta-cells begin producing more insulin in order to compensate. Along with insulin, beta cells also secrete islet amyloid polypeptide; so while beta-cells are producing insulin, they also secrete an increased amount of amyloid polypeptide. Over time, amyloid polypeptide builds up and aggregates in the islets. Histological analysis shows amyloid polypeptide deposits in the pancreas along with a variable number of beta-cells, depending on when the diabetes was diagnosed (beta-cells can die off over time in type 2 diabetes from being overworked).    

In contrast, patients with type 1 diabetes (T1DM) have lymphocytic infiltrates in the islets of Langerhans on histology, as a reflection of the underlying autoimmune process.  

Option Analysis

❌ Atypical nuclei with intracytoplasmic mucin production:
Incorrect: Atypical nuclei with mucin production are found in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, as a consequence of dysregulated cell division and function. Pancreatic cancer most often presents with abdominal pain, jaundice and weight loss; it is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.  
✅ Amyloid polypeptide deposits:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Nests and ribbons of cells with intervening stroma:
Incorrect: Nests and ribbons of tumor cells are found in pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. Most pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors are non-functional, but some, like insulinomas, secrete biologically active peptides. Insulinomas cause symptoms of hypoglycemia (confusion, sweats) rather than the polydipsia and polyurea seen in diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Lymphocytic infiltrate of islets of Langerhans:
Incorrect: Lymphocytic infiltrate of pancreatic islets of Langerhans is most often found in type 1 diabetes. Lymphocytes represent the ongoing autoimmune damage that causes type 1 diabetes, which most commonly occurs in young, non-obese patients.  
❌ Small serous cysts surrounded by collagenous stroma  :
Incorrect: Small serous pancreatic cysts surrounded by collagenous stroma are found in pancreatic serous cystic neoplasms. These benign cystadenomas are associated with a VHL tumor suppressor gene mutation. They usually occur in older women and are asymptomatic.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is evaluated for hematuria for the past 2 weeks. She had noticed a red tinge in her urine but denies dysuria or discharge. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. The patient does not use tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis reveals 10 RBC/hpf and no bacteria. CT scan of the abdomen is shown below, along with the results from a biopsy of the lesion.

 

Both images reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

This patient’s lesion most likely developed from which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
Renal oncocytoma is benign neoplasm that arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts. It represents approximately 10% of renal neoplasms. On imaging, a characteristic appearance of central stellate scar provides another clue for diagnosis, as seen here. On histology, the tumor is characterized by large eosinophilic cells with abundant mitochondria without perinuclear clearing. Patients are often asymptomatic, and the tumor is found as an incidental mass on imaging. Occasionally, patients may present with painless hematuria, flank pain, and abdominal mass. Resection is often performed to exclude malignancy.  



Option Analysis

❌ Proximal convoluted tubules:
Incorrect: Tumors arising from the proximal convoluted tubules are renal cell carcinoma. It is the most common 1° renal malignancy. It is typically seen in men 50–70 years old and is associated with smoking and obesity. On gross morphology, it is often seen as a golden-yellow lesion, due to high lipid content. Histology would demonstrate polygonal clear cells filled with accumulated lipids and carbohydrates.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Embryonic metanephric blastema:
Incorrect: Tumors that arise from the embryonic metanephric blastema are nephroblastomas (Wilms tumors). This tumor is the most common renal malignancy of early childhood (ages 2–4) and may arise sporadically or as a part of a syndrome (e.g. WAGR syndrome). This patient’s age and histological findings favor another diagnosis.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Perivascular epithelioid cells:
Incorrect: Tumors that arise from clonal proliferation of perivascular epithelial cells are renal angiomyolipomas. Renal angiomyolipoma may occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis complex. Histology would demonstrate adipose tissue, abnormal blood vessels with thickened walls, and spindle-shaped smooth muscle-like cells.  



Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Intercalated cells of collecting ducts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a breast lump she felt while showering. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension, which is managed with lovastatin and hydrochlorothiazide, respectively. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a lump in the right upper quadrant of the right breast and a palpable axillary lymph node are noted. She is sent for a mammography, which reveals no abnormalities. Ultrasound is obtained and shows a mass lesion. Core needle biopsy reveals the following image:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a palpable, nontender breast mass, nontender lymph nodes, a negative mammogram, and an ultrasound revealing a mass, all of which raises suspicion for a breast malignancy. The biopsy results show a classic picture of cells that invaded the stroma aligned in a “single-file,” which is characteristic of invasive lobular carcinoma. While most tumors appear as a palpable mass or mammographic density, a subgroup of invasive lobular carcinomas do not, as seen here. This allows lobular carcinomas to be clinically occult and difficult to detect by imaging, which often results in a worse prognosis.  

Invasive lobular carcinoma arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. It is the 2nd most common cause of invasive breast carcinomas and accounts for up to 15% of the cases. Morphologically, it consists of infiltrating cells similar to the tumor cells seen in lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Approximately one-third of women with LCIS eventually develop invasive carcinoma. Importantly, invasive carcinoma may arise secondary to LCIS in the same breast or in the contralateral breast, and therefore, bilateral imaging is indicated.   

In contrast to other types of breast cancer, which often metastasizes to the bone, brain and liver, invasive lobular carcinoma has a unique metastatic pattern, as it spreads to the cerebrospinal fluid, serosal surfaces, gastrointestinal tract, ovary, uterus, and bone marrow. The majority of lobular carcinomas express hormone (estrogen, progesterone) receptors, whereas HER2 overexpression is rare. Treatment usually conosist of clinical and radiologic follow-up, chemoprevention with tamoxifen or, less commonly, bilateral prophylactic mastectomy.  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  



Option Analysis

❌ Ductal carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lactiferous duct and does not cross the basement membrane. DCIS typically produces calcifications which appear on mammography.  


Reproduced from: flickr
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Invasive ductal carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive ductal carcinoma is an invasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the ducts, and crosses the basement membrane into the stroma. However, this patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis. Additionally, similar to ductal carcinoma in situ, it usually appears as calcifications on mammography.  
✅ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Comedo carcinoma:
Incorrect: Comedo carcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ that is characterized by extensive central necrosis. Transected ducts produce cheese-like necrotic tissue that extrudes from the ducts when gentle pressure is applied to the breast. However, this patient’s mammography and histology results favor another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of a two month history of weight loss and a right-sided neck mass. The patient reports a 6-lb (2.72 kg) weight loss over this same time period. He states the mass became somewhat painful on Saturday night when he was out drinking with his friends. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates right-sided, non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Hodgkin lymphoma is suspected. Which of the following biopsy results indicates a more favorable prognosis?

choices.text: Several Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes and few eosinophils and neutrophils
Broad bands of fibrosis separating cellular nodules containing Reed-Sternberg cells
Numerous Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by fibrosis and few lymphocytes
Reed-Sternberg cells with background infiltrate of eosinophils and neutrophils

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features that are characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL), including  painless cervical lymphadenopathy, B symptoms (fever, weight loss), as well as alcohol-induced pain lymphadenitis. HL encompasses a group of B-cell neoplasms that are characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells. Five subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma are currently recognized:  
 
  •  Nodular sclerosis is the most predominant subtype and is characterized by cellular nodules surrounded by fibrous bands of collagen.  
  •  Lymphocyte-rich and lymphocyte predominant are not common variants of HL, but they have the most favorable prognosis. As the names suggest, these variants demonstrate the RS cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes, with few eosinophils and neutrophils. 
  •  Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte-depletion are rare variants of HL and more commonly found in immunocompromised patients. Biopsy of this variant demonstrates mixed cellularity, and classically shows the RS cells with a background infiltrate consisting of eosinophils, neutrophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. The mixed cellularity variant has a variable prognosis, while the lymphocyte-depletion variant has a poor prognosis. 


Option Analysis

✅ Several Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by abundant lymphocytes and few eosinophils and neutrophils   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Broad bands of fibrosis separating cellular nodules containing Reed-Sternberg cells   :
Incorrect: With the nodular sclerosing variant of Hodgkin lymphoma, cellular nodules are surrounded by collagen bands containing variable numbers of Reed-Sternberg cells, within a mixed inflammatory background. While this variant is the most common (>60%), a different variant is associated with a more favorable prognosis.   
❌ Numerous Reed-Sternberg cells surrounded by fibrosis and few lymphocytes   :
Incorrect: This biopsy finding describes the lymphocyte-depleted variant of Hodgkin lymphoma. This variant is most commonly found in immunocompromised individuals and carries a poor prognosis.   
❌ Reed-Sternberg cells with background infiltrate of eosinophils and neutrophils   :
Incorrect: This biopsy finding describes the mixed cellularity variant of Hodgkin lymphoma. This variant is most commonly found in immunocompromised individuals and has a variable prognosis.

questions.text:
A histological section of the esophagus is taken from a healthy patient and examined under microscopy. The gastroesophageal junction is noted in this histological section, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding the gastroesophageal junction?  

Source: Histology guide

choices.text: Here, the epithelium changes from non-keratinized stratified squamous to columnar epithelium
It is considered an anatomical junction
Here, the epithelium changes from columnar to keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to columnar
Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) is a physiological junction between the esophagus and the stomach. It is marked by histological changes in the mucosal lining between the esophagus and the stomach.

In the GEJ, the cells lining the mucosa change from the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium of the esophagus to the simple columnar epithelium of the stomach. This transition can be noted at the GEJ. The other change that can be seen after this junction is that there will be less connective tissue between the glands of the stomach's mucosa.


Option Analysis

✅ Here, the epithelium changes from non-keratinized stratified squamous to columnar epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is considered an anatomical junction:
Incorrect: The gastroesophageal junction is considered to be a physiological junction, not an anatomical junction.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from columnar to keratinized stratified squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to columnar  :
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.  
❌ Here, the epithelium changes from cuboidal to non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium  :
Incorrect: At the gastroesophageal junction, the epithelial cells of the mucosa change from non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium.

questions.text: A segment of a peripheral nerve is taken and examined under the microscope. In the segment, the axons, nerve fascicles, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium were identified. Which of the following is true regarding these structures?

choices.text: Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium
The epineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle
The endoneurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle containing many nerve fibers.
Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the endoneurium
Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the perineurium

questions.solution:
Peripheral nerves comprise at least one bundle of nerve fibers called the fascicle, which contains many axons. The perineurium is a layer of connective tissue that surrounds each fascicle. This perineurium contributes to the blood-nerve barrier.  


Each nerve fiber inside the nerve fascicle is surrounded by a thin layer of connective tissue called the endoneurium. These nerve fibers surrounded by the endoneurium are made of axons (centrally located) and Schwann cells.  


Finally, the epineurium is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds the entire nerve and contains many fascicles. The epineurium also extends between the fascicles and holds them together. Blood vessels within the nerve are found in the epineurium.


Option Analysis

✅ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The epineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle  :
Incorrect: The perineurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle, which is made of a group of axons. The epineurium surrounds a group of nerve fascicles.  
❌ The endoneurium surrounds a single nerve fascicle containing many nerve fibers.  :
Incorrect: The endoneurium surrounds only one nerve fiber within the nerve fascicle. On the other hand, the perineurium surrounds a nerve fascicle.  
❌ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the endoneurium  :
Incorrect: The blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium.  
❌ Blood vessels within the nerves are found in the perineurium  :
Incorrect: The blood vessels within the nerves are found in the epineurium

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the office because of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough for the past two months. She reports that she often has to stop to catch her breath after climbing a flight of stairs to her apartment complex. She has seasonal allergies, for which she takes over-the-counter medications. Review of systems reveals occasional joint pain in the ankles and knees and painful swellings on the shins. The remainder of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness of the knees and ankles and tender, immobile, erythematous nodules on the shins bilaterally. Chest x-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. CT-guided transbronchial biopsy is shown:


Reproduced from Flickr

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s dermatologic lesions on the shins?

choices.text: Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to a contact allergen
Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics

questions.solution:
This patient presents with tender, erythematous shin nodules, exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, and arthralgias, together with a hilar lymph node biopsy demonstrating noncaseating granulomas. This presentation is diagnostic for sarcoidosis, a chronic granulomatous autoimmune disorder. The tender, erythematous nodules on her shins are most likely erythema nodosum (EN), which is a common dermatologic manifestation of sarcoidosis among other conditions (e.g., streptococcal infection, tuberculosis, coccidioidomycosis, histoplasmosis, hepatitis B, inflammatory bowel disease, and drugs, including oral contraceptives and penicillin).

EN is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction resulting in immune-complex deposition in the subcutaneous fat, causing inflammation. It classically manifests as erythematous, tender, immobile nodules on the shins bilaterally. It may follow a prodrome of malaise, fever, and upper respiratory tract infection. Diagnosis is usually clinical, but biopsy may be performed in case of an atypical presentation. It is a self-limited condition and usually resolves within a few weeks.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to a contact allergen:
Incorrect: Allergic contact dermatitis results from a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to contact allergens like nickel, chromium, cobalt, and poison ivy. It presents with well-demarcated, erythematous papules or vesicles with chronic lichenification. Although erythema nodosum is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, it does not appear in response to a contact allergen.
✅ Inflammation of subcutaneous fat cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics:
Incorrect: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics by Streptococcus pyogenes results in erysipelas. This condition manifests as a sharply-demarcated, fiery red, painful plaque at the site of bacterial entry. Presence of tender nodules on the shins with a non-caseating granuloma on lung biopsy suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Keratinocyte detachment within stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by bacterial exotoxin-induced destruction of keratinocytes resulting in their detachment in the stratum granulosum. The condition is characterized by a cutaneous, erythematous rash with sloughing and constitutional symptoms. Tender, erythematous nodules on shins would be atypical.
❌ Mast cell degranulation:
Incorrect: Acute urticaria, which presents with pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous wheals, results from mast cell degranulation. Tender nodules on the shins with difficulty breathing would be atypical.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the pathological changes seen in Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). According to the study, the nerve terminals in the peripheral nervous system lose their myelin sheath in GBS, leading to the disease manifestations. This myelin sheath is produced by which of the following cells in the peripheral nervous system?
questions.solution:
Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is a demyelinating disorder that affects nerves in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). The PNS contains all the nerves and the ganglia outside the central nervous system (CNS), i.e., the brain and spinal cord. The nerves of the PNS have many axons that convey signals from the CNS to the organs.  

Myelin is an insulating layer that wraps around the CNS and the PNS axons. It functions as an insulator and increases signal transmission speed by axons. Myelin production in the CNS is by oligodendrocytes, which are abundant in the white matter of the CNS. On the other hand, Schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons in the PNS.  

Option Analysis

✅ Schwann cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelinating nerve axons in the central nervous system, not the peripheral nervous system.
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibroblasts found in the nerves cannot produce myelin, and their function is unknown.  
❌ Microglial cells  :
Incorrect: Microglial cells are glial cells found in the central nervous system only, and they function as phagocytosing cells. They are incapable of producing myelin.  
❌ Astrocytes:
Incorrect: Astrocytes are only found in the central nervous system. They regulate blood flow, transfer mitochondria to neurons, and supply the building blocks of neurotransmitters, which fuel neuronal metabolism. However, they do not produce myelin.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with malaise and intermittent fevers over the past several weeks. She reports she was recently treated for a urinary tract infection, but her symptoms never completely improved. Her past medical history is significant for recurrent nephrolithiasis and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 157/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination shows left-sided costovertebral angle tenderness on palpation. If a biopsy of the kidney was to be performed, which of the following findings is most likely to be demonstrated on histologic analysis?

choices.text: Neutrophilic infiltrate of the renal interstitium
Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate

questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

This patient presents with chronic fevers, fatigue, and costovertebral angle tenderness in the setting of treatment failure for a urinary tract infection, consistent with chronic pyelonephritis. Her history is also notable for recurrent nephrolithiasis, which is a known risk factor for this condition.    

Chronic pyelonephritis refers to the worsening kidney function and scarring that occurs in the setting of either recurrent urinary tract infections (most commonly), poorly treated urinary tract infections, an impaired vesicoureteral reflux mechanism, or chronically obstructing kidney stones. Gross specimens will demonstrate coarse, asymmetric corticomedullary scarring and blunted calyces. Renal tubules often contain eosinophilic casts which resemble thyroid tissue, coined thyroidization of the kidney.  

Option Analysis

✅ Eosinophilic casts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages:
Incorrect: These histologic findings are more consistent with xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis, which is a rare form of chronic pyelonephritis commonly due to Proteus mirabilis infection. This disease is much rarer than generalized chronic pyelonephritis.  
❌ Neutrophilic infiltrate of the renal interstitium:
Incorrect: These histologic findings are more consistent with acute pyelonephritis, which tends to present with acute onset nausea, vomiting, dysuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness.  
❌ Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate:
Incorrect: These are the histologic findings associated with renal cell carcinoma, which typically manifests with hematuria, weight loss, and polycythemia.  
❌ Mesangial proliferation:
Incorrect: These histologic findings are more consistent with IgA nephropathy, which is characterized by episodic hematuria that occurs concurrently with GI infection or upper respiratory infection, due to deposition of IgA in the mesangium.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician’s office due to intermittent bleeding from the right breast for the past several weeks. She has had no recent trauma or unprotected sexual intercourse. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 4 days with light flow. The last menstrual cycle was 1 week ago. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs, and she states that she drinks alcohol occasionally. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her mother at age 60. Vitals are within normal limits. Breast examination shows no palpable mass, skin changes or nipple retraction. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy. When pressure is applied to the right breast, reddish-brown fluid is expressed from the nipple. Which of the following histopathologic findings is most likely to be seen on biopsy of this patient’s right breast?

choices.text: Branching fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells
Necrotic fat, bleeding, and giant cells
Large cells with clear cytoplasm infiltrating the nipple
Proliferating ductal elements nests in loose fibrous tissue

questions.solution:
Nipple discharge is among the most common breast complaints. It can be further divided according to the etiology, including lactational, physiologic (e.g., medication, neurological stimuli, etc.), and pathologic. Any discharge other than milk should raise suspicion for pathologic processes. These include serous (clear or yellow), sanguineous (bloody), or serosanguineous (blood-tinged). The most common cause of pathologic nipple discharge is intraductal papilloma, as seen in this patient.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 
 
Intraductal papilloma is a benign growth of papillary cells that grow into the lumen of the lactiferous ducts. It frequently presents as isolated, painless serous/bloody nipple discharge. Occasionally, it may present as a mass and/or tenderness. Mammography is mostly unrevealing or may show duct ectasia, calcifications, or a mass. Ultrasound may be more sensitive than mammography and show duct ectasia, nodules, or a cyst. MRI is the best modality to detect intraductal papilloma. On gross examination, it appears as a lobulated, soft, tan mass within a cystic cavity. Microscopically, it consists of a central, branching fibrovascular core with an overlying layer of epithelium. Although it is considered a benign lesion, it can harbor areas of atypia or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), and thus it is associated with a slightly increased risk for breast cancer. A biopsy is required for diagnosis. When biopsy demonstrates intraductal papilloma with atypical cells, surgical excision is warranted.  

Option Analysis

✅ Branching fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Necrotic fat, bleeding, and giant cells :
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with fat necrosis, a benign breast lesion that occurs in the setting of trauma or surgery. Patients often present with a firm and irregular mass. Fat necrosis often mimics malignancy on imaging and physical examination, and thus a biopsy is needed. The absence of a palpable mass and the presence of bleeding favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Acini and stromal fibrosis:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with sclerosing adenosis, a subtype of fibrocystic changes characterized by an increase in fibrous tissue and glandular cells within the lobules. Patients typically present with unilateral or bilateral, poorly-defined, tender, and lumpy breasts. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.   
❌ Large cells with clear cytoplasm infiltrating the nipple:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Paget's disease of the breast, which is an extension of underlying DCIS/invasive breast cancer to the lactiferous ducts and contiguous skin of the nipple. Patients typically present with eczematous patches over the nipple. On histology, collections of malignant, intraepithelial adenocarcinoma cells (Paget cells) are seen within the epidermis of the nipple. Although Paget's disease can present with bleeding, the absence of eczema or a palpable mass on physical examination makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Proliferating ductal elements nests in loose fibrous tissue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with fibroadenoma, a benign tumor of the breast, commonly seen in women in reproductive age. Patients often present with a small, well-defined mobile mass on physical examination. This patient has no palpable mass on physical examination, and the presence of bleeding makes fibroadenoma less likely.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious on the sidewalk. He is arousable to sternal rub. The patient’s family is contacted, and his next of kin reports that the patient is currently undomiciled. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient has been drinking a pint of vodka daily for the last 12 years, but does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 156/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals jaundice, palmar erythema, and pungent breath. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation; there is shifting dullness to percussion. The liver is not palpable. Which of the following is most likely to be present if a biopsy of the patient’s liver is performed?

choices.text: Regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands
Accumulation of glucocerebrosidase within hepatic macrophages
Periodic acid-Schiff positive spherical inclusion bodies in hepatocytes
Hepatocellular swelling and cytoplasmic emptying with diffuse neutrophilic infiltration

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of chronic liver disease (e.g., palmar erythema, jaundice, fetor hepaticus, ascites) and has a history of chronic alcohol use. He most likely has alcoholic cirrhosis. There are several factors that contribute to the pathogenesis of cirrhosis. However, cytokine-mediated activation of stellate cells is well established as the central driver of hepatic fibrosis.  

Cytokines are released when hepatotoxins, such ethanol and its breakdown products, destroy hepatocytes and trigger repair mechanisms. The inflammatory cytokines activate stellate cells, whose normal role is to store vitamin A. However, during states of constant hepatic injury, these quiescent stellate cells transform into proliferative, fibrogenic myoﬁbroblasts, which begin secreting TGF-ꞵ. TGF-ꞵ is a cytokine heavily involved in collagen production. As a result, as stellate cells proliferate and secrete TGF-ꞵ, there is excess collagen production.  

Over time, this constant cycle of destruction and repair leads to fibrosis and abnormal tissue architecture, ultimately impairing normal hepatic exocrine and metabolic function. Macroscopically, the fibrosis leads to a shrunken liver and a nodular liver surface with regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands.


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

✅ Regenerative nodules surrounded by fibrous bands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prussian-blue staining of hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Positive Prussian-blue staining is indicative of the presence of iron. This finding can be seen in patients with advanced hemochromatosis, wherein there is iron accumulation in various body organs. Although patients with hemochromatosis may present with cirrhosis, they typically have additional characteristic features, such as diabetes mellitus and bronze skin pigmentation.
❌ Accumulation of glucocerebrosidase within hepatic macrophages:
Incorrect: Gaucher disease is due to ꞵ-glucocerebrosidase deficiency and leads to the deposition of glucocerebrosidase within tissue. The condition can cause hepatosplenomegaly, avascular bone necrosis, and anemia. In contrast, this patient has none of these symptoms.
❌ Periodic acid-Schiff positive spherical inclusion bodies in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive staining of hepatocytes is suggestive of α1-antitrypsin deficiency, wherein misfolded protein aggregate and damage liver cells. Over time, this aggregation can lead to cirrhosis. Individuals also present with symptoms of severe emphysema (e.g., cough, dyspnea).
❌ Hepatocellular swelling and cytoplasmic emptying with diffuse neutrophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: Hepatocellular swelling (“ballooning”) with inflammatory cell infiltration is characteristic of acute viral hepatitis. The condition typically presents with concomitant fever, severe abdominal pain, and jaundice. In acute viral hepatitis, the liver would be enlarged and likely palpable on physical examination. Furthermore, the stigmata of cirrhosis (e.g., palmar erythema, fetor hepaticus) would not be expected in cases of acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. He does not have any abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has no family history of cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a few polyps in the colon. The polyps are biopsied and examined for abnormal histology. Which of the following histological subtypes is at the highest risk for malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
Colonic polyps are abnormal colonic mucosal overgrowths and become increasingly common with age. Therefore, screening for colorectal cancer is recommended in asymptomatic individuals aged 45 and over. The preferred screening tool is a colonoscopy, which allows for direct visualization, biopsy, and removal of polyps.  

Colorectal polyps are subdivided into non-neoplastic polyps and neoplastic polyps. Non-neoplastic polyps include hamartomatous polyps, hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory pseudopolyps, mucosal polyps, and submucosal polyps. Neoplastic polyps include adenomatous polyps and serrated polyps. Adenomatous polyps are the most common and clinically important neoplastic polyps, since they give rise to a majority of colorectal adenocarcinomas. Adenomatous polyps can further be characterized based on their histological architecture (e.g., tubular, tubulovillous, villous). Villous polyps have the highest malignant potential, tubulovillous polyps have intermediate potential, and tubular polyps have the least malignant potential. In addition, polyps that are larger in size have a greater chance of malignant transformation.


Option Analysis

✅ Tubulovillous adenomatous:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hamartomatous:
Incorrect: Hamartomatous polyps are made up of tissue elements that are normally found at that site but are growing in a disorganized mass. Although they have mild malignant potential, another subtype is at greater risk of transformation.
❌ Hyperplastic:
Incorrect: Hyperplastic polyps are the most prevalent non-neoplastic polyps in the colon. Small hyperplastic polyps rarely, if ever, develop into colorectal cancers.
❌ Inflammatory pseudopolyp:
Incorrect: Inflammatory polyps are non-neoplastic projections of mucosa consisting of stromal and epithelial components as well as inflammatory cells. This finding is commonly seen in patients with underlying inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis). Inflammatory polyps do not undergo neoplastic transformation.
❌ Mucosal:
Incorrect: Mucosal polyps, which are clinically insignificant, are usually small, less than 5 mm, and look similar to surrounding normal mucosa. They do not undergo neoplastic transformation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the physician for evaluation of a testicular mass, which the patient noticed a week ago while showering. The mass has not been causing pain or discomfort. However, the patient has been experiencing enlargement of the breast tissue and a decrease in facial hair. Temperature is 37.7°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 132/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a firm mass in the right testicle, which does not transilluminate with light. The cremaster reflex is present bilaterally, and there is no erythema of the scrotum. Bilateral breast enlargement is noted; palpation reveals centrally located glandular tissue and mild tenderness bilaterally. The remainder of the physical examination is non-contributory. Laboratory testing reveals normal placental alkaline phosphatase, α-fetoprotein, and ꞵ-hCG levels. Which of the following findings is most likely present within the patient’s testicular mass?

choices.text: Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Epithelial, cartilage, and smooth muscle tissue
Purulent material with a neutrophil predominance
Serous fluid originating from the peritoneal cavity

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a testicular mass, symptoms of hyperestrogenism, and normal ꞵ-hCG levels. He most likely has a Leydig cell tumor of the testis. Of note, choriocarcinoma can also cause hyperestrogenism but is associated with elevated ꞵ-hCG levels.

Leydig cell tumor is a type of sex cord stromal tumor with a bimodal age distribution, affecting prepubertal indviduals and those between the ages of 30-60 years. These tumors (unlike Sertoli cell tumors) originate from outside of the seminiferous tubules.

Clinically, Leydig cell tumors can be hormonally active, meaning they can secrete both male and female sex hormones. Excess male sex hormones, like testosterone, can cause premature puberty in young males, while in adults they usually cause no symptoms. Excess female sex hormones, like estrogen, can cause feminization and delayed puberty in young males. In adults (such as in the case of this patient), because of activity in Leydig cell aromatase that transforms testosterone to estradiol, signs of hypogonadism can be seen in males, including the following: unilateral or bilateral asymmetric gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction often associated with decrease of libido, infertility with oligo- or azoospermia, and feminine hair distribution.

On gross examination, Leydig cell tumors have a golden-brown appearance. On histology, they contain Reinke crystals, which are pink, rod-like crystals found within the cellular cytoplasm.



Option Analysis

❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors present with a markedly elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP), whereas this patient’s AFP level is within normal range.
❌ Epithelial, cartilage, and smooth muscle tissue:
Incorrect: Teratomas consist of tissue from all three germinal layers, which are the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. This type of tumor can contain epithelial cells, cartilage, and smooth muscle. However, teratomas would not typically manifest with the findings of hyperestrogenism (e.g., gynecomastia, decreased facial hair) as seen in this patient.
❌ Purulent material with a neutrophil predominance:
Incorrect: An infectious etiology, such as epididymitis, can lead to abscess formation and accumulation of purulent material. Patients with epididymitis typically have testicular pain and scrotal erythema, which are absent in this patient.
❌ Serous fluid originating from the peritoneal cavity:
Incorrect: Hydroceles are accumulations of serous fluid that arise due to failure of the processus vaginalis to fully obliterate. Although hydroceles can manifest as a testicular mass, they would transilluminate with light and would not cause symptoms of hyperestrogenism.
✅ Eosinophilic rod-like cytoplasmic inclusion bodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a low-grade fever and weight loss over the past few weeks. He has not had a cough, hemoptysis, or shortness of breath. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows non-tender lymphadenopathy of two adjacent cervical lymph nodes. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A biopsy of an affected lymph node is performed, which shows the following (see image below):  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s age, constitutional symptoms, presence of non-tender, contiguous lymphadenopathy (meaning adjacent lymph nodes), and Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells on lymph node biopsy all suggest Hodgkin lymphoma.  

RS cells are bilobed tumor giant cells that are CD15+ and CD30+ of B-cell origin, and their presence is the hallmark finding in Hodgkin lymphoma. Hodgkin lymphoma follows a bimodal distribution. Thus younger adults and teens, as well as older adults, are affected. As opposed to non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which has non-contiguous lymphadenopathy, Hodgkin lymphoma usually has contiguous lymph node involvement. The non-tender quality of the enlarged lymph nodes suggests the lymphadenopathy is caused by a neoplasm, rather than an acute infection.

Tip: Non-Hodgkin =  Non-contiguous, while Hodgkin = contiguous  



Option Analysis

❌ Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL):
Incorrect: Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL, previously called AML-M3) is a subtype of AML. AML composes a group of hematopoietic neoplasms involving precursor cells of the myeloid lineage with a median onset of 65 years. On smear, APL cells show Auer rods cytoplasmic inclusions. Since lymph node biopsy showed Reed-Sternberg cells in this case, and the physical exam revealed lymphadenopathy, lymphoma is more likely than leukemia. Leukemia usually presents with symptoms of bone failure such as anemia and bleeding.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Smear from a patient with APL showing abnormal promyelocyte with Auer rods  
❌ Burkitt lymphoma  :
Incorrect: Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma that usually presents in adolescents or young adults. Non-Hodgkin lymphomas typically show the involvement of multiple peripheral nodes in a non-contiguous spread. On peripheral blood smear, Burkitt lymphoma shows a sheet of mature B-cells with numerous tingible-body macrophages interspersed, giving a “starry sky” appearance.  


Reproduced from: Flickr  
Burkitt lymphoma “Starry sky”  
❌ Chronic myelogenous leukemia  :
Incorrect: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm causing dysregulated production and proliferation of granulocytes. Although the patient is in the peak age range for CML (45-85 years), the lymph node biopsy showed Reed-Sternberg cells, which is diagnostic for Hodgkin lymphoma rather than leukemia.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia commons  
Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) smear showing leukocytosis with granulocyte left shift  
❌ Hairy cell leukemia  :
Incorrect: Hairy cell leukemia typically occurs in adult males and is histologically characterized by the presence of mature B-cells with abnormal, hair-like projections. The most common symptoms include pancytopenia, due to bone marrow involvement, and massive splenomegaly. Reed-Sternberg cells are not seen in this condition.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Smear showing abnormal B-cells with hair-like projections  
✅ Hodgkin lymphoma  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A segment of the spinal cord is examined under microscopy. In the segment, the portion to the periphery was identified to be the white matter. Which of the following is true about white matter?

choices.text: It contains axons with abundant myelin sheath
It contains the cell bodies of the neurons in the central nervous system
Most of the glial cells are found in the white matter
Myelination of the axons is done by Schwann cells
It is only found in the spinal cord in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
The central nervous system comprises the cerebrum, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. The primary cells found in the CNS are neurons and non-neuronal cells (glial cells).  

The cerebrum, cerebellum, and spinal cord are divided into gray and white matters, which were made by their appearance in gross and microscopic examination. The white matter got its name from its lighter appearance because it is made of axons and abundant myelin sheath, and the myelin sheath disappears, leaving a white space. On the other hand, the gray matter comprises the neuronal cell bodies, its dendrites, and the glial cells (e.g., oligodendrocytes, astrocytes, microglial cells). The glial cells are mainly found in gray matter.  

The gray matter is found in the outermost portion of the cerebellum and cerebrum, while the white matter is found deep. The opposite is true in the spinal cord, where the white matter is on the periphery, and the gray matter is located in the center of the spinal cord.  


Option Analysis

✅ It contains axons with abundant myelin sheath  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It contains the cell bodies of the neurons in the central nervous system  :
Incorrect: The cell bodies in the central nervous system are found in the gray matter, while the white matter contains the axons of these neurons.  
❌ Most of the glial cells are found in the white matter  :
Incorrect: Glial cells are mainly found in the gray matter of the central nervous system, not the white matter.  
❌ Myelination of the axons is done by Schwann cells  :
Incorrect: Schwann cells are responsible for myelination of the peripheral nervous system neurons, while central nervous system neurons and nerve terminals (including axons in the white matter) are myelinated by the oligodendrocytes.  
❌ It is only found in the spinal cord in the central nervous system  :
Incorrect: The white matter is found in the spinal cord, the cerebrum, and the cerebellum.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to worsening fatigue and abdominal distention over the past 2 months. The patient has felt increasing fatigue, early satiety, and has lost 4.5 kg (10 lbs) without changes in diet. Medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus type 2 managed with metformin. The patient’s last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, bilateral adnexal masses are palpated. The vaginal exam shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows distention and shifting dullness. Hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. Histological analysis of the masses would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Tumor giant cells with bilobed nuclei
Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate
Sheets of malignant cells invading the stroma and concentric calcifications

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with ascites, bilateral adnexal masses, weight loss, and anemia, suggesting a gastric cancer with metastases to the ovaries, the so-called Krukenberg tumors. Krukenberg tumors are characterized by bilateral ovarian metastases from an undifferentiated gastric carcinoma. Although anemia is associated with many cancers, it is common in gastric cancer due to blood loss through feces.  

The majority of patients with gastric cancer are symptomatic. Weight loss and persistent abdominal pain are the most prevalent symptoms at initial diagnosis. Symptoms are location dependent and may include adenopathy (Virchow's node), ascites (peritoneal spread), palpable liver mass and jaundice, and Krukenberg tumors, as seen in this patient. On histology, Krukenberg tumor is characterized by abundant mucin-secreting, signet ring cells.  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons



Option Analysis

❌ Tumor giant cells with bilobed nuclei:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Reed-Sternberg cells (“owl eyes”), a distinctive feature seen in Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Patients present with constitutional signs/symptoms (“B symptoms”), including low-grade fever, night sweats, and weight loss, as well as contiguous lymph nodes abnormalities.
❌ Polygonal clear cells filled with lipids and carbohydrate:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with renal cell carcinoma, a primary neoplasm of the kidney. The presentation includes hematuria, palpable flank mass, flank pain, fever, and weight loss, as well as a variety of paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., ectopic EPO, ACTH, renin production).
❌ Keratin pearls and intercellular bridges:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Patients may present with cough, hemoptysis, bronchial obstruction, and wheezing, as well as the ectopic production of PTHrP.
✅ Abundant mucin-secreting, signet ring cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sheets of malignant cells invading the stroma and concentric calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with serous cystadenocarcinoma, a surface epithelial ovarian cancer. Patients with ovarian cancer may present with acute symptoms (e.g., pleural effusion, bowel obstruction) or chronic (e.g., abdominal symptoms, pelvic heaviness). Anemia, however, is not typical.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the physician with his parent due to severe abdominal pain for the past several days. The patient states the pain occurs “randomly” while playing,and would often go away on its own. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. The parent reports being called to meet with the boy’s teacher several times in the last 2 months due to the boy’s poor academic performance and inability to sit still. He also states that other children at the patient’s school have had similar symptoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Oropharyngeal examination reveals lines of hyperpigmentation on the gingiva. The abdomen is slightly distended and tender to palpation. Peripheral blood smear shows the following:    


Image reproduced from Flickr

Which of the following best describes the aggregates seen in the red blood cell identified by the arrow?
questions.solution:
This young boy is presenting with severe abdominal pain, constipation, neuropsychiatric disturbances, and basophilic stippling on peripheral blood smear. He most likely has lead poisoning. Lead poisoning can occur in children residing in buildings built before 1978, due to ingestion of lead paint chips or from consuming contaminated water from old, lead plumbing.  

Although most children with lead poisoning are asymptomatic, there is no safe blood lead level. Even low-level lead poisoning can lead to temporary or permanent central nervous system injury in young children. Patients may also present with a purple-blue line that is visible at the margin of the gums (Burton line).   

On a peripheral smear, lead poisoning can manifest with basophilic stippling. This finding arises since lead inhibits RNA degeneration, which causes ribosomes to aggregate and remain visible in erythrocytes as blue stipples. Additionally, lead inhibits several key enzymes involved in heme synthesis, resulting in microcytic anemia.   



Option Analysis

✅ Precipitation of ribosomes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Denatured hemoglobin:
Incorrect: Patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency have impaired regeneration of glutathione, which is an important antioxidant. As a result, oxidative stress can trigger hemoglobin denaturation. The denatured hemoglobin precipitates as small inclusions within red blood cells, which are microscopically visible as Heinz bodies. Although patients with G6PD deficiency may present with abdominal pain, they also have jaundice, dark urine, and an identifiable trigger (e.g., recent infection, use of certain antibiotics). 
❌ Clusters of deoxynucleic acid :
Incorrect: Normally during erythrocyte maturation, a small amount of DNA remains in the red blood cells (RBCs). These clusters are subsequently removed by the spleen. However, for patients who are asplenic or have functional asplenia (e.g. patients with sickle cell disease), these clusters of DNA remain in the RBCs. However, splenic dysfunction or asplenia would not account for the patient’s neuropsychiatric symptoms and gingival hyperpigmentation.
❌ Iron-laden mitochondria:
Incorrect: Ringed sideroblasts can be seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia. This finding is seen on a bone marrow biopsy, not on a peripheral blood smear.
❌ Complex formation from parasitic infection:
Incorrect: Patients infected with Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale can develop Schuffner stippling, often described as “brick-red granules” in erythrocytes on a Giemsa-stained blood film. These granules are formed by the parasites and are believed to be involved in nutrient uptake. However, this patient has no history of recent travel that would predispose him to a malaria infection.

questions.text: A 56-year-old nulliparous woman presents to the office for evaluation of vaginal spotting for 2 weeks. She has not experienced any associated pain or discharge. Menarche was at age 10, and she had a regular menstrual cycle until menopause at the age of 52. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for 20 years treated with metformin. She is on continuous estrogen replacement therapy for postmenopausal hot flashes for the last 3 years. Family history is significant for breast cancer in her maternal grandmother. BMI is 33.5 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows labial fullness, moist vaginal mucosa and a normal-sized uterus. Endometrial biopsy of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The histopathologic finding of glandular architecture admixed with solid areas together with postmenopausal bleeding in this patient are consistent with the diagnosis of type I (endometrioid) endometrial carcinoma.  

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common gynecological cancer in the developed countries. It is a pathological process that results from an increase in estrogen levels without accompanying increase in progesterone. A stepwise acquisition of genetic mutations is involved in the development of this carcinoma, including mutations in PTEN and KRAS and microsatellite instability. PTEN inactivation is the most common and is observed in early carcinogenesis. Major risk factors include obesity, early menarche, late menopause, unopposed estrogen therapy (ET), nulliparity, chronic anovulation and hereditary syndromes (e.g. Lynch syndrome). It clinically presents as unexplained dysfunctional uterine bleeding in pre or post-menopausal women. Ultrasound can be obtained in post-menopausal patients, which reveals endometrial thickness >5mm. However, endometrial biopsy is diagnostic and shows atypical glandular architecture with or without intervening solid areas.  

Option Analysis

❌  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This answer is an endometrial sample representing the secretory phase of menstrual cycle, where the endometrial glands become large and coiled under the effect of progesterone. This patient has passed menopause.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons:
Incorrect: This answer is a sample of uterine myometrium showing bundles of spindle-shaped cells with uniform size and shape indicative of a leiomyoma.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons:
Incorrect: This histologic image shows all three germ layers including mesoderm (top left), endoderm (center bottom) and ectoderm (right), typically seen in mature teratoma. Most women with teratomas are asymptomatic; however, symptoms depend upon the size of the mass. Abdominal fullness is a common feeling, with ovarian torsion as a common complication.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons:
Incorrect: This answer is a typical histologic picture of type II (serous) endometrial carcinoma showing a complex papillary architecture with psammoma bodies and nuclear atypia (high nucleus-to-cytoplasmic ratio, hyperchromasia and prominent nucleoli). It is less common and usually occurs after the age of 65 in the setting of endometrial atrophy.
✅  Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl comes to the pediatrician complaining of exertional dyspnea and easy bruising for the last 2 weeks. She had an upper respiratory infection 3 weeks ago. The remainder of the patient’s past medical history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 116/68 mmHg. Physical exam shows conjunctival pallor, large purple contusions on the legs, and petechiae on the inside of the mouth. The abdominal exam shows a non-tender, non-distended abdomen and no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing is obtained and reveals the following:  



Which of the following would most likely be seen on microscopic examination of this patient’s bone marrow?
questions.solution:
This patient had a recent upper respiratory infection, and laboratory testing reveals a decreased reticulocyte index and pancytopenia. She likely has aplastic anemia secondary to parvovirus B19 infection.  

Aplastic anemia, which is characterized by pancytopenia, is caused by failure or destruction of platelet, leukocyte, and erythrocyte precursor cells in the bone marrow. The best initial test in diagnosis is a complete blood count (CBC) with peripheral blood smear. This study will show a normocytic anemia with low reticulocyte index (< 2%), leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Iron studies, if performed, are normal. Definitive diagnosis is made via bone marrow aspiration, which would show a hypocellular bone marrow with fat cells and fibrous stroma.  






Causes of aplastic anemia include radiation exposure, environmental toxins (e.g. benzene), and certain medications (e.g., chloramphenicol, carbamazepine). Other causes include viral infections (e.g., EBV, HIV, parvovirus B19), autoimmune disorders, and Fanconi anemia. In some cases, aplastic anemia is idiopathic.  

Treatment includes red blood cell and platelet transfusions. It may also be necessary to discontinue the offending agent and administer immunosuppressants. Bone marrow stimulation with GM-CSF may also be helpful. Definitive treatment is bone marrow transplantation. 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: The image shows normal bone marrow histology. In contrast, this patient has aplastic anemia; microscopic examination would reveal a hypocellular bone marrow with fat cells and fibrous stroma. 
❌ :
Incorrect: The image shows a hypercellular bone marrow with immature cells, which is consistent with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, the patient in this vignette has aplastic anemia following an upper respiratory infection. Biopsy of her bone marrow would reveal hypocellularity, fatty infiltration, and fibrous stroma.
❌ :
Incorrect: This image shows a hypercellular bone marrow and cells with clear cytoplasm. It is consistent with leukemia and to be precise, hairy cell leukemia. Hairy cell leukemia tends to affect older males. Patients may also have hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. In contrast, it would be unusual for a young female to develop this condition.  
❌ :
Incorrect: This image shows a hypercellular bone marrow with increased blasts, which is consistent with myelofibrosis. Myelofibrosis tends to affect older individuals in their 5th and 6th decade of life. It would be unusual for myelofibrosis to affect a child. Moreover, the patient's history of a recent respiratory infection makes aplastic anemia more likely.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to abdominal pain that started suddenly several hours ago. Two hours ago, the patient felt a sudden, sharp pain in the lower abdomen during a routine workout at the gym. Since then, she has felt nauseated and vomited twice. Medical history is unremarkable. She denies any trauma or history of similar symptoms, vaginal bleeding, unprotected sexual intercourse, or history of sexually transmitted diseases. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 127/74 mmHg. On physical examination, there is no guarding, but severe, right adnexal tenderness is noted. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Doppler ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ovarian torsion and a thin-walled, unilocular cystic mass filled with anechoic fluid is visualized. The patient subsequently undergoes ovarian cystectomy and detorsion. The results of the histopathological examination are shown below:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy woman is presenting with ovarian torsion which is most commonly associated with a physiologic cyst (e.g. functional cyst) or a neoplasm. The ultrasound demonstrates a thin-walled, unilocular cystic mass filled with anechoic fluid, favoring the diagnosis of a benign lesion. Additionally, the histopathological examination demonstrates cuboidal non-ciliated epithelium resembling ovarian surface epithelium with underlying stroma containing fibroblasts, which is consistent with serous cystadenoma.  

Serous and mucinous cystadenomas are very common benign, epithelial, ovarian neoplasms. They are usually asymptomatic and may be found incidentally on physical examination or imaging. If the mass becomes large enough, it may present with pelvic pressure or pain, bloating, urinary symptoms or lead to ovarian torsion. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, are larger, and are less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, both are lined with columnar epithelial cells, whereas mucinous cystadenomas cells contain abundant amounts of mucin. The stroma of both types of benign lesions usually contains spindly fibroblasts.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mucinous cystadenoma:
Incorrect: Mucinous cystadenoma is a common benign ovarian tumor. Similar to serous cystadenoma, it is usually thin-walled, uni- or multilocular, ranging from 5 to < 20 cm in size. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, and are larger and less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, the cysts are lined by columnar epithelial cells with abundant intracellular mucin. This patient’s histological results favor the diagnosis of serous cystadenoma.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Serous cystadenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mature cystic teratoma:
Incorrect: A mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is a benign germ cell tumor that often contains elements of differentiated germ cell layers including ectoderm (e.g. hair follicles), mesoderm (e.g. muscle), and endoderm (e.g. lung). On imaging, it appears as a complex mass with hyperechoic contents and areas of acoustic shadowing. This patient’s imaging and histopathological results favor another diagnosis.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: flickr
❌ Endometrioma:
Incorrect: An endometrioma or "chocolate cyst" is a benign tumor that arises from the ectopic growth of endometrial tissue. Patients with endometriosis often complain of dyschezia, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. On ultrasound, it appears as a complex mass containing homogeneous internal echoes often described as "ground glass." This patient has none of these features.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Serous cystadenocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Serous cystadenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial ovarian neoplasm. Patients with ovarian cancer may be asymptomatic or present with bloating, urinary symptoms, early satiety, pelvic or abdominal pain, bowel obstruction, pleural effusion, and venous thromboembolism. Macroscopically, the tumor appears as a solid, hemorrhagic, and necrotic mass. Microscopically, it may be high or low grade, and papillary and psammoma bodies are usually seen. A malignant epithelial ovarian tumor is seen in women older than 40 years of age and would be unlikely in this young female.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to uterine bleeding and breast tenderness. Over the past 2 months, the patient has noted occasional bloody spotting on her underwear which requires using multiple pads throughout the day. In addition, she noticed her breasts have become tender and mildly swollen. She has no urinary symptoms. Menopause occurred 5 years ago. The patient’s last Pap smear 1 year ago was normal. Family history is remarkable for breast cancer in her mother at age 65 and diabetes mellitus in her father. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, both breasts appear engorged but without expressible discharge. Vaginal examination is normal other than minimal blood in the vaginal vault. Pelvic examination reveals a left-side adnexal mass. Laboratory tests show the following:


The patient’s mass is most likely predominantly composed of which the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a thecoma, a subtype of sex cord-stromal tumors. Definitive diagnosis can only be made by histopathological analysis. Thecomas are benign, solid, and fibromatous neoplasms, composed of theca cells arising from the ovarian stroma. The tumors are usually seen in postmenopausal women. Thecomas may produce estrogen and therefore often present with abnormal uterine bleeding, and up to 20% of patients have concomitant endometrial cancer. Grossly, the tumors appear yellow from accumulated lipids. Histologically, they are primarily composed of theca cells.  

Of note, some tumors may be pure stromal tumors (e.g. thecoma) and others mixed (e.g. thecoma fibroma). The same goes for sex cord tumors (e.g. Sertoli cell tumor vs. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). The hormonal production pattern and associated markers depend upon the cell types present.




Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
Thecoma

Option Analysis

✅ Theca cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulosa cells:
Incorrect: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumors. Granulosa cell tumors include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors do often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) in adults and sexual precocity in children. However, inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors and would be elevated, unlike in this patient.
❌ Fibroblasts:
Incorrect: Fibromas are the most common amongst sex cord-stromal tumors. Pure fibromas are benign solid tumors, are typically unilateral, and are not hormonally active, distinguishing them from this patient’s presentation. They occur primarily in postmenopausal women. Rarely, the tumor may lead to ascites and pleural effusion, a constellation of symptoms known as Meig syndrome. Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) may be elevated.
❌ Undifferentiated germ cells:
Incorrect: Dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor that is composed of undifferentiated germ cells. It is commonly seen in adolescents and young adults but rarely in the elderly. The presentation includes a rapid increase in abdominal girth and pain due to torsion or rupture with hemoperitoneum. Menstrual abnormalities are also seen if the tumor is hormonally active. Dysgerminomas may contain syncytiotrophoblastic cells that produce placental alkaline phosphatase, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) that can be used for monitoring. hCG production is also possible. This patient’s laboratory findings suggest a different diagnosis.
❌ Cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts:
Incorrect: Non-gestational choriocarcinoma is a rare and highly malignant type of ovarian germ cell tumor. The placental origin is far more common than ovarian origin. Those of ovarian origin arise from the extraembryonic differentiation of malignant germ cells, which differentiate to trophoblastic structures. Essentially, all choriocarcinomas produce hCG, which may lead to precocity in girls and/or irregular vaginal bleeding. Serum levels of hCG are used for monitoring response to treatment. This patient’s hCG is negative.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is referred to the clinic for the evaluation of a thyroid nodule. Medical history is significant for Hodgkin lymphoma as a teenager, for which she received radiation treatment. Temperature is 36°C (97.4°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a 2cm x 2cm hard nodule on the right lobe of the thyroid gland. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasound imaging suggests a malignancy, and fine needle aspiration is performed. Fine needle aspiration is most likely to show which of the following pathological findings?

choices.text: Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures
Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma
Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule
Malignant cells with nuclear clearing and indentations
Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures

questions.solution:
This patient, who has a history of exposure to ionizing radiation as a teenager, is now presenting with a suspicious thyroid nodule. She likely has papillary thyroid carcinoma. This is the most common type of thyroid cancer (80% of cases), and exposure to ionizing radiation in childhood is a significant risk factor. Additional risk factors include RET/PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations. Histologically, the tumor is composed of papillae, which are finger-like projections. The cells lining the papillae contain central clearing of the nucleus, which is why they are referred to as “Orphan Annie eyes,” and nuclear grooves (dark indentations within the nucleus). In addition, concentric calcifications, termed psammoma bodies, are often seen. The tumor usually spreads to cervical lymph nodes but carries a good prognosis.


Option Analysis

❌ Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures:
Incorrect: Undifferentiated malignant cells invading local structures is characteristic of anaplastic carcinoma. This highly malignant aggressive tumor, often seen in elderly patients, invades local structures and presents with compressive symptoms such as dysphagia, hoarseness, and respiratory compromise. This patient is young and has no signs of compression, which favors a different diagnosis.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma:
Incorrect: Malignant cells in an amyloid stroma is characteristic of medullary thyroid carcinoma. This tumor is composed of a malignant proliferation of parafollicular С cells, which secrete calcitonin. Calcitonin deposits within the tumor as amyloid. Familial cases are often due to multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A and 2B. In contrast, this young patient with a history of radiation and no other features of MEN syndrome more likely has papillary carcinoma.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule:
Incorrect: Malignant proliferation of follicles that invade the capsule is characteristic of follicular carcinoma. Identification of capsular invasion is essential in distinguishing follicular carcinoma from follicular adenoma, wherein the neoplastic cells are separated from the nearby tissue by an intact capsule. However, since fine needle aspiration only examines the cells and not the capsule, this finding would be unlikely.

Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Malignant cells with nuclear clearing and indentations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
