❌ Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures:
Incorrect: Normal cells with fibrosis that extend to local structures is characteristic of Riedel thyroiditis. Chronic inflammation leads to extensive fibrosis, leading to a hard, non-tender goiter. There also may be local compressive features such as dysphagia or hoarseness. This young patient with a history of radiation, a discrete thyroid nodule, and no features of local compression more likely has papillary carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a syncopal episode that he experienced while playing with his grandchildren. He reports new exercise intolerance over the past few months, noting that he now cannot reach the mailbox without experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath. He also notes that his urine appears darker than normal. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux disease. He denies alcohol or tobacco use. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mmHg. The patient appears pale. A systolic ejection murmur over the 2nd right intercostal space with radiation to the carotids is heard on auscultation. Laboratory tests are obtained and results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hematologic 
 Hemoglobin  9.2 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   88 fL 
 Platelet count  280,000/mm3  
 Reticulocyte count   4.2% 
Blood, plasma, serum 
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  1380 U/L 
Which of the following are most likely seen on this patient’s peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
This older male patient, who presents with angina, syncope, dyspnea, and a systolic murmur over the 2nd right intercostal space with radiation to the carotids, likely has aortic stenosis. The additional finding of dark urine suggests aortic stenosis-associated hemolytic anemia, a type of extrinsic hemolytic anemia caused by mechanical destruction of the RBCs as they attempt to squeeze past the stiffened aortic valve. Peripheral blood smear would demonstrate sheared erythrocyte fragments, or schistocytes. These cells, which can be seen in the image above, are typically removed by the spleen due to their abnormal shape. The resultant hemolytic anemia also presents with dark urine, which is caused by hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria. This usually occurs a few days later when the renal tubular cells, which absorbed the hemoglobin, slough off into the urine. Hemolytic anemia also presents with elevated reticulocyte count, due to a compensatory increase in erythrocyte production.  

Extrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem outside of the erythrocyte, whereas intrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem with the erythrocyte itself. Other causes of extrinsic hemolytic anemia include prosthetic heart valves, infections, hypersplenism, and immune-mediated causes.  




Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons   

Option Analysis

❌ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Incorrect: This peripheral blood smear shows the presence of acanthocytes. Acanthocytes, also known as “spur cells,” are associated with liver disease and abetalipoproteinemia.  
✅ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Incorrect: This peripheral blood smear shows the presence of dacrocytes. Dacrocytes, also known as “teardrop cells,” are associated with myelofibrosis and thalassemias.   
❌ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Incorrect: This peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells (RBCs) with the increased central pallor associated with iron deficiency anemia, a type of microcytic anemia. Microcytic anemia is defined by RBCs with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) less than 80 fL.  
❌ Reproduced from: Wikipedia:
Incorrect: This peripheral blood smear shows the presence of megaloblastic anemia, a type of macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils. Macrocytic anemia is defined by red blood cells with a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) greater than 100 fL.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man comes to his primary care physician because of fatigue, jaundice, and pruritus. His symptoms began 1 month ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis, which was diagnosed seven years ago, and hypertension. Family history is positive for cholecystitis in his older sister. In the office, his temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 147/88 mmHg, and pulse is 74/min. Physical examination shows jaundice, scleral icterus, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Total bilirubin  6.5 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  5.9 mg/dL 
 Alanine aminotransferase  127 U/L 
 Aspartate aminotransferase  115 U/L 
 Alkaline phosphatase  142 U/L 
Radiographic imaging and biopsy are scheduled as part of the work-up process. Which of the following findings will be most likely found on this patient’s biopsy?

choices.text: Lymphocytic infiltration of extrahepatic bile ducts only
Fibrosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts
Accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes
Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
This patient has primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), which is a progressive liver disease characterized by inflammation, fibrosis, and strictures of both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary tree. This finding is classically described as “onion-skin” fibrosis, because on histology, concentric rings of fibrosis around the bile duct can be visualized. PSC is classically diagnosed in middle-aged males with inflammatory bowel disease, such as ulcerative colitis. The etiology of PSC is unclear, but it is hypothesized to be an autoimmune disorder.  

Most patients complain of abdominal pain, pruritus, fatigue, and jaundice. The pruritis can be disabling, cause excoriations, and reduce quality of life. Patients can also have hepatomegaly.  

Magnetic response cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) can confirm the presence of bile-duct strictures and diagnose patients with PSC. There is currently no cure for PSC. However, ursodeoxycholic acid and immunosuppressants can be used to slow disease progression and improve symptoms. Liver transplantation is necessary for patients who develop cirrhosis secondary to PSC.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lymphocytic infiltration of extrahepatic bile ducts only  :
Incorrect: Patients with primary biliary cholangitis may have this biopsy finding. Primary biliary cholangitis is typically found in middle-aged females with autoimmune conditions. In contrast, the patient in this vignette is a male with past history notable for inflammatory bowel disease.
✅ Fibrosis of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: The accumulation of epinephrine metabolites in hepatocytes would be observed in patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome. The condition can cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, patients with this condition usually have normal liver enzymes and alkaline phosphatase levels. 
❌ Fibro-obliterative destruction of extrahepatic bile ducts:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in patients with biliary atresia. The condition typically affects pediatric patients, manifests in the first few weeks of life, and presents with symptoms including persistent jaundice and darkening of the urine. In contrast, it would be atypical for biliary atresia to develop in a middle-aged male.
❌ Calcification of the gallbladder:
Incorrect: This describes a “porcelain” gallbladder, which occurs when the gallbladder becomes calcified due to chronic cholecystitis. Although the patient has a family history of cholecystitis, he himself has no signs of cholecystitis, such as postprandial pain or Murphy’s sign.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. He recently returned from a trip to the Carribbean and began feeling ill on the return flight. He ate local foods there, including oysters and crabs. He states he is otherwise healthy but does drink 6-7 alcoholic beverages daily. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. On physical exam, the patient has jaundice of the buccal mucosa. Palpation of the right upper quadrant elicits significant pain. Laboratory results are as follows:


The patient is referred for liver biopsy, with histologic findings demonstrated below:


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following findings is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Ballooning degeneration of zone I hepatocytes
Bridging necrosis of zone III hepatocytes
Granulomatous degeneration of zone II hepatocytes
Thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein
Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and jaundice after eating oysters. The laboratory findings demonstrate an increase in ALT relative to AST, and the liver biopsy demonstrates councilman bodies. Together, these findings are consistent with viral hepatitis, most likely due to hepatitis A. Zone I is the region of the liver lobule primarily affected by viral hepatitis.  

Viral hepatitis refers to infection of hepatocytes caused by the hepatitis viruses A, B, C, D, and E. Regardless of the type of virus, the pathologic degeneration and zone of the liver lobule affected remains the same. Infection of hepatocytes in zone I results in hepatocyte injury and “ballooning degeneration” followed by hepatocyte death and “bridging necrosis.” Over time, this process results in the presence of councilman bodies or apoptotic globules of cells that represent a dying hepatocyte and panlobular mononuclear infiltration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ballooning degeneration of zone I hepatocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bridging necrosis of zone III hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Ethanol, halothane, and rifampin are associated with damage to zone III hepatocytes. This site has a high concentration of CYP-450 enzymes and is highly susceptible to toxic metabolites. This patient has an increase in ALT relative to AST, making alcoholic hepatitis less likely.
❌ Granulomatous degeneration of zone II hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis or tuberculosis can result in granulomatous degeneration of the differing regions of the liver lobule. Yellow fever is associated with damage to hepatocytes in zone II; however, it is not associated with granulomatous degeneration.
❌ Thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome refers to thrombosis of the hepatic portal vein. While this patient has recently returned from a long distance flight, he does not have a clinical history or other stigmata, such as active hepatocellular carcinoma, that would place him at risk for developing this condition.
❌ Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cirrhosis results in fibrosis between nodules of hepatocytes. While this patient does consume significant amounts of alcohol, the liver biopsy does not demonstrate fibrotic liver architecture.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of abdominal pain and bloody stools. The symptoms began three-weeks ago. The abdominal pain is intermittent and usually self-resolves within an hour. Past medical history is noncontributory. She has been meeting all developmental milestones. Physical examination reveals a nontender and nondistended abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory testing reveals the following:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.2 g/dL 
 Platelet count  260,000/mm3 
 Prothrombin time  14 seconds 
 Partial thromboplastin time  32 seconds 
 
A radiolabeled technetium-99 scan is performed and reveals increased uptake in a structure located in the right lower abdominal quadrant. The walls of this structure will most likely consist of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Meckel diverticulum, which occurs due to incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (also termed omphaloenteric duct). The remnant that is left behind is called a Meckel diverticulum. It is a “true” diverticulum since there is outpouching of all three layers of the intestinal wall (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis). In contrast, most other diverticula, such as diverticulosis, are “false” and contain only the mucosa and submucosa layers.  

Meckel diverticulum typically follows the rule of twos: it affects 2% of the population, is twice more common in males, is 2 inches long, is found within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve in the small intestine, and contains 2 types of ectopic tissue: gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue. The gastric mucosa secretes acid, and the pancreatic tissue secretes alkaline juices, both of which can erode the intestinal walls.    

Most patients are asymptomatic but some can develop abdominal pain and bleeding. Moreover, it can be a lead point for volvulus, intussusception, and subsequent bowel obstruction.  

The condition is diagnosed using a technetium-99 scan (“Meckel scan”), which can detect ectopic gastric mucosa in the intestines; therefore, Meckel diverticulum lacking gastric mucosa will not be seen on a Meckel' scan.

Option Analysis

✅ Mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis layers :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mucosa and submucosa layers only :
Incorrect: Patients with diverticulosis will have outpouching of only the mucosa and submucosa layers. The muscularis layer is unaffected. Diverticulosis typically affects elderly individuals with a history of constipation. It would be atypical for diverticulosis to manifest in a young child. 
❌ Mucosa layer only :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of intermittent abdominal pain and bloody stools. These symptoms raise concern for a Meckel diverticulum, which is characterized by outpouching of all three layers of the intestinal wall.  
❌ Granulomas and lymphoid aggregates :
Incorrect: Granulomas and lymphoid aggregates are seen in Crohn disease. The condition can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. However, it would be atypical for Crohn disease to manifest in a child this young. Moreover, results of the patient’s technetium-99 uptake scan are more consistent with the presentation of a Meckel diverticulum. 
❌ Fibrous bands of scar tissue :
Incorrect: This answer describes adhesions, which can occur after abdominal surgery. Adhesions can potentially cause a bowel obstruction. However, this pathology would not account for the increased technetium-99 uptake in the right lower abdominal quadrant, which suggests that there is ectopic gastric mucosa.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a skin lesion on the back of his hand. He first noticed the lesion 3 months ago at the site of a previous scar mark from a second-degree burn he endured while cooking as a chef nearly 35 years ago. His medical history is significant for chronic renal failure secondary to diabetes mellitus type II, for which he underwent renal transplantation 2 years ago. Current medications include insulin, cyclosporine and glucocorticoids. Physical examination shows a 1-cm scaly plaque on the dorsum of right hand and numbness over the hypothenar eminence. Biopsy of the lesion is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisading basal cells
Subepidermal microabscesses at the tip of dermal papillae
Saw-tooth lymphocytic infiltrates at the dermoepidermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a 1 cm scaly plaque at the site of previous scar and signs of perineural invasion (hypothenar numbness), in combination with immunosuppression (due to cyclosporine and glucocorticoids), is consistent with invasive cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC).

cSCC is the second most common malignant tumor of the skin, and it arises from epidermal keratinocytes. It is prevalent in fair-skinned individuals, and sun exposure is a major risk factor. Other associated factors include advanced age, immunosuppressive therapy, chronic non-healing wounds (such as from a previous burn), and chronic arsenic exposure. It commonly involves the sun-exposed areas including face, lower lips, ears, and hands. It is a fairly aggressive tumor which may present with early perineural invasion (regional numbness and paraesthesias). The lesion appears as 0.5-1.5 cm indurated or firm plaque, papule or nodule with or without hyperkeratosis and ulceration. Biopsy of the lesion shows dysplastic keratinocytes with ‘keratin pearls’ (arrows) involving the full thickness of the epidermis.



Option Analysis

❌ Nests of melanin-producing atypical melanocytes:
Incorrect: Nests of melanin-producing atypical melanocytes with large hyperchromatic nuclei, nuclear polymorphism, and a distorted architecture with dermal solar elastosis is typical of melanoma. It clinically presents as a hyperpigmented lesion with irregular borders and a diameter >6 mm. Perineural invasion is uncommon.
❌ Clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisading basal cells:
Incorrect: Clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisading basal cells are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). Although it is the most common skin cancer, BCC usually presents as a waxy, pink, pearly nodule with rolled borders and central ulceration. A scaly plaque with signs of perineural invasion is inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Subepidermal microabscesses at the tip of dermal papillae:
Incorrect: Subepidermal microabscesses at the tip of dermal papillae on biopsy are typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition is a dermal autoimmune reaction to dietary gluten and usually presents with intensely pruritic erythematous papules, vesicles, and bullae. A scaly plaque with signs of perineural invasion is unlikely.
✅ Dysplastic keratinocytes with keratin pearls:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Saw-tooth lymphocytic infiltrates at the dermoepidermal junction:
Incorrect: Saw-tooth lymphocytic infiltrates at the dermoepidermal junction are seen in lichen planus. It usually presents with a purple, polygonal, pruritic plaque or papule. A scaly plaque at the site of previous scar with neurologic involvement makes cSCC more likely.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of weight loss, increased appetite, and palpitations. The patient’s symptoms began around 5 weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for seasonal allergies and type I diabetes mellitus, managed with cetirizine as needed and insulin, respectively. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral eyelid lag and a mildly enlarged thyroid. Examination of the testes reveals a solid mass on the left testicle that fails to transilluminate. Laboratory testing is ordered and reveals the following:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Thyroid-stimulating hormone  0.2 µU/ml 
 Thyroxine (T4)  37 µg/dL 
 Triiodothyronine (T3)  170 mg/dL 

Histological analysis of the patient’s testicular mass would likely reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm
Tumor cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid

questions.solution:
This young patient is presenting with a testicular mass, clinical symptoms of hyperthyroidism, as well as laboratory testing demonstrating a reduced TSH and elevated T4 level. These findings are concerning for testicular choriocarcinoma.

Choriocarcinoma is a rare and aggressive form of testicular cancer that often metastasizes hematogenously to the brain and lungs. It most often affects young men between 20-35 years of age. The cancer is composed of cytotrophoblasts, which are immature cells with a central nuclei and pale cytoplasm, and syncytiotrophoblasts, which are more differentiated cells with multiple nuclei and a darker cytoplasm.

Laboratory testing will show elevated ꞵ-hCG levels but normal placental alkaline phosphatase and alpha-fetoprotein levels. The alpha subunit of ꞵ-hCG is structurally similar to luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). As a result, patients with choriocarcinoma can develop gynecomastia, due to hyperestrogenism secondary to FSH and LH activation, and hyperthyroidism (e.g., heat intolerance sweating, palpitations, eyelid lag). Furthermore, patients can develop hemoptysis, if there is lung metastasis, and neurological deficits, if there is brain metastasis.





Option Analysis

❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors typically result in elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and would not cause hyperthyroidism and hence would not account for the patient’s physical examination or laboratory findings.
❌ Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes cells with a “fried egg” appearance, which can be found in testicular seminomas. However, a testicular seminoma would not account for the symptoms of hyperthyroidism that this patient is experiencing.
❌ Presence of rod-like cytoplasmic inclusions:
Incorrect: Leydig cell tumors can produce androgens and estrogen, potentially causing precocious puberty and gynecomastia. Histological analysis of Leydig cell tumors would reveal Reinke crystals, which are eosinophilic rod-like structures found within the cellular cytoplasm. However, Leydig cell tumors would not manifest with symptoms of hyperthyroidism.
❌ Tumor cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Call-Exner bodies, which are found in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors are a type of ovarian cancer that most often affect middle-aged women. In contrast, this patient is a young male presenting with a testicular mass.
✅ Presence of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: As part of a research project, the uterus is examined histologically during different phases of the menstrual cycle. Which of the following is true regarding the physiology behind the menstrual cycle?

choices.text: The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.
The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle
The stroma of the functional layer tends to be less cellular in the proliferative phase
The proliferative phase is the only phase where the functional layer is regenerating
During the menstrual phase, the functional layer, and the basal layer are lost

questions.solution:
The endometrium is the innermost layer of the uterus and is made up of simple columnar epithelium. The endometrium is further divided into 2 layers, which are the functional layer (outer layer that is lost during menstruation) and the basal layer (attached to the myometrium and is not lost during menstruation).  

The functional layer of the endometrium is lined with simple columnar epithelium (which can be ciliated near the top), the endometrial glands (which are formed by evagination of the surface columnar epithelium and extends down to the basal layer), and stroma (containing blood vessels and supporting cells).  

However, the structure of the functional layer actually varies and undergoes significant changes during the phases of the menstrual cycle in order to prepare itself to receive an embryo.  

During the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, the endometrium starts proliferating to replace the layer lost as a result of the prior menstrual cycle. Here the functional layer is thin, and the stroma tends to be more cellular. The endometrial glands are also thin and straight during the proliferative phase with a narrow lumen.  

In the secretory phase, the endometrial glands begin secreting glycogen, which causes these glands to dilate and eventually coil. The dilated and coiled glands are the hallmark histological features of the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.  

Finally, if no embryo implants in the uterus, the functional layer is shed in menstruation, and this is known as the menstrual phase. Here, the functional layer tends to be very thin.  


Option Analysis

✅ The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The endometrial glands tend to be more dilated and coiled in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle  :
Incorrect: The endometrial glands tend to be thin and straight in the proliferative phase.  
❌ The stroma of the functional layer tends to be less cellular in the proliferative phase   :
Incorrect: In the proliferative phase, the stroma tends to be more cellular.  
❌ The proliferative phase is the only phase where the functional layer is regenerating  :
Incorrect: Regeneration of the functional layer begins in the proliferative phase, and continues in the secretory phase.  
❌ During the menstrual phase, the functional layer, and the basal layer are lost  :
Incorrect: In the menstrual phase, the functional layer is shed and lost. However, the basal layer remains attached and aids in the regeneration of the functional layer for the next menstrual cycle.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to rhythmic jerking of the limbs followed by a period of drowsiness and confusion. Her husband reports she has been experiencing mild headaches for the past 2 years that occasionally awoke her from sleep, in addition to some noticeable left leg weakness over the past few months. The patient denies any trauma or vision changes. Neurological examination shows increased tone and hyperreflexia in the left lower extremity. Magnetic resonance imaging of the head is obtained and reveals a right parasagittal intracranial mass. The patient undergoes a biopsy of the lesion, and the results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following cell types is most likely responsible for this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a seizure, headaches, and evidence of a focal neurological deficit affecting the left lower limb (weakness, hypertonicity, and hyperreflexia). These features combined with a parasagittal mass seen on imaging, as well as the characteristic psammoma bodies seen on histology, suggests that this patient has a meningioma.  

Meningiomas are tumors of arachnoid cell origin that commonly grow in the parasagittal region external to the brain parenchyma (extra-axial), often having a dural attachment (“tail”). On histology, the tumor is composed of spindle cells concentrically arranged in a whorled pattern and have characteristic psammoma bodies (laminated calcifications). The tumor can be asymptomatic, or may present with seizures or focal neurologic deficits. Treatment includes resection and/or radiosurgery.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Oligodendrocyte cells:
Incorrect: Oligodendrogliomas are tumors of oligodendrocyte origin that often grow in the frontal lobes. On histology, cells have round nuclei with a clear cytoplasm forming a “fried egg” appearance, and the capillaries of the tumor are arranged in a “chicken-wire” pattern. This tumor location as well as appearance on histology favors the diagnosis of meningioma.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons 
✅ Arachnoid cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Endothelial cells:
Incorrect: Hemangioblastomas are uncommon, slow-growing tumors, which typically occur in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Hemangioblastomas can occur both sporadically and as a component of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease. On histology, hemangioblastomas are compohused of an extensive vascular network and neoplastic "stromal cells,” which are embedded among the vascular channels. The neoplastic cells have abundant cytoplasm packed with lipid vacuoles.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Schwann cells:
Incorrect: Schwannomas are tumors of Schwann cell origin that grow along the peripheral nerves, most commonly involving both cranial nerves VII and VIII. On histology, it stains positive for S-100 and characterized by a biphasic architecture: Antoni A-dense, hypercellular areas containing spindle cells, alternating with Antoni B-hypocellular myxoid areas. This patient’s lesion location and histological appearance favors the diagnosis of meningioma.  



Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons  
❌ Ependymal cells:
Incorrect: Ependymomas are a group of tumors that arise from glial cells lining the ventricular system. They most commonly occur in the 4th ventricle, leading to hydrocephalus. On histology, cells form characteristic perivascular pseudorosettes.

 


Reproduced by: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text: An investigator is studying the biopsy specimen from a region of the gastrointestinal tract. Histologically, this area of the digestive tract contains crypts of Lieberkuhn and many goblet cells and lacks villi. Which of the following segments of the digestive tract is the investigator most likely studying?
questions.solution:
The colon makes up the longest part of the large intestine. It begins from the caecum at the ileocecal valve and ends in the rectum. The colon can be distinguished histologically from the small intestine based on the absence of villi in the former. Crypts of Lieberkuhn, enteroendocrine cells, and many goblet cells are also present in the colon.  


Option Analysis

✅ Colon:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Duodenum:
Incorrect: The duodenum is histologically characterized by abundant villi and microvilli, Brunner glands (bicarbonate-secreting cells), and crypts of Lieberkuhn.  
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus is histologically characterized by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Crypts of Lieberkuhn and goblet cells are not present.  
❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: The ileum of the small intestine is histologically characterized by villi, Peyer patches, plicae circulares, crypts of Lieberkuhn, and an abundance of goblet cells.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: The jejunum is histologically characterized by villi, plicae circulares, and crypts of Lieberkuhn.

questions.text:
A histological sample is collected from an area in the gastrointestinal tract to identify the different types of cells and structures. The picture of the sample under the microscope is shown below. To which part of the gastrointestinal tract does this sample most likely belong?
 

Source: histological guide
questions.solution:
The gastrointestinal tract has histological features that can be similar in different parts, but quite a few differences help distinguish other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

In the proximal duodenum, specifically the first part of the duodenum, the Brunner glands can be visualized, which are submucosal glands (arrow in picture). The function of these glands is to form a mucous layer to protect the duodenal lining from acid damage. The secretions from these glands are alkaline, which also helps neutralize the acidity of the food coming from the stomach.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ First part of the duodenum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Last part of the duodenum  :
Incorrect: The sample in the picture above shows Brunner glands, only found in the proximal duodenum.  
❌ Jejunum:
Incorrect: The histological sample of the jejunum usually contains enterocytes and goblet cells. Brunner glands are not seen in the jejunum.  
❌ Ileum:
Incorrect: The histological sample of the ileum usually contains small collections of lymphatic tissue (Peyer patches) in addition to the villous architecture. It does not have Brunner glands like the first part of the duodenum.  
❌ Stomach:
Incorrect: Villi and the Brunner gland suggest that this sample was taken from the proximal duodenum, not the stomach, which does not contain either. A microscopic examination of the stomach shows gastric glands in the mucosa.

questions.text: A group of researchers is examining the different parts of the kidney histologically. A segment of the kidney is taken and visualized under the microscope as shown below. The arrow in the picture is pointing towards which of the following cells?

choices.text: Parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule

questions.solution:
The renal corpuscle is the area in the nephron where the blood is initially filtered. This filtered fluid is then modified in the renal tubules to produce urine.  

The renal corpuscle is made of a tuft of capillaries called the glomerulus, surrounded by a capsule called the bowman’s capsule. The filtered fluid from the glomerulus goes into the bowman’s space.  

Lining the glomerulus is a fenestrated layer of endothelial cells; these fenestrations allow the filtered fluids and molecules to pass. The bowman’s capsule is lined with two layers: the outer layer, called the parietal layer, which is made of flat simple squamous epithelium, and the visceral layer, made of specialized cells called podocytes. These podocytes line around the endothelial cells of the glomerulus and have a particular function in filtration by their foot processes (which are elongated structures from the cells that form a physical barrier to prevent larger molecules like proteins from being filtered). The oval basophilic nucleus can identify the podocytes. Finally, another type of cell can also be found in the glomerulus called the mesangial cell. These cells have darker and more round nuclei than the podocytes and function in regulating blood flow to the kidney and in immune defense and repair.  


Option Analysis

✅ Podocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mesangial cells  :
Incorrect: Although mesangial cells can be challenging to differentiate from podocytes, they usually have a round and darker nucleus, unlike the podocytes, whose nucleus is more oval.  
❌ Endothelial cells  :
Incorrect: Endothelial cells line the glomerulus capillary. The arrow is pointing at a podocyte.  
❌ Parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule  :
Incorrect: The parietal layer of the bowman’s capsule is the outer layer of the capsule that consists of squamous epithelium. The arrow is pointing toward podocytes.  
❌ Alpha intercalated cells  :
Incorrect: Alpha intercalated cells are found in the collecting tubules, not the glomerulus.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a 6 month history of worsening retrosternal burning pain and coughing after eating. The patient reports he has had similar symptoms over the past 10 years but states they have never been this severe. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. The patient's family history is significant for esophageal adenocarcinoma in his older brother. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed, and an image of the gastroesophageal junction is shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

A biopsy of this lesion is most likely to demonstrate which of the following pathological changes?
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of chronic, worsening gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is at an increased risk of developing Barrett esophagus. An upper endoscopy study will show erythematous mucosa (also referred to as salmon-colored mucosa) at the junction of the esophagus and stomach. Barrett esophagus refers to metaplasia of the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus to columnar epithelium with goblet cells due to prolonged acidic content exposure. Biopsies will reveal a transition from stratified squamous epithelium to columnar epithelium with goblet cells as detailed in the histologic image below:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia  

Barrett esophagus is considered premalignant esophageal adenocarcinoma, the most common esophageal carcinoma in the United States. Patients with Barrett esophagus should have an upper endoscopy study every five years to monitor for progression of metaplasia into dysplastic tissue. Treatment includes proton pump inhibitors and H2 receptor blockers; however, patients who still experience symptoms of acid reflux despite medical therapy may require surgical management.  

Option Analysis

✅ Columnar epithelium with goblet cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Columnar epithelium with cilia:
Incorrect: The trachea and bronchi are lined with columnar epithelium and cilia. The motile nature of the cilia allows for the expulsion of particles in the respiratory tract. Histology will also show goblet cells and club cells.  
❌ Columnar epithelium with parietal cells:
Incorrect: Parietal cells are specialized cells which normally line the fundus and body of the stomach and are not generally found in the metaplasia of Barrett esophagus. Parietal cells produce stomach acid and release intrinsic factor for vitamin B12 absorption and are modulated by gastrin, histamine, and acetylcholine.   
❌ Non-keratinized squamous epithelium:
Incorrect: The esophagus is normally lined with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. The epithelium undergoes rapid turnover and serves to protect the inner layers of the esophagus from mechanical abrasion during swallowing.   
❌ Transitional epithelium:
Incorrect: Transitional epithelium consists of basal, intermediate, and superficial cell layers. These cells line the ureters and bladder and play an important role in allowing for distension and contraction of these tissues.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of a “gritty” sensation in the eyes for the last several months. She states her eyes have also been increasingly itchy and red, and she also needs to chew food for a longer period of time in order to swallow it properly. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis that is well managed with methotrexate. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows redness of both eyes. Bilateral wrist and first metacarpophalangeal joints show mild swelling and tenderness. There is nontender, diffuse parotid gland enlargement bilaterally. Oral examination reveals mucosal atrophy and multiple dental caries. Ophthalmologic examination reveals decreased visual acuity in both eyes. A strip of litmus filter paper is folded at one end and inserted in the patient's lower eyelid; after 5 minutes, there is < 5 mm (normal > 15 mm) of moisture on the filter paper. Multiple corneal punctate spots are noted on fluorescein staining. Labial salivary gland biopsy would most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Numerous tightly aggregated clusters of lymphocytes with interstitial fibrosis and glandular atrophy
Acinar atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and ductal dilatation with no lymphocytic infiltrates
Well-differentiated lesions with prominent keratinization and “pearl-like” structures invading the basement membrane
Mixed cellular constitution with myoepithelial cells and chondroid tissue
Uniform hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the acinar parenchyma of salivary glands
Uncontrolled proliferation of monoclonal B-cells surrounding the ducts

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with sicca symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes), abnormal Schirmer test (wherein litmus paper is used to evaluate for decreased lacrimal gland function), and corneal damage on fluorescein staining. She most likely has Sjogren syndrome.  

Sjogren syndrome is characterized by chronic inflammation of the exocrine glands. Work-up will involve checking for autoantibodies, such as anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La antibodies. In addition, a Schirmer test and fundoscopic examination with fluorescein staining can be performed to evaluate for lacrimal gland function and corneal injury, respectively.  

Labial salivary gland biopsy, while not necessary for diagnosis, is useful for confirmation. Biopsy would show focal (nodular) lymphocytic infiltrates resulting in glandular atrophy and subsequent decreased salivary and lacrimal gland function. Treatment is generally symptomatic, involving secretagogues (e.g. muscarinic agonists) to increase saliva and tear production. Moderate to severe cases involving other organs (e.g., interstitial lung disease, interstitial nephritis) require systemic glucocorticoids or disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Numerous tightly aggregated clusters of lymphocytes with interstitial fibrosis and glandular atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Acinar atrophy, interstitial fibrosis, and ductal dilatation with no lymphocytic infiltrates:
Incorrect: This finding of glandular atrophy without lymphocytic infiltration is seen in age-related sicca syndrome. In this condition, age-related atrophy of secreting tissue results in decreased tear and saliva flow rates. There is an absence of lymphocytes since it is not caused by an inflammatory process. This patient with parotid gland enlargement, positive Schirmer test, and corneal lesions likely has Sjogren syndrome, a chronic inflammatory process, making this biopsy finding unlikely.
❌ Well-differentiated lesions with prominent keratinization and “pearl-like” structures invading the basement membrane:
Incorrect: This pathologic finding is seen in squamous cell carcinoma. This patient has diffuse, bilateral parotid gland swelling, whereas patients with squamous cell carcinoma typically have nodular enlargement. Moreover, this patient has sicca symptoms (e.g., dry mouth, dry eyes), which further makes squamous cell carcinoma a less likely diagnosis.
❌ Mixed cellular constitution with myoepithelial cells and chondroid tissue:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas most commonly occur in the parotid gland and normally present as a unilateral, movable mass. In contrast, this patient has bilateral parotid gland swelling and sicca symptoms, making pleomorphic adenoma an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Uniform hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the acinar parenchyma of salivary glands:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of sialadenosis. Sialadenosis is a recurrent, noninflammatory swelling of the salivary glands. It can be seen in certain endocrine disorders (e.g. diabetes mellitus), alcoholism, and malnutrition. This patient’s sicca symptoms and diagnostic findings are suggestive of a different underlying disorder. 
❌ Uncontrolled proliferation of monoclonal B-cells surrounding the ducts:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, which can be seen in patients with chronic, uncontrolled Sjogren syndrome. MALT lymphoma classically presents as a unilateral and nodular mass. In contrast, this patient has bilateral, diffuse enlargement of the parotid glands, which is indicative of another condition.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of a 12-lb weight gain over the past two months. The patient is a vegetarian and her diet consists of fruits, vegetables, and grains. She has had no increase in appetite. The patient also complains of excessive fatigue but attributes it to her stressful job as a nurse. Three months ago, she experienced recurrent episodes of anxiety, palpitations, and unintentional weight loss of 8-lb; these episodes resolved on their own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 52/min, blood pressure is 124/88 mm Hg, and BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals cold, dry skin and thinning hair on the scalp. Neck palpation reveals no tenderness or masses. There is delayed tendon reflex relaxation in the lower extremities. Diagnostic testing shows the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   137 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride   99 mEq/L 
 Glucose  89 mEq/L 
 ESR  9 mm/hr 
 TSH  7.1 μU/mL 
 Anti-thyroid peroxidase   Positive 

BIopsy of this patient’s thyroid will most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with germinal center formation and destruction of follicles
Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells
Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications
Tall, crowded follicular cells with decreased colloid and peripheral scalloping
Obliterated follicles compressed by dense, fibrous, collagenous tissue

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with cold, dry skin, delayed tendon reflexes, and positive anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies. She most likely has Hashimoto thyroiditis.   

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common form of autoimmune thyroiditis, as well as the most frequent cause of hypothyroidism in the United States. In this condition, B lymphocytes produce antibodies against thyroglobulin (Tg) and/or thyroid peroxidase (TPO), resulting in diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the thyroid gland. Since there is thyroid follicular cell destruction, there is occasionally an early episode of hyperthyroidism (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, weight loss) due to leakage of preformed T3 and T4, as seen in this patient. On histology, there can be Hürthle cells, which are also called oncocytes; these cells arise from the follicular epithelium and have an eosinophilic cytoplasm and a vesicular nucleus with a large nucleolus. There can also be lymphoid aggregates with germinal center formation.   





Option Analysis

✅ Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration with germinal center formation and destruction of follicles:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells:
Incorrect: This pathological finding is seen in subacute granulomatous thyroiditis (i.e. de Quervain thyroiditis). This condition may also present with initial hyperthyroidism (e.g., anxiety, palpitations, weight loss) due to the damaged thyroid follicular cells releasing preformed T3 and T4, followed by hypothyroidism due to granulomatous inflammation of the thyroid gland. A key characteristic finding of this condition, however, is a tender thyroid gland, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications:
Incorrect: This pathological finding is consistent with papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The “empty-appearing nuclei” describe the Orphan Annie nuclei, which are characteristic of papillary carcinoma. Additionally, the dispersed concentric lamellar calcifications describe psammoma bodies. Patients with papillary carcinoma usually present with a painless thyroid mass and have normal TSH levels. In contrast, this patient has no thyroid masses and an elevated TSH, making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Tall, crowded follicular cells with decreased colloid and peripheral scalloping :
Incorrect: This pathological finding is characteristic of Graves disease, which is a form of hyperthyroidism. Patients form autoantibodies to the TSH-receptors on the thyroid gland, which leads to thyroid gland overstimulation. The resulting activation of follicular cells induces reabsorption of stored colloid (giving rise to the pathognomonic, diffuse scalloping seen on biopsy) as well as production and release of T3 and T4. 
❌ Obliterated follicles compressed by dense, fibrous, collagenous tissue:
Incorrect: This biopsy finding is consistent with Riedel thyroiditis, which is another form of autoimmune thyroiditis. In this condition, there is invasive fibrous growth in the thyroid, often extending into neighboring organs. The condition can present as a hard, enlarged thyroid and cause symptoms secondary to compression (e.g., dysphagia, dyspnea). The patient’s clinical symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 20 minutes of crushing chest pain and diaphoresis that began suddenly while watching television. According to the patient’s partner, lately he has had occasional chest pain occurring during rest that resolved after a few minutes. Medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus. The patient has not been compliant with the medications. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6° F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. The patient appears to be in acute distress and in pain. Cardiac examination shows an additional sound just prior to S1 on auscultation. ECG demonstrates ST segment elevation in leads V1-V5. While being prepared for percutaneous coronary intervention, the patient suddenly dies. Following this patient’s death, an autopsy is performed to better understand the underlying pathology. At the time of this patient's death, which of the following sets of findings is most likely to be seen in the anterior wall of the myocardium?

choices.text: Gross changes Microscopic changes Red gray infarct  Extensive phagocytosis and granulation tissue
Gross changes Microscopic changes  Mottling with a yellow-tan center Coagulative necrosis and acute inflammation with neutrophils
Gross changes Microscopic changes Hyperemic border with a yellow-tan centerMyofiber disintegration and acute inflammation with macrophages
Gross changes Microscopic changes Dark mottling Coagulation necrosis and contraction bands
Gross changes Microscopic changes None  No changes and/or presence of wavy fibers
Gross changes Microscopic changes Grey-white to white color  Dense collagen

questions.solution:
This patient suffered an acute myocardial infarction (MI) complicated by ventricular arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death. Up to four hours after a MI, no changes are expected on gross morphology, while microscopic appearance varies from no changes seen to the presence of wavy fibers. The wavy appearance reflects the stretching and buckling of noncontractile dead fibers.  

The following chart summarizes the gross morphologic changes, microscopic changes, and possible complications based on the time since MI:  



Option Analysis

❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Red gray infarct  Extensive phagocytosis and granulation tissue :
Incorrect: These changes are expected 7-14 days after myocardial infarction.
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes  Mottling with a yellow-tan center Coagulative necrosis and acute inflammation with neutrophils:
Incorrect: These changes are expected 1-3 days after myocardial infarction. 
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Hyperemic border with a yellow-tan centerMyofiber disintegration and acute inflammation with macrophages:
Incorrect: These changes are expected 3-7 days after myocardial infarction. 
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Dark mottling Coagulation necrosis and contraction bands:
Incorrect: These changes can be seen 4-24 hours after myocardial infarction. Ongoing coagulation necrosis will result in pyknosis of the nuclei (condensation of chromatin) and hypereosinophilic appearance of myocytes, due to contraction band formation. Contraction bands are a unique finding for cardiac myocytes; they are thought to arise from reperfusion and hypercontraction, which results in sarcolemmal rupture leading to free calcium influx. 
✅  Gross changes Microscopic changes None  No changes and/or presence of wavy fibers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Gross changes Microscopic changes Grey-white to white color  Dense collagen  :
Incorrect: The formation of a fibrous scar consisting of dense collagen begins after two weeks and is completed within several months after myocardial infarction.

A 69-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with dysphagia. The patient reports progressive difficulty swallowing, now to the point where he has trouble tolerating liquids and sometimes vomits after eating. The patient has a significant history of alcohol abuse, 50-pack-year smoking history, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical exam shows a thin male with bitemporal wasting and non-tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Oral and neck examination is unremarkable aside from poor dentition. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
CBC, Serum 
 Hemoglobin  11.2  g/dL 
 Hematocrit  33.6% 
 Leukocyte count  10,100 /mm3 
 Platelet count  149,000/mm3 
 MCV                        72 fL 
 RDW                    11.5-14.5% 
 Iron Studies, Serum

A barium swallow study reveals an esophageal mass that significantly narrows the lumen in the middle of the esophagus. Which of the following pathologic features is most likely to be found on upper endoscopy?

choices.text: Columnar dysplasia with goblet cell crowding and invasion into the lamina propria
Invasion of neoplastic squamous cells into the lamina propria
Loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus

questions.solution:
This patient with a significant smoking and alcohol abuse history, cachexia, lymphadenopathy and microcytic anemia raises concern for esophageal carcinoma, of which the squamous cell variant is most likely.  

Esophageal carcinoma gets divided into two types: squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. In general, the two variants are clinically indistinguishable, but typically present with weight loss and progressive difficulty swallowing. Laboratory results may show either an anemia of chronic disease pattern, as in this patient, or iron deficiency anemia due to chronic blood loss from the invading tumor.    

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common variant worldwide and is attributable to >95% of cases. It most commonly occurs in the upper or middle 2/3 of the esophagus, with alcohol abuse and smoking as the greatest risk factors. Adenocarcinoma typically occurs in the lower or distal third of the esophagus and is a consequence of untreated Barrett esophagus due to long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Treatment of the cancer depends on both grade and stage but generally involves a combination of both surgery and chemo-radiation.    

Option Analysis

❌ Columnar metaplasia with goblet cells :
Incorrect: Columnar metaplasia with goblet cells describes the pathohistology of Barrett esophagus, the precursor to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. This older patient presenting with cachexia, a significant history of alcohol and tobacco use, and an esophageal mass more likely has a neoplastic process occurring.
❌ Columnar dysplasia with goblet cell crowding and invasion into the lamina propria:
Incorrect: This describes the features of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. While difficult to distinguish clinically, this cancer variant is less likely in this patient with a strong history of smoking and alcohol一the most significant risk factors for squamous cell cancer of the esophagus. Additionally, the location of this patient’s esophageal mass in the upper 2/3 of the esophagus is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus. 
✅ Invasion of neoplastic squamous cells into the lamina propria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus:
Incorrect: Achalasia is a process due to loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus. While possible, it remains a diagnosis of exclusion and is less likely in an older patient with a mass and systemic findings concerning for underlying malignancy. 
❌ Eosinophilic predominance and basophilic hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic esophagitis occurs in all age groups and especially in patients with other atopic disorders such as asthma and eczema. Patients typically present with upper abdominal pain and food impaction.

A 56-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to progressive pelvic discomfort over the past few months. Medical history is noncontributory, and she is in good health. The patient does not have a family history of malignancy, history of sexually transmitted disease, urinary symptoms, or bleeding. Last menstrual cycle was 5 years ago, and the last Pap smear 6 months ago was normal. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits, other than a right adnexal mass upon palpation. Ultrasonography shows a solid right adnexal mass. The patient subsequently undergoes laparoscopy with excision of the mass. The specimen and histopathological analysis are shown below:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

This patient’s lesion most likely arose from which of the following structures of the ovary?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Brenner tumor, which is an uncommon, solid, ovarian tumor composed of nests of transitional-type epithelium (urothelium) that resemble that of the urinary tract. Brenner tumors are composed of circular patches of cells with coffee bean nuclei. These tumors can arise from the surface epithelium or from urogenital epithelial cells that have been trapped within the germinal ridge. Although mostly benign, both malignant and borderline tumors have been observed.


Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: This area is the oocyte (germ cell), which can give rise to germ cell tumors including dysgerminoma, teratoma, and yolk sac tumors. This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.
❌ C:
Incorrect: This area is the follicle, which is composed mainly of primitive sex cord cells and some stromal cells that support oocytes. The stromal cells include theca cells, fibroblasts, and Leydig cells, while the primitive sex cords include granulosa cells and Sertoli cells. Sex cord-stromal tumors may develop from the sex cords (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor, granulosa cell tumor), the stromal cells (e.g., thecoma, fibroma, Leydig cell tumor) or both (e.g., Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.
❌ D:
Incorrect: This area refers to the ovarian stroma. The stromal cells include theca cells, fibroblasts, and Leydig cells, while the primitive sex cords include granulosa cells and Sertoli cells. Sex cord-stromal tumors may develop from the sex cords (e.g., Sertoli cell tumor, granulosa cell tumor), the stromal cells (e.g., thecoma, fibroma, Leydig cell tumor) or both (e.g. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor). This patient’s presentation and histopathology results favor another diagnosis.

A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to intermittent sensations that her heart is racing. Over the past 2 months, the patient has experienced palpitations and lost 2.7 kg (6 lbs) without changes in her diet. The patient also notes she is sweating more than usual, which often makes her change her clothes to avoid embarrassment. Last menstrual cycle was 8 weeks ago, but it previously occurred every 28 days. The patient is sexually active with her partner, and they use condoms consistently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 110/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the thyroid gland is normal and nontender without nodules. The breasts appear normal. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized uterus. A right-sided adnexal mass is palpated. Laboratory studies reveal TSH levels of 0.1 μU/mL. She subsequently undergoes laparoscopic unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The results of the pathohistological analysis are shown below:


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The constellation of symptoms of hyperthyroidism, low TSH, and an adnexal mass is consistent with struma ovarii, a type of specialized teratoma. The histology results demonstrate thyroid tissue found within the ovary.  

Struma ovarii is a specialized teratoma that is composed of mature thyroid tissue primarily. It may secrete thyroid hormones and lead to hyperthyroidism, but not all patients are symptomatic. The majority of cases are benign and managed by excision of the ovary or by unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. However, malignant transformation can occur. Another type of specialized teratoma is ovarian carcinoid,  which rarely produces carcinoid syndrome.  

Option Analysis

✅ Teratoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Choriocarcinoma:
Incorrect: Non-gestational choriocarcinoma is a rare and highly malignant type of ovarian germ cell tumor. The placental origin is far more common than ovarian origin. Those of ovarian origin arise from the extraembryonic differentiation of malignant germ cells, which differentiate into trophoblastic structures. Essentially, all choriocarcinomas produce b-hCG, which may lead to precocity in girls and/or irregular vaginal bleeding. Due to homology between the beta-subunits of hCG and TSH, hCG has weak thyroid-stimulating activity and may lead to hyperthyroidism. However, this patient's histological results favor another diagnosis.

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism may occur in normal pregnancies due to homology between the beta-subunits of hCG and TSH. This occurs during peak concentrations at 10 to 12 weeks gestation. However, this patient consistently uses contraception and does not show any signs of pregnancy (e.g., breast swelling, uterine enlargement). Additionally, pregnancy does not explain the patient’s adnexal mass or the subsequent histopathological findings.
❌ Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor:
Incorrect: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors are a type of rare sex cord-stromal tumors that may be benign or malignant. They are capable of producing androgens resulting in virilization. They are not, however, associated with hyperthyroidism.
❌ Yolk sac tumor:
Incorrect: Yolk sac tumors are malignant ovarian germ cell tumors typically seen in young women. Patients commonly present with symptoms related to the presence of a pelvic mass. They do not produce hormonally active substances and are not associated with hyperthyroidism. AFP is the most commonly elevated tumor marker. Histologically, the tissue in these tumors resembles yolk sac tissue. The hallmark of yolk sac tumors is marked by the presence of papillary invaginations that surround a central vessel, known as Schiller-Duval bodies.

A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of bilateral flank pain and cola-colored urine. He had been healthy until 3 days ago, when he started having cold-like symptoms with a runny nose and throat pain. The patient denies any recent rashes or arthralgias. Temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema without exudates and mild bilateral flank tenderness. Complete blood count is normal. Serum chemistries and urinalysis are as follows:


Which of the following changes would most likely be present on this patient’s renal biopsy?

choices.text: “Spike and dome” appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy
Crescent-shaped deposition of fibrin and C3b compressing the glomerular tuft
Granular IgG and C3 deposits along glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence microscopy
IgA-based immune complex deposits in mesangium on immunofluorescence microscopy
Wire looping of capillaries on light microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with flank pain, mild proteinuria, and hematuria with red blood cell casts in the urine sediments is consistent with nephritic syndrome. In association with an ongoing viral upper respiratory tract infection, this presentation suggests IgA nephropathy (formerly known as Berger’s disease) as the most likely cause.  

IgA nephropathy is also called “synpharyngitic nephritis” hematuria and commonly occurs in young adults (age 20-30). The timing of the hematuria is important, as it helps differentiate it from poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a similarly presenting condition. The episodic hematuria in IgA nephropathy usually starts within a day or two of a nonspecific upper respiratory tract infection (hence synpharyngitic), as opposed to PSGN, in which the hematuria occurs some time (weeks) after initial infection (and is therefore termed postpharyngitic nephritis).  

The inciting event is the formation of abnormal IgA antibodies (in response to a recent infection) which the body recognizes as foreign and makes IgG antibodies against them. The immune complexes (IC) that are formed become trapped in the mesangium, thereby activating the complement system and resulting in the release of cytokines and inflammation. Renal dysfunction (e.g. increased creatinine) and hypertension are common but not always present in early disease (as in this patient). Moreover, normal serum complement levels are observed, which is likely due to weak complement-fixing activity of IgA as compared to IgG, which is seen in PSGN. Light microscopy reveals mesangial proliferation. Immunofluorescence and electron microscopies show IC deposits in the mesangium.



IgA nephropathy is differentiated from IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) in that the latter presents with colicky abdominal pain, bloody stools, arthritis and palpable purpura, and it is more commonly seen in children.

Option Analysis

❌ “Spike and dome” appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy:
Incorrect: “Spike and dome” appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy is characteristic of membranous nephropathy, one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndromes in adults. It usually presents with marked proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), edema and fatty casts on urinalysis, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Crescent-shaped deposition of fibrin and C3b compressing the glomerular tuft:
Incorrect: Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis is a result of damage to the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which leads to leakage of plasma proteins and fibrin deposition in the glomerulus, resulting in parietal cell proliferation (glomerular structural support cell) and crescent formation. This patient more likely has IgA nephropathy.
❌ Granular IgG and C3 deposits along glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescence microscopy:
Incorrect: In contrast to IgA nephropathy, which demonstrates IgA-based immune complex deposits in mesangium, the presence of granular IgG and C3 deposits along the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluorescent microscopy is characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children 2-4 weeks after streptococcal infection of the pharynx or skin. Complement (C3) levels are decreased.
✅ IgA-based immune complex deposits in mesangium on immunofluorescence microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wire looping of capillaries on light microscopy:
Incorrect: Wire looping of capillaries on light microscopy is seen in diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. The condition is usually associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and often presents with findings of both nephritic and nephrotic syndromes. Common findings in SLE include malar rash, joint pain and fatigue, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He reports an insidious onset of symptoms over the past several weeks with an associated 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and night sweats. His past medical history is notable for hypertension and high cholesterol but is otherwise unremarkable. He does not drink, smoke, or use illicit substances. He has worked as a manufacturer in an electronics factory for the past 40 years. He undergoes spirometry which demonstrates an increased FEV1/FVC ratio. This patient’s lung biopsy is most likely to demonstrate which of the following histologic features?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of working in electronics manufacturing presents with insidious shortness of breath, fatigue, and weight loss. His evaluation reveals an increased FEV1/FVC ratio on pulmonary function testing, consistent with a restrictive lung physiology. Together, these findings warrant consideration for the pneumoconiosis, berylliosis—a noncaseating granulomatous disorder.  

Berylliosis is a form of metal poisoning caused by inhalation of beryllium dusts, vapors, or its compounds. It is most commonly related to occupational exposure, especially in those who work or worked in the aerospace industry, electronic manufacturing, and car manufacturing.  

Over time, inhaled beryllium particles become lodged in the small airways, which trigger a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and noncaseating granuloma formation. In some patients, they become sensitized to beryllium particles and are completely asymptomatic. In other patients, noncaseating granuloma formation progresses to lung fibrosis, causing shortness of breath, weight loss, fatigue, night sweats, and cor pulmonale. It is important to note that progressive disease can occur years after last exposure, with some cases noted to have exposures greater than thirty years ago.  

Diagnosis of berylliosis rests on history, physiologic, radiographic, and histologic findings. Pulmonary function tests will typically demonstrate restrictive physiology, and radiographic findings often include nodular opacities in the mid and upper lung zones. Diagnosis can further be elucidated by the beryllium sensitivity test, where the patient's lymphocyte count is measured in response to exposure to beryllium sulfate. Cells are then counted, and those with elevated numbers of cells are considered abnormal. Treatment is usually supportive care and removal from the offending exposure; steroids can be considered on a case-by-case basis.  





Option Analysis

✅ Non-caseating granulomas :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ferruginous bodies :
Incorrect: Ferruginous bodies are commonly associated with asbestosis. Patients with exposure to asbestos typically have a history of working in shipbuilding, plumbing, roofing, or the textile industry.  
❌ Birefringent particles surrounded by fibrosis :
Incorrect: Silicosis refers to a fibrotic pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of fine particles of crystalline silicon dioxide. At risk populations include those who work in foundries, mining, or sandblasting.
❌ Macrophages laden with carbon:
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to coal dust results in coal miners’ pneumoconiosis. Prolonged coal dust exposure results in macrophages laden with carbon, with subsequent inflammation and fibrosis.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of a painless mass that emerged on her right forearm several months ago. She has not had any recent trauma to the area. Past medical history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the hands reveals bilateral swelling and reduced range of motion in the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Examination of the patient’s right forearm reveals the following finding:  


Reproduced from: CDC Public Health Image Library  

The nodule is firm and nontender to palpation. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Biopsy of the nodule is performed. Which of the following histological patterns will be most likely present?

choices.text: Fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes

questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune condition that triggers cytokine release by the immune system. The condition often affects the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and metatarsophalangeal joints. In addition, cytokines can travel to other parts of the body, causing extra-articular symptoms.  

In the skin and visceral organs, cytokines lead to the formation of rheumatoid nodules, which are bumps with a central area of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes (a type of macrophage). Palisading means the cells are arranged in parallel layers around the necrotic area. On examination, these nodules are seen as singular or multiple subcutaneous masses that are firm to the touch, non-painful, and distributed around the affected joint.  

Rheumatoid arthritis can also cause carpal tunnel syndrome, since the inflammation causes tendon swelling and nerve compression. Carpal tunnel syndrome can manifest as paresthesia, pain, and numbness in the hand.  

Lastly, cytokines can lead to inflammation of the uvea, which is the layer of tissue beneath the white of the eye or sclera, causing uveitis. Some signs of uveitis include eye pain, conjunctival redness, blurry vision, miosis, and accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber of the eye (hypopyon). If the sclera is involved, it can cause scleritis.  




Option Analysis

✅ Fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by palisading histiocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Proliferation of malignant epithelial cells:
Incorrect: This answer describes skin cancer, with the most common type being basal cell carcinoma (BCC). BCC presents as a waxy, pearly nodule with central crusting or ulceration. However, it would be atypical for BCC, or any other type of skin cancer, to manifest as a firm nodule.
❌ Deposition of calcium salts:
Incorrect: This answer describes calcinosis cutis, which is when calcium is deposited in the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is associated with scleroderma, which can also cause sclerodactyly, Raynaud phenomenon, and esophageal dysmotility. In contrast, this patient does not have any of these symptoms. 
❌ Palisading granulomas and eosinophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: This histological finding can be seen in the skin nodules of patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Patients with EGPA can also develop allergies, sinusitis, and peripheral neuropathy, none of which are present in this patient.
❌ Needle-shaped positively birefringent crystals:
Incorrect: This finding would be seen in the synovial fluid of patients with gout, which causes an inflammatory monoarthritis. The affected joint is generally warm and painful. In contrast, this patient’s nodule is not tender or erythematous.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office because of perianal discomfort and foul-smelling discharge around the anus for the past 2 months. She also reports intermittent abdominal pain and watery diarrhea for the last few years for which she did not seek medical attention. She has no other significant past medical history and has not traveled outside of the country recently. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination shows canker sores on the oral mucosa. There is mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant of abdomen and an anterolateral anal fistula draining foul-smelling purulent discharge. Stool microscopy shows 1-2 cell/hpf leukocytes. Colonoscopy shows skip lesions and cobblestone appearance of the descending colon with rectal sparing. Which of the following findings will be seen on light microscopy of the involved tissue sample?

choices.text: Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes
Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a perianal fistula (perianal discomfort, foul-smelling perianal discharge), a chronic history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain, and physical examination findings of aphthous ulcers (canker sores) and abdominal tenderness; she is most likely suffering from Crohn disease (CD).

CD is characterized by immune-mediated transmural inflammation that can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract from the mouth to anus, though it usually involves the terminal ileum and colon. Clinically, it presents with chronic watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. Systemic findings of inflammation (low-grade fever, weight loss, anemia, fatigue) can be seen. Suspected cases are evaluated by ileo-colonoscopy with biopsies. Microscopic features suggestive of CD include:

  •  Non-caseating granulomas (Figure A): Aggregates of epithelioid macrophages that may fuse to form multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a band of lymphocytes. 
  •  Crypt abscess (Figure B): Clusters of neutrophils and pus within crypt epithelium. 
  •  Transmural inflammation (Figure C): inflammation involving the entire thickness of intestinal wall. 
  •  Paneth cell metaplasia (arrows in Figure D): Occurs exclusively in affected mucosa and is a useful marker of IBD. 
  • Pseudopolyps (Figure E): When the ulceration destroys significant portions of the mucosa, the residual mucosa protrudes above the surface of the ulcers in the form of polyps. Since these are not true neoplastic polyps, they are called pseudopolyps.


Figure A (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)



Figure B (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)



Figure C (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure D (Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons)


Figure E (Reproduced from: flickr.com)

Complications other than perianal fistula formation include malabsorption (due to associated ileitis), as well as abscess or stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Non-caseating granulomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caseating granulomas:
Incorrect: Caseating granulomas are aggregates of epithelioid macrophages with central necrosis that are usually seen on histopathology of patients with intestinal tuberculosis. Although chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea are the presenting symptoms, a history of travel to an endemic area or exposure to infected individuals is usually present. Cobblestoning of mucosa is also atypical.
❌ Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes:
Incorrect: Infiltration of lamina propria with atypical lymphocytes is characteristic of lymphomas arising in mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT or MALTomas). They usually arise in the stomach and present with dyspepsia and epigastric discomfort. Long-standing watery diarrhea and perianal fistula are atypical.
❌ Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi:
Incorrect: Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes and atrophy of villi is characteristic of celiac disease, which usually presents with foul-smelling bulky diarrhea and flatulence. It is usually associated with dietary gluten intake. Endoscopy shows atrophic mucosa with loss of folds in the duodenum. Colon involvement is atypical.
❌ Distended macrophages in lamina propria:
Incorrect: Distended macrophages in the lamina propria are pathognomonic of Whipple disease. The condition is a multisystem progressive disease presenting with joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, and central nervous system involvement. Endoscopy usually shows a normal appearing mucosa. Perianal involvement is uncommon.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the office because of a red ulcerated lesion on the skin of his face. He noticed the lesion 6-months ago while shaving his beard and just recently noticed the ulceration. He worked on a farm for the past 20 years and retired this year. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/86 mmHg. Physical examination shows a red ulcerating lesion below his left jawline. An image of the ulcer is shown below:



Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathological findings is most likely to be found on biopsy of this lesion?
questions.solution:
