This patient’s presentation with a waxy, pink ulcerated lesion on the skin of his face, in combination with a history of excessive sunlight exposure (as a farmer), is consistent with the diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma (BCC).

BCC is the most common skin cancer, and it arises from the stratum basale and its appendages. It is a slow-growing locally invasive tumor that only rarely metastasizes to distant parts of the body, but it may continue to grow and invade nearby tissues and structures, including the nerves, bones, and brain. It is most common among fair-skinned individuals, and major associated risk factors include exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation (e.g. sunlight), use of tanning beds, chronic arsenic exposure, and immunosuppression. The head and face are the most common locations of BCC, where it usually presents as a waxy, pink pearly nodule with rolled borders and central ulceration, a persistent open bleeding sore, a reddish patch, or a pale scar-like area.

Definitive diagnosis is established on biopsy that shows invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisading basal cells. Treatment depends on the size, location and depth of the lesion. Electro-dessication and curettage, 5-fluorouracil, and Mohs microsurgery are available options.



Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: The pathological findings of partial thickness epidermal dysplasia and keratinocytes with nuclear atypia (hyperchromatic and pleomorphic nuclei) are characteristic of actinic keratosis. It presents as small (<1 cm) erythematous macules or papules with or without scaling on sun-exposed areas. Ulceration of the lesion is atypical and is suggestive of a malignancy.
❌ :
Incorrect: These findings of keratinocytic dysplasia involving the full thickness of the epidermis without infiltration of atypical cells into the dermis are characteristic of Bowen disease. It is a cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma in situ that clinically appears as small, well-circumscribed, red elevations of the skin with scaly plaques on top. An ulcerated lesion with rolled borders, as seen in this patient, would be atypical.
❌ :
Incorrect: The image findings of nests of melanin-producing atypical melanocytes with large hyperchromatic nuclei, nuclear polymorphism and a distorted architecture with dermal solar elastosis are typical of melanoma. It clinically presents as a hyperpigmented lesion with irregular borders and a diameter >6 mm. A waxy, pink lesion with central ulceration, as seen in this patient, would be unlikely.
✅ Retrieved fromWikimedia Commons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: Dysplastic keratinocytes involving the full thickness of the epidermis that penetrates the epidermal basement membrane to involve the dermis or deeper tissues is characteristic of invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). It is much less common than BCC and often arises from a precursor lesion (e.g. actinic keratoses), and typically has overlying hyperkeratosis. An ulcerated lesion with rolled borders, as seen in this patient, is suggestive of a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating the histological features of the gastrointestinal tract. In one section of the ileum, he finds a group of specialized cells in nodules in the submucosal layer, as shown in the image below (red circle). Which of the following is the function of this structure?  

Source: Wikimedia commons

choices.text: They help in identifying antigens and producing antibodies.
They assist in the digestion of fat.
They assist in the breakdown of proteins.

questions.solution:
Peyer’s patches are a group of well-organized lymphoid follicles found mainly in the ileum but also in the duodenum and jejunum. Histologically, they are found in the lamina propria and the submucosa.

These patches are specialized immune structures that mainly contain B-cells. However, it also includes T-cells, macrophages, and dendritic cells. In addition, a particular type of cell called microfold cells (M cells) is found in these patches, which function as antigen-presenting cells. Once M cells encounter a pathogen, they activate dendritic cells and macrophages, which, in turn, activate lymphocytes leading to the amplification of immune response and production of IgA antibodies (by B-lymphocytes). These antibodies finally travel to the gut lumen to fight the intraluminal pathogens.
 
 

Option Analysis

✅ They help in identifying antigens and producing antibodies.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ They secrete an alkaline solution.:
Incorrect: Peyer’s patches are specialized immune structures containing lymphoid cell follicles. Brunner’s glands are secretory glands that produce alkaline mucus. They do not secrete alkaline solutions.  
❌ They assist in peristalsis.  :
Incorrect: Peristalsis is mediated by the muscularis layer. Peyer’s patches are not involved in the peristalsis.  
❌ They assist in the digestion of fat.  :
Incorrect: Digestion of fat involves pancreatic enzymes and bile. However, Peyer's patches are not involved in the digestion process.  
❌ They assist in the breakdown of proteins.  :
Incorrect: Protein digestion involves gastric acid and enzymes and pancreatic enzymes. Peyer’s patches are not involved in the digestion process.

questions.text: A study is conducted on the respiratory system to determine the different cell types found in each portion of the respiratory system. A histological examination of the tracheal tissue was performed, and the image under microscope is shown below. Which of the following is true about the cells that are marked by the arrow?

choices.text: They are found in the trachea and bronchi only.
The concentration of these cells is higher in the bronchi than in the trachea
They function as regenerative cells for the epithelial cells
They extend from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles
They do not extend beyond the trachea

questions.solution:
The cells that are marked by the arrow are goblet cells that are only found in the trachea and bronchi in the respiratory tract. The trachea and bronchi are part of the conducting system of the respiratory tract, where they participate in conducting and modifying the inspired air (e.g. humidification) but do not participate in gas exchange.  

Both the trachea and bronchi have similar unique features that help distinguish them from other parts of the respiratory system. First of all, both have a cartilaginous component that does not extend beyond the bronchi. The cartilaginous component of the trachea is arranged into a C-shaped cartilaginous cap, and helps in supporting the trachea when different pressures are found in the lumen during inspiration and expiration.  

The cartilaginous component in the bronchi is less organized and is found surrounding the lumen with occasional gaps. The other histological feature that is unique to the trachea and bronchi is the presence of the goblet cells. These cells are found between the epithelial cells, and function to secrete mucus. They do not extend beyond the bronchi. Additionally, the concentration of goblet cells is the highest in the upper trachea and decreases as we move towards the lower trachea and further decreases in the bronchi.    


Option Analysis

✅ They are found in the trachea and bronchi only.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The concentration of these cells is higher in the bronchi than in the trachea  :
Incorrect: The goblet cells are less abundant in the bronchi than in the trachea. Also, they are less abundant in the lower trachea than in the upper trachea.
❌ They function as regenerative cells for the epithelial cells  :
Incorrect: The primary function of goblet cells is mucus secretion; they do not have stem cell properties.  
❌ They extend from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are only found in the trachea and bronchi, and do not extend beyond the bronchi.  
❌ They do not extend beyond the trachea  :
Incorrect: Goblet cells are found in the trachea and bronchi.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-day history of blurry vision in the left eye and pain with eye movement. She had an episode of urinary incontinence several months ago that resolved spontaneously. The patient does not use tobacco or illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild sensory loss in both legs below the knees. The left foot shows an extensor plantar reflex. Which of the following pathologic brain lesions is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Focal areas of demyelination with macrophages containing myelin debris
Extracellular senile plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles
Necrosis of rapidly proliferating, anaplastic glial cells
Accumulation of nuclear viral inclusions within enlarged oligodendrocytes
Axonal demyelination in pontine white matter

questions.solution:
This young woman is presenting with classic signs and symptoms (e.g., urinary incontinence, optic neuritis, paresthesias) of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is a chronic, degenerative disease of the central nervous system that results from an autoimmune-mediated attack against oligodendrocytes. The exact etiology of MS is unclear; however, there is a genetic predisposition to the condition (HLA-DR2), as well as identifiable triggers, such as vitamin D deficiency and cigarette smoking. Vitamin D deficiency can explain why the rate of MS is higher among people who live further from the equator, where there is less sunlight.  

The lesions in MS are caused by a type IV hypersensitivity (cell-mediated reaction) in which Th1 and Th17 T-cells react against myelin antigens and secrete cytokines, which dilate the blood vessels, allowing more immune cells to extravasate from the bloodstream, as well as directly cause damage to oligodendrocytes. The cytokines attract B-cells, which begin to make antibodies that target the myelin. Macrophages are able to identify these antibodies and attack the marked oligodendrocytes. Without oligodendrocytes, there is no myelin to cover the neurons, leaving behind areas of scar tissue, also called plaques.   





Option Analysis

✅ Focal areas of demyelination with macrophages containing myelin debris:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Extracellular senile plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles:
Incorrect: Neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are typically seen in patients with Alzheimer disease. The condition presents in elderly individuals with an insidious onset and is characterized by slow, progressive short term memory loss. In later stages, there are also behavioral and personality changes. 
❌ Necrosis of rapidly proliferating, anaplastic glial cells :
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a highly malignant primary brain tumor. Due to its rapid growth, there is often a central area of necrosis and hemorrhage. Patients may present with epileptic seizures, as well as signs of an elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, vomiting, papilledema). The episodic nature of this patient’s disease makes GBM an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Accumulation of nuclear viral inclusions within enlarged oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is caused by JC virus, a polyomavirus, which infects oligodendrocytes resulting in demyelination and neuronal death. PML typically occurs in patients who are immunosuppressed (e.g. HIV patients) and typically presents as progressive encephalopathy. In contrast, this patient is not immunosuppressed and has episodic symptoms, making PML unlikely. 
❌ Axonal demyelination in pontine white matter:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome, also known as central pontine myelinolysis, occurs secondary to rapid osmotic changes, most commonly in the setting of correction of hyponatremia. Patients typically present with acute paralysis, dysphagia, and loss of consciousness. In contrast, this patient is presenting with a more episodic disease course, making osmotic demyelination syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to worsening dyspnea and wheezing. The patient has had a chronic productive cough for the past several years, which has worsened in the past 2 weeks. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 102/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals accessory muscle use during respiration. The patient frequently coughs and produces significant quantities of yellowish sputum. Diffuse wheezes are heard bilaterally on chest auscultation. The patient is started on antibiotics and supplemental oxygen. Despite appropriate treatment, he passes away several days later in the intensive care unit, and an autopsy is performed. Which of the following will most likely be seen on histopathological evaluation of this patient’s lungs?

choices.text: Increased thickness of submucosal mucinous glands
Numerous crystalloids made of eosinophil proteins
Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells
Nodules with concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers

questions.solution:
This patient has dyspnea, productive cough, and wheezing in the setting of a long smoking history, which raises concern for underlying chronic bronchitis. The fever, tachycardia, and reduced oxygen saturation are suspicious for a superimposed pneumonia. Autopsy of this patient’s lungs will reveal bronchial mucinous gland hyperplasia and hypertrophy.  

Chronic bronchitis (CB) describes inflammation of the tracheobronchial tree that leads to increased mucus production. The most important cause is cigarette smoking, which irritates the airway mucosa, leading to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of mucinous glands in the main bronchi and goblet cells in the bronchioles. Symptoms include productive cough due to excess mucous secretion and wheezing due to airway narrowing.  

The diagnosis of CB is made on clinical grounds; it is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. In post-mortem scenarios, the diagnosis can be made via the Reid index, which measures the ratio of the thickness of the bronchial mucinous gland layer relative to the total thickness of the wall between the epithelium and the glands. Normally, the ratio is less than 0.3, but for patients with CB it can exceed 0.4.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Increased thickness of submucosal mucinous glands:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diffuse panlobular emphysema :
Incorrect: Diffuse panacinar (panlobular) emphysema is classically seen in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, in which alveolar proteases are uninhibited, resulting in destruction of the alveolar parenchyma. In contrast, this patient has chronic bronchitis, which makes another histopathological finding more likely. 
❌ Numerous crystalloids made of eosinophil proteins:
Incorrect: Charcot-Leyden crystals are crystalloids formed from the breakdown of eosinophils. These crystals are seen in patients with asthma. In contrast, this patient has chronic bronchitis, which makes another histopathological finding more likely. 
❌ Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells:
Incorrect: Noncaseating granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis. This patient, who suffers from chronic bronchitis, would have a different finding on histopathological examination of the bronchial wall. 
❌ Nodules with concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers:
Incorrect: Silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors (e.g. history of working in mining or glass manufacturing) that would predispose him to developing silicosis.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of shortness of breath over the past few months. She has had no fever or weight loss over this time period. The patient drinks 2-3 glasses of wine on the weekends and does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. She states her father died of liver disease at the age of 55. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a prolonged expiratory phase and scattered wheezes bilaterally. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the costal margin. There is no palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites noted. Laboratory results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Leukocytes   7,000/mm3 
 Creatinine   0.7 mg/dL 
 Total bilirubin   1.0 mg/dL 
 Glucose  92 mg/dL 
 AST  78 U/L 
 ALT  81 U/L 
Which of the following changes will most likely be observed on histopathological examination of this patient’s proximal and distal acini?
questions.solution:
This patient has shortness of breath despite no prior smoking history, hepatomegaly, and elevated liver enzymes. She likely has alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency, which is characterized by impaired hepatic secretion of AAT. The condition results in emphysema, due to increased elastase activity and subsequent breakdown of lung tissue, as well as liver injury.  

Emphysema describes permanent alveoli enlargement and loss of alveolar wall elasticity. It is most commonly caused by an irritant, such as tobacco smoke, which triggers inflammation in the alveoli. Inflammatory cells (e.g. neutrophils) gather in the lungs and release destructive proteases, which degrade connective tissue in the alveolar walls. The alveoli become progressively weaker, lose their ability to stretch and recoil, and eventually collapse, resulting in air trapping.  

Emphysema can be further classified based on which alveoli clusters (termed acini) are damaged. The three types of emphysema are:  

 1) Centriacinar emphysema is the most common type and involves damages to the central alveoli of the acinus. This is the pattern seen with cigarette smoking and typically affects the upper lobes of the lungs.  
2) Panacinar emphysema affects the entire acinus and usually occurs in the lower lobes. This pattern is associated with AAT deficiency.  
3) Paraseptal emphysema is characterized by enlargement of the distal alveoli of the acinus. This type typically affects lung tissue on the periphery of the lobules, near the interlobular septa.



Option Analysis

❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Enlargement  Normal :
Incorrect: Enlargement of the proximal acini with distal sparing is seen in centriacinar (centrilobular) emphysema. This type of emphysema is classically seen in patients who smoke cigarettes. In contrast, this patient has no history of tobacco use, making centriacinar emphysema unlikely. 
✅   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Enlargement  Enlargement :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Normal Enlargement :
Incorrect: Enlargement of distal acini with proximal sparing is seen in distal acinar (paraseptal) emphysema. The condition can be a cause for spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. However, this patient has shortness of breath, elevated liver enzymes, and no smoking history, which raises concerns for alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. AAT deficiency typically presents with panacinar emphysema.
❌   Proximal acini  Distal acini  Normal Normal :
Incorrect: This patient likely has alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) deficiency. Normal acini are not seen in patients with this condition, as the absence of AAT leads to increased elastase activity and increased breakdown of the lung parenchyma.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient was the unrestrained driver and suffered chest and abdomen contusions. She is hemodynamically stable and complains of mild abdominal pain. Medical history is unremarkable. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Serum β-hCG is negative. The chest radiograph is normal, and abdominal radiograph is normal other than an incidental finding indicated by the arrow in the picture below:

Retrieved from: Radiopaedia

The patient subsequently undergoes diagnostic laparoscopy, which shows the following histopathological finding:

Reproduced from: flickr

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy patient is presenting with an incidental calcified mass on abdominal imaging; the subsequent histological results confirm the diagnosis of a mature ovarian teratoma.  

Teratomas, a type of germ cell tumor, constitute up to 20% of ovarian tumors. They typically occur in the first 2 decades of life. The majority of teratomas are benign cystic teratomas while the immature, malignant subtype is rare. In general, the younger the patient, the greater the likelihood of the lesion being malignant.  

Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are also known as dermoid cysts, a name derived from the presence of cysts within the tumor that are lined by epidermis. These tumors are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, as well as other tissues. Most teratomas are discovered incidentally on abdominal x-rays or scans due to the presence of tooth-like structures within the tumor that produces foci of calcification. These neoplasms (especially the larger variants) are prone to cause ovarian torsion, since they increase the likelihood for the ovary to rotate on the axis of the infundibulopelvic and utero-ovarian ligaments and become fixed in a torsed position. A rare paraneoplastic complication is hyperthyroidism, which develops in teratomas containing thyroid tissue, a condition known as struma ovarii. Rarely, mature teratomas may transform into squamous cell carcinoma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Mucinous cystadenoma :
Incorrect: Mucinous cystadenoma is a common type of benign ovarian tumor. Similar to serous cystadenoma, it is usually thin-walled, uni- or multilocular, ranging from 5-20 cm in size. Compared with serous cystadenomas, mucinous cystadenomas are less common, more likely to be multiloculated, are larger and are less likely to occur bilaterally. On histology, the cysts are lined by columnar epithelial cells with abundant intracellular mucin. This patient’s histological results favor the diagnosis of a mature ovarian teratoma.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Endometrioma :
Incorrect: An endometrioma or "chocolate cyst" is a benign tumor that arises from the ectopic growth of endometrial tissue. Patients with endometriosis often complain of dyschezia, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. On ultrasound, it appears as a complex mass containing homogeneous internal echoes often described as "ground glass.” Occasionally, it can lead to calcifications that can be visualized on x-ray. This patient had none of the symptoms of endometriosis, and the histopathology favors another diagnosis.

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Mature teratoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Theca lutein cyst:
Incorrect: Theca lutein cysts are a type of follicular cyst that arise due to high levels of β-hCG or sensitivity to β-hCG. It is associated with a gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestations, and ovarian hyperstimulation. Patients are usually asymptomatic but may present with virilization, hyperemesis gravidarum, preeclampsia, or thyroid dysfunction. This patient has none of these symptoms and had a negative serum β-hCG, eliminating this diagnosis.
❌ Ovarian carcinoma:
Incorrect: The vast majority of ovarian malignancies are derived from the surface epithelial cells of the ovary. Patients with ovarian cancer may be asymptomatic or present with bloating, urinary symptoms, early satiety, pelvic or abdominal pain, bowel obstruction, pleural effusion, and venous thromboembolism. Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common ovarian cancer. Macroscopically it appears as solid, hemorrhagic, and necrotic mass. Microscopically, it may be high or low grade, and psammoma bodies (concentric calcifications) are usually seen. A malignant ovarian epithelial tumor is most commonly seen in women older than 40 years of age.


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department with inability to urinate for the past 2 days. He also has noticed blood in his urine for the past week. The patient has had no pain with urination or myalgias. Review of the medical charts reveals multiple clinic visits for recurrent rhinosinusitis. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows 2+ peripheral pitting edema. There is no flank tenderness or tenderness on palpation of the lower abdomen.  Laboratory results are as follows:  


Serum creatinine is 4.0 mg/dL. Kidney biopsy is performed, and a light microscopy image is shown below:


The area marked is mainly composed of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient has signs and symptoms of nephritic syndrome (hematuria, anuria, red blood cell casts, edema). Renal biopsy specimen in light microscopy is showing a glomerular crescent, which is diagnostic for rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN).  

Glomerular crescent is defined as >2 layers of proliferating cells within the Bowman capsule. The proliferation is a result of disruptions in the glomerular basement membrane that allows influx of coagulation factors (e.g. fibrinogen) and inflammatory cells (e.g. macrophages) into the Bowman capsule. Fibroblasts are recruited in response to chemotactic factors released by inflammatory cells, and the coagulation cascade is initiated, resulting in rapidly progressive glomerular hypercellularity, cross-linking of fibrin, and irreversible renal injury.

Several disease processes may result in RPGN, and they may be differentiated on characteristic patterns under immunofluorescence microscopy.



Like other nephritic syndromes, RPGN causes hematuria, hypertension, and progressive renal failure; however, its prognosis is generally poor due to rapid decompensation and progression to end-stage renal disease (within weeks to months).

Option Analysis

❌ Insoluble polymers of proteins:
Incorrect: Deposition of insoluble polymers of proteins (e.g. amyloid) is seen in amyloidosis. Renal involvement usually presents with asymptomatic proteinuria or clinically apparent nephrotic syndrome; significant hematuria is not seen. Biopsy findings include mesangial deposits of amyloid that can be observed in Congo red staining as apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
✅ Fibrin and C3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Albumin:
Incorrect: Disruption of the glomeruli in crescentic glomerulonephritis causes increased filtration of plasma proteins such as albumin. These proteins are lost in the urine and do not deposit in glomeruli. Low levels of plasma proteins lead to low plasma oncotic pressure, resulting in edema.
❌ Hyaline:
Incorrect: Hyaline, or acellular deposits of plasma proteins, is usually seen in Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules of diabetic nephropathy, which presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria. This patient is not diabetic, and the findings are consistent with nephritic, not nephrotic, syndrome.
❌ Myoglobin:
Incorrect: Myoglobin in the urine is observed in rhabdomyolysis, a condition in which urine dipstick is positive for blood but erythrocytes are absent (unlike this patient). Myoglobin is toxic to renal tubular cells and causes acute tubular necrosis, not glomerular injury and crescent formation.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of abdominal pain and itching. The symptoms began several months ago but have progressively worsened. Past medical history is significant for celiac disease, which is well managed with a gluten-free diet. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly. There is no scleral icterus or jaundice. Laboratory results are as follows:



A liver biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathological changes would most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Hepatocytes with swollen endoplasmic reticulum due to increased viral proteins
Destruction of of intrahepatic biliary ducts and periductal fibrosis
Central vein with surrounding congestion and necrosis

questions.solution:
Autoimmune hepatitis (AH) is a form of chronic hepatitis that predominantly affects females (78%), and more specifically young and middle-aged females. The exact origin of the condition is unclear; however, it is commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., celiac disease, ulcerative colitis, systemic lupus erythematosus). Triggers for the immune reaction may include viral infections, toxin exposure, and drugs.  

The clinical presentation of AH can vary from an acute clinical illness to fulminant liver failure resulting in hepatic encephalopathy. Symptoms may include weight loss, fatigue, fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain.  

A characteristic finding in most patients with AH is the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies and anti-smooth muscle antibodies. As antibodies attack the liver, inflammation results in elevated liver enzymes and hepatomegaly. Biopsy findings in patients with AH include necrosis, inflammation, and plasma cell infiltration. Since AH is autoimmune in origin, therapy consists of immunosuppression, such as with high-dose steroids.



Option Analysis

✅ Portal plasma cell infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocytes with swollen endoplasmic reticulum due to increased viral proteins:
Incorrect: Chronic hepatitis B can result in “ground glass” hepatocytes, which occur due to accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen within the endoplasmic reticulum. However, this patient has positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies, which makes another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Destruction of of intrahepatic biliary ducts and periductal fibrosis:
Incorrect: Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune liver disease characterized by the destruction of interlobular bile ducts. Although initial stages may present similarly to autoimmune hepatitis, the patient’s normal alkaline phosphatase makes this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Widespread lipid accumulation in hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is typically seen in patients with obesity and/or have type II diabetes. Insulin resistance and obesity results in increased free fatty acid mobilization from adipose tissue and subsequent liver uptake. This patient has a normal BMI and blood glucose level, hence making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Central vein with surrounding congestion and necrosis:
Incorrect: This finding is seen in congestive hepatopathy, wherein outflow of blood from the hepatic veins is hindered due to increased right atrial and vena caval pressures. This is commonly seen in patients with right-sided heart failure, which typically presents with jugular venous distension and lower extremity edema; these symptoms are absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of dark urine and a skin rash for the past day. He does not have a cough, shortness of breath, vomiting, dysuria, or urinary frequency. He was recently started on a medication for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) refractory to famotidine. His medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Current temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a diffuse, maculopapular skin rash. Mucous membranes are moist with no lesions or pharyngeal exudates. There is mild costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory results are shown.

 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Blood urea nitrogen  36 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis 
 Proteinuria  Absent 
 Erythrocytes  3-4/hpf 
 Leukocytes  10-12/hpf 
 Eosinophils  5-6/hpf 
 Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)  3% 
 Urine osmolality  340 mOsm/kg 
 Dysmorphic red blood cells  Absent 
 Casts  White blood cell casts 
   
Renal biopsy is most likely to demonstrate which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of fever, maculopapular rash and rising creatinine shortly after starting a medication for GERD (most likely a proton pump inhibitor) is highly suggestive of drug-induced acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). Other medications associated with this condition include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), penicillins, diuretics, and sulfonamides.  

AIN is thought to result from a type I (IgE-mediated) and type IV (cell-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction. As the name suggests, AIN primarily involves the renal interstitium, leading to interstitial edema and leukocyte infiltration--particularly with macrophages and eosinophils. AIN is also associated with autoimmune diseases, including sarcoidosis and lupus, and systemic infections.  

Clinical manifestations of AIN include fever, rash, hematuria, oliguria, and costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates increased creatinine, eosinophilia, pyuria, eosinophiluria, and white blood cell casts. Diagnosis is made on laboratory findings, with renal biopsy reserved for atypical or unclear cases. Treatment involves discontinuing the offending agent.

Option Analysis

✅ Inflammatory interstitial infiltrate and edema:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Focal tubular necrosis:
Incorrect: Histological findings of focal tubular epithelial necrosis occurs secondary to ischemic or nephrotoxic insults. Proton pump inhibitors are not associated with this condition. Moreover, granular, not white blood cell, casts are seen with this condition. 
❌ Immune complex deposition in glomeruli:
Incorrect: Immune complex deposition in glomeruli occurs in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, as well as several other nephritic syndromes. These conditions are usually associated with proteinuria, dysmorphic red blood cells, and red blood cell casts. 
❌ Preservation of normal architecture:
Incorrect: Normal renal architecture is preserved in prerenal azotemia, which is characterized by FENa of <1%. Patients present with a history of volume depletion and clinical signs of hypovolemia. 
❌ Granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages:
Incorrect: Renal biopsy findings of granulomatous tissue containing foamy macrophages are characteristic of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis, a rare type of infection associated with Proteus sp. Maculopapular rash and eosinophiluria are atypical.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man with a history of hypertension and COPD presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of chest tightness and extremity swelling. The patient reports chest tightness on his daily walk, and he noticed his legs look “puffy.” Physical exam is notable for a loud P2 heart sound, jugular venous distention, and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Laboratory examination reveals normal troponin and B-natriuretic peptide levels. An ECG is demonstrated below. The patient undergoes right heart catheterization, which shows a mean pulmonary arterial  pressure of 34 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most likely observation seen on histologic examination of this patient’s lungs?



Reproduced from: wikipedia

choices.text: Areas of patchy fibrosis with complete occlusion of small airways
Mucosal necrosis and sloughing of tissue into airway lumen

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of COPD presents for evaluation of chest pain and extremity swelling has several clinical findings that indicate he is suffering from symptomatic pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. The ECG with evidence of right axis deviation suggests right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH), which occurs when the right heart is forced to pump harder against a hypertensive circuit. In addition, right heart catheterization reveals the patient’s mean pulmonary arterial pressure is 34 mm Hg--which is well above a normal pulmonary artery pressure.

There are several causes of pulmonary hypertension, but the underlying pathological changes are similar. Common etiologies include left sided heart failure, as blood backs up in the pulmonary veins and capillary beds, causing increased pressures in the pulmonary arteries. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) results in reflexive pulmonary arteriole constriction and shunting of blood from diseased areas of the lung. Over time, widespread areas of the lung undergo this process, leading to an increase in pulmonary vascular resistance.

Pathological examination of lung tissue in patients with long-term pulmonary hypertension often demonstrates smooth muscle hypertrophy  of arterioles--which reflects chronic damage to endothelial cells. Important complications of pulmonary hypertension include right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale) and pulmonary edema.



Option Analysis

✅ Hypertrophy of arteriolar smooth muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Multilobular consolidations:
Incorrect: Multilobular consolidations are consistent with an underlying infectious or neoplastic process, which are unlikely given the information provided in the stem.
❌ Areas of patchy fibrosis with complete occlusion of small airways:
Incorrect: This answer describes bronchiolitis obliterans, which does not characterize this patient’s symptomatology.
❌ Mucosal necrosis and sloughing of tissue into airway lumen:
Incorrect: This answer describes bronchial necrosis, which does not characterize this patient’s symptomatology.
❌ Loculated pleural effusions:
Incorrect: Loculated pleural effusions are found in profoundly septic patients; this patient is without other infectious findings on exam or per history.

questions.text:
A 5-year old boy is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive by his grandmother. For the past week, the patient has had a fever and cough, and his grandmother has been providing him with over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications for symptom control. Today, the boy vomited three times, and an hour later, he became unresponsive. On physical examination, the child withdraws to pain only. Abdominal examination demonstrates hepatomegaly. During the evaluation, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which terminates with administration of lorazepam. Laboratory evaluation demonstrates the following findings as documented below. Liver biopsy is most likely to demonstrate which of the following histopathologic findings?

Laboratory value  Result 
Sodium   142 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.5 mg/dL 
 Alanine transaminase  411 U/L 
 Aspartate transaminase  357 U/L 
 Bilirubin (total)  2.5 mg/dL 
 Serum ammonia  177 µ/dL

choices.text: Sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema

questions.solution:
Reye syndrome is a rare but fatal disorder and occurs in children less than 16 who are treated with over the counter aspirin for viral infections like influenza A, influenza B, and varicella.

Although the pathophysiology of Reye syndrome is not fully understood, it is thought that aspirin induces hepatic mitochondrial injury in the setting of a viral infection, which results in the cells’ inability to break down fatty acids. Ultimately, this defect results in the characteristic finding of microvesicular steatosis without necrosis as seen in the image below.


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Mitochondrial injury also results in hepatocytes inability to clear ammonia, resulting in hyperammonemia, cerebral edema, and related sequelae (e.g., seizures, severe intractable vomiting, and altered mental status). A high-index of suspicion for this condition should be adopted for any child presenting with severe vomiting and altered mental status in the setting of a viral infection.

On laboratory evaluation, the most significant finding is elevated serum ammonia, in addition to elevated liver enzymes, abnormal coagulation parameters (e.g. elevated PT), and signs of hypovolemia (e.g. AKI). Cerebral edema is typically apparent in imaging studies.

Option Analysis

✅ Microvesicular fatty infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatocytes with “ground-glass” cytoplasm:
Incorrect: In chronic hepatitis B infection, the hepatitis B surface Antigen (HBsAg) accumulates in hepatocytes, giving a “ground glass” appearance to the cytoplasm.
❌ Sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema:
Incorrect: Marked sinusoidal dilation with congestion and edema is seen in patients with Budd-Chiari syndrome. This condition occurs secondary to hepatic venous flow obstruction and thrombus formation.
❌ Panlobular hepatic necrosis:
Incorrect: Panlobular hepatic necrosis is seen in patients with fulminant liver failure, which is most commonly due to acute viral hepatitis, though it can also be induced by toxins or drugs. However, in Reye syndrome, the liver biopsy demonstrates microvesicular steatosis without significant necrosis.
❌ Hepatocytes with eosinophilic intracytoplasmic globules:
Incorrect: Intracytoplasmic eosinophilic globules are seen in patients with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the clinic for a routine visit. He does not have any active complaints but does report approximately 9.1-kg (20-lbs) of unintentional weight gain over the last few months. Review of systems is significant for loss of libido which he attributes to increasing “tiredness” for the past 2 years. Past medical history is significant for non-specific arthritis, for which he takes ibuprofen as needed. He spent a week in India 3 months ago for a business trip. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 12/min and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. On physical examination, the liver is palpated 3 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory studies show the following:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   132 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Glucose  211 mg/dL 
 Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)   13.2 uU/mL 
 AST  94 U/L 
 ALT  115 U/L 


A biopsy specimen of this patient’s pituitary gland would likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Cholesterol crystals found in a motor oil-like fluid on gross examination

questions.solution:
Reproduced from: " href="%3Cimg%20data-hash=">">Wikimedia Commons

This middle-aged male patient is presenting with classic signs of hemochromatosis (e.g., hepatomegaly, arthritis, diabetes, and signs of hypopituitarism).

Hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by unregulated iron reabsorption leading to iron accumulation throughout the body. It can manifest in numerous ways, the most common being the hepatic damage seen in this patient, indicated by hepatomegaly and elevated liver enzymes. Overtime, iron deposition in the pancreas and skin leads to type II diabetes mellitus and hyperpigmentation, respectively. Occasionally, the excess iron can accumulate in the pituitary gland, resulting in various manifestations of hypopituitarism.

This patient’s symptoms of tiredness and weight gain, in conjunction with the abnormally elevated thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) found on laboratory evaluation, indicates hypothyroidism. Additionally, the decrease in libido can be a result of the iron deposition in gonadotrophs within the anterior pituitary gland. While a biopsy is rarely indicated for diagnosis of hemochromatosis, it would show iron deposition that can be seen on Prussian blue staining.



Option Analysis

✅ Diffuse Prussian blue staining:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acid-fast bacilli:
Incorrect: Positive acid-fast staining would be seen in cases of M. tuberculosis infiltration of the pituitary gland. Although a very rare cause of hypopituitarism, tuberculosis can potentially travel hematogenously to the pituitary and hypothalamus and result in endocrine dysfunction. Although this patient traveled to an endemic region (India), he has had none of the clinical findings (e.g., cough, night sweats or weight loss) typically seen in tuberculosis.
❌ Cholesterol crystals found in a motor oil-like fluid on gross examination:
Incorrect: This finding is indicative of craniopharyngioma, a benign pituitary tumor that arises from a remnant of the Rathke pouch. While this condition could result in loss of pituitary function, it would not adequately explain the other findings seen in this patient (e.g., hepatomegaly, arthritis).
❌ Diffuse hemorrhage and ischemia:
Incorrect: Infarction and hemorrhage of the pituitary epithelial cells would be seen in cases of pituitary apoplexy, which is sometimes observed in patients with a pre-existing pituitary adenoma. In such cases, the pituitary enlarges and requires greater blood supply, ultimately leading to ischemia and hemorrhage. This condition would present suddenly, rather than the gradual onset of symptoms seen in this patient.
❌ Proliferation of lactotroph cells:
Incorrect: Proliferation of lactrophic cells would be seen in patients with prolactinoma. Though it can present similarly with loss of libido and other signs of hypopituitarism secondary to compression and loss of function of other pituitary cells, this patient has additional findings which cannot be explained by a prolactinoma alone (e.g., hepatomegaly, arthritis).

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to her physician due to a painless lump on the right side of her face. She noticed the mass growing over the past several months, and one week ago noticed a right-sided facial droop. She has no significant past medical history and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a right-sided, non-tender, mobile, preauricular mass extending  to the angle of the mandible. A right-sided facial droop is present on examination. A biopsy of the mass is performed, and pathological examination shows proliferation of ductal myoepithelial and epithelial cells with a marked increase in stromal components. Staining with S100 is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenomas are benign tumors consisting of ductal epithelial and myoepithelial cells. The presence of both epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation defines this tumor as “pleomorphic.” Pleomorphic adenomas predominantly affect the parotid gland, although other salivary glands (e.g. submandibular) can be implicated.  

Pleomorphic adenomas typically present as slow-growing, mobile, painless masses. Symptoms and signs depend on the size, location, and potential to undergo malignant transformation. In the parotid gland, symptoms of facial nerve weakness can occur when the tumor is large or undergoes malignant change invading adjacent structures.  

The diagnosis of pleomorphic adenomas depends on biopsy and subsequent pathological examination. It is characterized by mixed proliferation of epithelial and myoepithelial cells in a variable stroma matrix of myxoid or cartilaginous origin.

Option Analysis

✅ Pleomorphic adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Warthin tumor:
Incorrect: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum (Warthin tumors) are benign cystic tumors with germinal centers, typically found in patients with a significant smoking history. This patient’s biopsy shows epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation, characteristic of another salivary gland tumor.
❌ Mucoepidermoid carcinoma:
Incorrect: Mucoepidermoid carcinomas have variable amounts of squamous cells, mucus-secreting cells, and intermediate cells. They are the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary glands and occur mainly in the parotid glands. This patient’s biopsy shows epithelial and mesenchymal differentiation, characteristic of another salivary gland tumor.
❌ Sialadenosis:
Incorrect: Sialadenosis typically presents as bilateral, non-tender swelling of the parotid glands; the condition occurs in several systemic conditions (e.g., nutritional disorders, hypothyroidism, cirrhosis). Pathological examination typically reveals atrophy of parenchymal tissue and a compensatory increase in adipose tissue. 
❌ Facial nerve schwannoma:
Incorrect: Facial nerve schwannomas are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that commonly present with facial paresis or hearing loss. Schwannomas demonstrate S100 expression; therefore, this patient’s pathological and immunohistochemical staining suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of the spleen and the different types of cells and structures found in it. A biopsy is taken from a spleen and is examined under a microscope, as shown below. Which of the following best describes area A?

choices.text: It is a highly vascularized area containing sinusoids and is responsible for removing old red blood cells.
It contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen
It contains a group of mature T-lymphocytes that surround a central arteriole and is part of the adaptive immune system.
The marginal center where antigen presentation occurs

questions.solution:
The spleen is the largest lymphatic organ. It receives blood supply via the splenic artery. Histologically, it is divided into two regions, i.e., the red pulp and the white pulp.  

The red pulp of the spleen is a highly vascularized structure that contains the parenchyma and venous sinuses. The venous sinuses are a chain of interconnected vascular spaces lined with endothelial cells and are responsible for filtering the blood. These sinuses join and drain into the splenic vein.  

The white pulp of the spleen is comprised of follicles. The center of the follicle is made of the germinal matrix, which contains mature and activated B-lymphocytes. Surrounding the germinal matrix is the mantle zone, which includes B-lymphocytes and macrophages. Finally, the outermost layer of the follicle is called the marginal zone. It contains B-lymphocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells, where antigen-presenting cells catch blood-borne antigens and present them to lymphocytes, allowing an adaptive immune response. The T-lymphocytes are primarily found in a periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS), which immediately surrounds a central arteriole.  


Option Analysis

✅ It is a highly vascularized area containing sinusoids and is responsible for removing old red blood cells.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen  :
Incorrect: The splenic capsule contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen. Area A in the picture points to the red pulp, not the splenic capsule.   
❌ It contains a group of mature T-lymphocytes that surround a central arteriole and is part of the adaptive immune system.  :
Incorrect: The white pulp contains the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS), a group of T-lymphocytes surrounding a central arteriole. Area A in the picture is pointing to the red pulp.  
❌ Contains the germinal centers  :
Incorrect: The germinal centers are packed with mature and activated B-cells found in the follicles' center. These follicles are located in the white pulp.  
❌ The marginal center where antigen presentation occurs  :
Incorrect: The marginal center is the outermost layer of the follicles and is found in the white pulp.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to the abrupt onset of right-sided weakness. She was watching TV when she started feeling right side numbness and had difficulty moving her right arm and leg. Medical history is unremarkable. Medications include oral contraceptives and ibuprofen for occasional migraines. She reports a 2-month history of dyspnea which she initially attributed to a viral illness she had prior. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.2°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. On physical examination, strength is 5/5 on the left side and 2/5 on the right side. Touch and temperature sensations are diminished on the right side. Cardiac auscultation reveals a low pitch early diastolic sound heard most prominently on the left sternal border. Echocardiography is obtained and shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Histopathology examination of this patient’s finding will most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Hamartomatous growth; polygonal cells with glycogen-laden vacuoles
Gelatinous material; cells immersed in glycosaminoglycans
Vegetations; strands of fibrin, neutrophils, and lymphocytes

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of dyspnea, low-grade fever, new onset of stroke along with the echocardiography findings, most likely has a cardiac myxoma.  

Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac neoplasm, accounting for 50% of all primary cardiac tumors. The majority of myxomas originate from the left atrium. Histologically, it is composed of gelatinous myxoma cells scattered within a mucopolysaccharide stroma. Macroscopically, they are often described as a pedunculated, “ball-valve” lesion. Patients frequently present with constitutional symptoms (e.g., weight loss, fever) that are thought to be related to the production of cytokines (e.g. interleukin-6) and growth factors by the tumor. Symptoms vary and often accompany a change of body position due to the pedunculated architecture, causing a "ball-valve" effect that obstructs blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. The transient mitral valve obstruction can mimic mitral stenosis. Symptoms include dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, palpitations, chest pain, embolization, and sudden death. Systemic embolization occurs when fragments from the tumor enter the systemic circulation. On physical examination, early diastolic, low pitch sounds are often heard when the tumor is lodged into the mitral valve surface (“tumor plop”). Diagnosis is made by echocardiography and treatment involves resection.     

Option Analysis

❌ Hamartomatous growth; polygonal cells with glycogen-laden vacuoles:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with a cardiac rhabdomyoma, the most common primary pediatric tumor of the heart. It develops almost exclusively in children, and the majority of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. It typically develops intramurally in the septum or the free wall of the left ventricle, where it may cause conduction abnormalities and obstruction, rather than embolization. This patient’s presentation and age favor another diagnosis.   
✅ Gelatinous material; cells immersed in glycosaminoglycans:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Benign growth; mature white adipocytes:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with a lipoma, which can present at any age. The majority of lipomas originate from the subendocardial region and less commonly from the myocardial and subepicardial regions. Many are asymptomatic, but some obstruct flow or cause arrhythmias. Embolization is less likely.   
❌ Vascular channels; malignant cells:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with angiosarcoma, an extremely rare cardiac tumor. Most originate from the right atrium, infiltrate the pericardium and cause right ventricular inflow tract obstruction, pericardial tamponade, and lung metastases. The tumor location and the rarity of cardiac angiosarcoma favor another diagnosis.   
❌ Vegetations; strands of fibrin, neutrophils, and lymphocytes:
Incorrect: These characteristics are consistent with Libman–Sacks endocarditis, a form of nonbacterial endocarditis that is often associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. The mitral valve is typically affected, and the vegetations occur on both sides of the valve. It can also be seen in advanced malignancy and inflammatory conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, sepsis, and burns. Libman–Sacks lesions are often asymptomatic and rarely cause valve dysfunction and embolization. This patient was previously healthy and her echocardiography findings favor another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman comes to the clinic following an abnormal mammogram showing calcifications in the right breast. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. She does not smoke or use alcohol excessively, and she has not experienced weight loss, fever, or trauma. She is referred for a biopsy, which confirms the diagnosis of benign fat necrosis. However, during the biopsy, another area suspected of malignancy is found. The results of the biopsy of this additional are are shown below:  



Reproduced from: flickr

This type of cancer is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings are consistent with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), which is typically clinically and radiographically silent and is almost always an incidental finding.  

LCIS is a noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. Unlike ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), it is rarely associated with calcifications on mammography. Approximately 1/3 of women diagnosed with LCIS eventually develop invasive carcinoma. It is important to note that invasive carcinomas following a diagnosis of LCIS may arise in either breast (unlike DCIS, which predisposes to invasive carcinoma in the same breast). On histology, the tumor has a homogeneous appearance. The cells are monomorphic with round nuclei and are found in clusters within the lobules. The tumor is typically ER-positive and rarely shows overexpression of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2). Treatment may include close observation and radiologic follow-up, chemoprevention with tamoxifen, and rarely, bilateral prophylactic mastectomy.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Rare metastases:
Incorrect: Tubular carcinoma is a rare type of ER-positive/HER2- negative cancer accounting for up to 2% of invasive breast cancers. The majority of cases are detected on mammography as a small irregular mass. On histology, cells are arranged in well-formed tubules. Metastases to the lymph nodes are rare, and the prognosis is excellent. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Aggressive behavior:
Incorrect: A comedocarcinoma is a subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) which is characterized by extensive necrosis, aggressive behavior, and increased risk for recurrence. On histology, the lesion plugs the lactiferous duct and exhibits necrosis. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Lymphatic and vascular invasion:
Incorrect: Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare and highly aggressive form of breast cancer. Patients typically present with a red, tender and indurated breast with dimpling of the skin follicles that resembles an orange peel (peau d’orange). The classic skin appearance is caused due to invasion of the tumor to the skin lymphatic system. On histology, inflammatory carcinoma is poorly differentiated, diffusely infiltrative and obstructs the dermal lymphatic. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
❌ Invasion to the overlying skin:
Incorrect: Paget disease of the breast is an extension of ductal carcinoma in situ to the overlying skin of the nipple. Patients often present with scaly, raw, vesicular, or ulcerated oozing lesions that resemble eczema. On histology, clusters of malignant, intraepithelial Paget cells (adenocarcinoma cells) can be found within the epidermis of the nipple. This patient’s histological findings are associated with a different type of breast cancer.  
✅ Bilateral disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A study was made on the dynamics of skeletal muscle fibers during muscle contractions. A sarcomere unit was examined under the microscope to investigate changes in muscle sarcomere parts during contraction. Two bands shorten in length, but one band remains the same. Which is this band?
questions.solution:
The muscle fibers are made of myofibrils. Myofibrils are made of myofilaments. These myofilaments contain actin and myosin overlapping and make up the muscle's basic contractile unit called a sarcomere.    

Sarcomeres are the building blocks of the skeletal muscles made of arrays of thin actin filaments and thick myosin filaments aligned perpendicularly. When the sarcomere is examined under electron microscopy, the parts of the sarcomere can be identified. First, the A band is the area in the middle of the sarcomere where actin and myosin overlap. In the middle of the A band, the H band (which is paler in color) and M line can also be seen. The H band is the area in the middle of the A band that contains no actin filaments. Finally, the A band is surrounded by two pale regions. These are the  I bands, which have only actin filaments without overlapping myosin. These I bands include the Z lines in the middle, and the sarcomere unit extends from one Z line to the other.    

During muscle contraction, the muscle fibers shorten as the myosin pulls on the overlapping actin filaments. This results in a shortening of the I band and H band. However, the A band always remains the same in contraction and relaxation.  


Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: These are the Z lines inside the I band. The Z lines are pulled closer together when the muscles contract because the I band shortens.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: This is the M line that is inside the H band.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: This is the I band. The I band shortens during muscle contraction.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: This is the H band which also shortens during muscle contraction.  
✅ E:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old individual comes to the physician due to fever for the last three days. The patient has a history of diabetic nephropathy and chronic kidney failure and underwent successful kidney transplantation one month ago. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 88/minute, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. On physical examination, tenderness is noted in the graft site. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Chart review from the previous visit two weeks ago shows a serum creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. BK virus DNA PCR test is negative. The patient is referred for a biopsy from the transplanted kidney. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological examination of the biopsy?  

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium  147 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.5 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  30 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.3 mg/dL

choices.text: Dense mononuclear infiltration of the interstitium and necrosis of the arterial wall
Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels
Interstitial inflammation, tubular fibrosis with basophilic intranuclear inclusions
Interstitial fibrosis with arteriolar hyalinosis and tubular vacuolization

questions.solution:
This patient has fever, graft site tenderness, and abnormal kidney function test one month after kidney transplantation. This presentation is concerning for acute graft rejection. Although the incidence of acute renal graft rejection has decreased immensely after the introduction of immunosuppressant drugs, it is still one of the leading causes of rejection.  
Acute rejection develops due to recognition of the graft antigens by the immune system, and it results from two immunological immune responses that act in combination or alone: the cellular and the humoral immune responses. The cellular response is mediated by T-cells, which directly recognize MHC antigens on the graft and cause damage to the graft (T-cell dependent process), while the humoral response develops when B cells are recruited (by T-helper cells) and generate antibodies that cause acute humoral rejection (B-cell dependent process). Therefore, acute rejection is considered a type II (antibody-mediated) and type IV (cellular-mediated) hypersensitivity reaction.  

Acute rejection develops from one week to three months after transplantation, and patients usually complain of fever and graft site tenderness. Additionally, there is typically decreased function of the transplanted organ; for example, patients with acute renal graft rejection develop anuria, metabolic abnormalities (e.g. hyperkalemia), and elevated serum creatinine, as seen in this patient.  

A biopsy is needed to diagnose acute graft rejection and differentiate it from other diagnoses (e.g. tacrolimus toxicity). Histologically, acute graft rejection is characterized by mononuclear lymphocytic infiltrate in the interstitium of the graft tissue along with necrosis of the arterial walls (vasculitis).  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Option Analysis

✅ Dense mononuclear infiltration of the interstitium and necrosis of the arterial wall:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with tubular atrophy :
Incorrect: Interstitial fibrosis with tubular atrophy is seen in chronic transplant rejection, not acute transplant rejection. 
❌ Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels:
Incorrect: Widespread thrombosis of the graft vessels is seen in patients with hyperacute transplant rejection, not acute transplant rejection.
❌ Interstitial inflammation, tubular fibrosis with basophilic intranuclear inclusions :
Incorrect: BK virus is an opportunistic infection of transplanted kidneys that can lead to nephritis and graft failure. On histology, viral basophilic intranuclear inclusions can be seen in addition to interstitial inflammation and varying degrees of tubular atrophy and fibrosis. However, this patient has a negative BK DNA PCR test, making BK virus infection less likely the cause.  
❌ Interstitial fibrosis with arteriolar hyalinosis and tubular vacuolization:
Incorrect: Tacrolimus toxicity on histology is characterized by interstitial fibrosis, arteriolar hyalinosis, and tubular vacuolization. In addition, patients may show acute tubular necrosis. However, tacrolimus nephrotoxicity occurs due to vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles of the kidney, causing prerenal kidney injury where the BUN:Cr ratio is >20 (unlike this patient).

questions.text: A segment of the dorsal root ganglia was taken from a cadaver and examined under microscopy, and the neuron's cell bodies were identified. In their cytoplasm, dark blue bodies were identified with a special stain, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about these stained structures?

choices.text: They consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
They consist of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum
They are only found in the cell bodies of the neurons
They are found in the neuronal cell bodies, the dendrites, and the axons

questions.solution:
The dorsal root ganglia comprise a group of neuronal cell bodies outside the central nervous system. When examining these cell bodies under microscopy, few structures can be identified.  

Nissl bodies or Nissl granules are groups of structures in the cytoplasm of the neuronal cell bodies identified by their darker color. These Nissl bodies can be stained with a special stain called Nissl stain.  

Nissl bodies are comprised of rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes. They are seen in the neuronal cell bodies and also can be seen in the dendrites. However, Nissl bodies are not found in the axons.


Option Analysis

✅ They consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ They consist of the smooth endoplasmic reticulum  :
Incorrect: The Nissl bodies are darker granules in the cytoplasm of the neuron cell bodies and the dendrites and consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes.  
❌ They are only found in the cell bodies of the neurons  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies are found in the cell bodies of neurons and the dendrites.  
❌ They are found in the neuronal cell bodies, the dendrites, and the axons  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies are only found in the neuronal cell bodies and the dendrites; they are not seen in the axons.  
❌ They consist of the mitochondria  :
Incorrect: Nissl bodies consist of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes. They do not contain mitochondria.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male with a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents to the primary care physician with leg swelling. He states that “My shoes won’t fit anymore, and I feel like I’ve gained weight too.” The patient last received treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma 1.5 weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 105/64 mmHg. On physical exam he is noted to have bilateral periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Urinalysis demonstrates 4+ protein and is negative for blood. The patient subsequently undergoes a kidney biopsy. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on electron microscopy?

choices.text: Thickened basement membrane with a spike and dome appearance
Glomerular basement membrane with a lamellated basket weave appearance

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma presents with new lower extremity edema and proteinuria consistent with minimal change disease. This condition is the most common type of nephrotic syndrome in children (average age of onset is 2-years-old) and is often triggered by cytokine-mediated damage, in this case due to the patient's history of lymphoma.

Minimal change disease occurs primarily in children and is often idiopathic. However it has a number of known secondary causes including malignancies (lymphoma), drugs (NSAIDs), immunizations, and recent infections. The disease is thought to occur due to T-cell mediated injury to podocytes that results in disruption of the charge barrier, which leads to massive proteinuria.  

Clinical features include edema, frothy urine, and laboratory findings consistent with nephrotic syndrome (hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, proteinuria). Renal biopsy will demonstrate normal glomeruli on light microscopy, no deposits on immunofluorescence microscopy, and diffuse podocyte effacement on electron microscopy. Treatment for minimal change disease includes a course of oral corticosteroids.   

Option Analysis

✅ Podocyte foot effacement:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Thickened basement membrane with a spike and dome appearance:
Incorrect: Membranous nephropathy, also known as membranous glomerulonephritis, can be caused by drugs, infectious processes, or antibodies against the phospholipase A2 receptor. Membranous nephropathy is an uncommon cause of nephrotic syndrome in pediatric patients.
❌ Subepithelial immune complex humps:
Incorrect: Immune complex humps are observed in patients with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This disease process typically presents in patients 2-4 weeks after a Streptococcal infection and manifests with cola-colored urine and hematuria. In contrast, this patient has no history of pharyngitis and the urinalysis is negative for blood. 
❌ Mesangial immune complex deposition:
Incorrect: Mesangial immune complex deposition is the electron microscopy finding for IgA nephropathy. This disease process is characterized by episodic hematuria that occurs after or concurrently with respiratory or gastrointestinal tract infections. In contrast, this patient has no history of hematuria.
❌ Glomerular basement membrane with a lamellated basket weave appearance:
Incorrect: A basket weave appearance is the electron microscopy finding for Alport syndrome, a disease which results in splitting of the basement membrane due to a mutation in type IV collagen. This disease clinically presents with additional symptoms including difficulty hearing and vision disturbances.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by her concerned parents. She was born at 39-weeks gestational age via a spontaneous vaginal delivery, and past medical history is non-contributory. The patient is at the 30th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 90/63 mmHg. Physical exam reveals increased distance between the eyes, a flat nasal bridge, and triphalangeal thumbs. Laboratory testing is obtained, and the results are shown below:



Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological analysis of this patient’s bone marrow aspiration?

choices.text: Hypocellular bone marrow with fat cells and fibrous stroma
Hypercellular bone marrow with immature cells
Hypercellular bone marrow with increased blast cells

questions.solution:
This patient has growth delay, craniofacial and thumb abnormalities, and anemia. She has pure red cell aplasia secondary to Diamond-Blackfan anemia.  

Pure red cell aplasia is a type of non-hemolytic macrocytic anemia. In pure red cell aplasia, the bone marrow ceases to produce erythrocytes, whereas leukocyte and platelet production are unaffected. As a result, unlike the pancytopenia seen in patients with aplastic anemia, patients with pure red cell aplasia only have anemia with low reticulocyte count. Bone marrow aspiration will show a normocellular bone marrow without erythroblasts.  



Causes of pure red cell aplasia may be congenital or acquired. Congenital causes include Diamond-Blackfan anemia, and acquired causes include autoimmune diseases against erythrocyte precursors, tumors that produce antibodies against erythropoietin (e.g. thymoma), and viral infections (e.g., HIV, HSV, parvovirus B19). However, pure red cell aplasia may also be idiopathic with no identifiable cause.  

Treatment includes red blood cell transfusions, immunosuppressants, and addressing any underlying causes (e.g. surgical resection of thymoma).  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypocellular bone marrow with fat cells and fibrous stroma:
Incorrect: A hypocellular bone marrow with fat cells and fibrous stroma is associated with aplastic anemia. Individuals with aplastic anemia have pancytopenia, whereas this patient has only a decrease in hemoglobin. As a result, this patient has pure red cell aplasia, most likely due to Diamond-Blackfan anemia given the patient’s facial and thumb abnormalities.
✅ Normocellular bone marrow without erythroblasts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypercellular bone marrow with immature cells:
Incorrect: A hypercellular bone marrow with immature cells is associated with leukemia. However, this patient has an isolated anemia, facial abnormalities, and triphalangeal thumbs, which is more consistent with pure red blood cell aplasia secondary to Diamond-Blackfan anemia. Pure red blood cell aplasia results in a normocellular bone marrow without erythroblasts.  
❌ Hypercellular bone marrow with increased blast cells:
Incorrect: A hypercellular bone marrow with increased blast cells on bone marrow aspiration is associated with acute myelogenous leukemia (AML). The condition can cause hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and an elevated leukocyte count. In contrast, this patient does not have any of these findings.
❌ Normocellular bone marrow with fibrosis:
Incorrect: Normocellular bone marrow with fibrosis is associated with myelodysplastic syndromes, such as myelofibrosis. These conditions tend to affect older individuals in their 5th and 6th decades of life. It would be unusual for any of the myelodysplastic syndromes to affect a child.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Over the past 2 months, the patient has noticed an increase in her abdominal girth despite losing 4.5 kg (10 lb) without changes in diet. She smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years but does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Menarche occurred at age 11, and her last menstrual cycle was 10 years ago. The patient’s last Pap smear was normal. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, abdominal distention and shifting dullness are noticed. Pelvic examination reveals mild tenderness and a right-sided adnexal mass. Cancer antigen 125 is elevated. The patient is prepared for laparoscopy. Which of the following will most likely be found on histopathological examination of the patient’s adnexal mass?

choices.text: Sheets large cells with clear, glycogen-rich cytoplasm and occasional granulomas
Sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and concentric calcifications
Small clusters of round cells encircling a central cavity

questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman with risk factors for ovarian cancer is presenting with abdominal ascites, pelvic pressure, fatigue, and an adnexal mass, raising concerns for possible ovarian malignancy. Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125) is a marker protein that is typically elevated in women with epithelial ovarian cancer and is seen in up to 90% of cases. From the answers above, only choice D describes serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most common type of ovarian cancer. Of note, CA-125 can be undetectable in cases limited to the ovary and elevated in a variety of benign conditions and other cancers. Therefore, it is mainly used in monitoring response to therapy.  

Ovarian cancers may arise from any of the 3 cell types found in normal ovary: the surface epithelium, the germ cells, and the sex cord–stromal cells. Surface epithelial tumors account for the majority of ovarian tumors, of which the serous subtype is the most common. Serous tumors are more commonly seen in women between 45 and 65 years of age. Risk factors for developing epithelial carcinomas of the ovary include older age, early menarche or late menopause, genetic mutations (e.g., BRCA1 and BRCA2), Lynch syndrome, nulliparity, and endometriosis. On gross examination, the mass is cystic, multilocular with serous/bloody fluid, and contains soft friable papillary projections. On histology, it is composed of sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and occasional concentric calcifications known as psammoma bodies.  

Mucinous tumors are another less common subtype of epithelial ovarian cancer that differ from serous tumors in a few aspects: the epithelium consists of mucin-secreting cells, the tumors are less likely to be malignant, and they are associated with a better prognosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Sheets large cells with clear, glycogen-rich cytoplasm and occasional granulomas:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with dysgerminoma, the equivalent of male seminoma. On histology, it is composed of sheets of uniform cells described as having “fried egg” appearance. Peak incidence occurs in the 2nd to 3rd decade of life. hCG is often mildly elevated. It is not associated with elevated CA-125.
❌ Primitive neuroepithelial elements:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with immature teratomas, a malignant tumor commonly diagnosed before the age of 20. This tumor is not associated with elevated CA-125.
❌ Transitional-type epithelium with “coffee bean” nuclei:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a benign Brenner tumor, a rare condition. It is usually unilateral and consists of transitional-type epithelium that resembles that of the urinary tract. On histology, it is often described as having “coffee bean” nuclei. It is not associated with elevated CA-125.
✅ Sheets of malignant cells invading the ovarian stroma and concentric calcifications:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
