❌ Small clusters of round cells encircling a central cavity:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with granulosa cell tumors, a type of potentially malignant ovarian sex cord tumor. These include 2 subtypes, adult and juvenile. Histology shows granulosa cells arranged around collections of eosinophilic fluid, known as Call-Exner bodies, which resemble primordial follicles. These tumors often produce estrogen and/or progesterone, leading to symptoms of hyperestrogenism (e.g., abnormal uterine bleeding, breast tenderness) and in children, sexual precocity. Inhibin is the most common serum marker of these tumors, not CA-125.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with worsening fatigue and arthralgias. She reports her symptoms started 2-3 weeks ago and states that her eyes have looked “discolored.” She has a history of chronic alcohol use but does not use illicit drugs. She had unprotected sexual intercourse several months ago. She has never received blood products. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for scleral icterus and hepatomegaly. Blood titers are positive for a DNA hepadnavirus, and she subsequently undergoes liver biopsy. Which of the following best describes the most likely histologic features of this patient’s biopsy specimen?

choices.text: Lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis
Spotty necrosis and portal expansion with inflammatory infiltrates
Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, malaise, and recent unprotected sexual intercourse. The workup is notable for titers positive for a DNA hepadnavirus, consistent with hepatitis B infection. Of the histologic descriptions listed, a ground glass appearance of hepatocytes is most consistent with hepatitis B infection.  

Hepatitis B is a partially double-stranded DNA virus of the hepadnavirus family. It is transmitted via multiple routes including parenteral transmission, sexual transmission, as well as vertical transmission from mother to fetus. Following inoculation, hepatitis B infects hepatocytes via a bile salt transporter and enters the cell. During the proliferative phase, viral HBsAg and HBcAg are produced in abundance within the hepatocyte cytoplasm and are ultimately expressed on the hepatocyte cell surface. The cytoplasm's granular homogeneous eosinophilic staining is caused by the presence of HBsAg. Abundant hepatitis B antigen in the endoplasmic reticulum results in the “ground-glass” appearance of hepatocytes. Ultimately, viral HBsAg and HBcAg expressed on the hepatocyte cell surface trigger an immune response by cytotoxic T-cells, resulting in hepatocellular damage.

Option Analysis

✅ Granular eosinophilic "ground-glass" appearance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis:
Incorrect: Biopsy specimens in patients with hepatitis C will typically demonstrate lymphoid aggregates with focal areas of macrovesicular steatosis. Hepatitis C is primarily transmitted parenterally, and this patient does not have risk factors for bloodborne transmission.
❌ Hepatocyte swelling and monocyte infiltration:
Incorrect: Biopsy specimens in patients with hepatitis A will typically demonstrate hepatocyte swelling and monocyte infiltration—as will most presentations of acute hepatitis, which tends to present with nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant pain.
❌ Spotty necrosis and portal expansion with inflammatory infiltrates:
Incorrect: Hepatitis E results in areas of patchy necrosis on biopsy. It is rare in the United States and poses a high risk to pregnant patients and those with underlying liver disease.
❌ Regenerating nodules of hepatocytes and deposition of fibrosis:
Incorrect: Cirrhosis is unlikely in this patient without other evidence of end-stage liver disease including ascites, bleeding dyscrasias, or spider angiomata.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a non-productive cough and associated shortness of breath with exertion. He reports his symptoms started after he began working as a manager in a textile factory. He reports he is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 61/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 131/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. As part of his work-up, he undergoes a transbronchial biopsy, which demonstrates the following histologic findings:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia    

This patient likely has occupational exposure to which of the following inorganic compounds?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of working in a textile-factory presents with non-productive cough and dyspnea. His transbronchial biopsy specimen is notable for multiple ferruginous bodies, consistent with asbestos exposure. Given this patient's constellation of findings, he likely has asbestosis—a type of restrictive lung disease and pneumoconiosis.  

Abestoses refers to an interstitial lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers. These silicate fibers are classically found in materials involved in shipbuilding, plumbing, roofing, and the textile industry. Inhaled asbestos fibers become lodged in the small airways, which over time results in fibrosis and restrictive lung physiology.

Patients exposed to asbestos through these industries may develop symptoms dependent on the duration and intensity of exposure. If exposure duration and intensity is adequate, symptoms usually arise in the form of productive cough, exertional dyspnea, and fatigue. More severe symptoms—indicating progressive fibrosis—may include hypoxia, nail clubbing, and dry crackles at the bases of the lung. If left untreated, asbestosis can lead to right heart failure (cor pulmonale), mesothelioma, or bronchogenic carcinoma.     

Diagnosis of asbestos rests on history, physiologic, radiographic, and histologic findings. Patients will typically demonstrate restrictive physiology on pulmonary function testing (increased FEV1/FVC ratio), as well as bilateral reticular opacities that affect the lower lobes on chest x ray or CT-scan. Additional radiographic findings include pleural plaques with calcification as well as an “incomplete border sign” (where the inner margin of the pleura is well defined but the outer margin is barely visible). Histologically, sputum samples or specimens from transbronchial biopsy will demonstrate ferruginous bodies with Prussian blue staining.    



Option Analysis

✅ Asbestos:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Silica :
Incorrect: Silicosis is another type of pneumoconiosis more commonly found in patients with a history of sandblasting or working in a mine. Histopathological examination of silicotic nodules typically reveals weakly birefringent particles in a central hyalinized region surrounded by concentric collagen fibers. It is not associated with the formation of ferringous bodies.   
❌ Beryllium :
Incorrect: Berylliosis is another type of pneumoconiosis more commonly found in patients with a history of working in the aerospace and manufacturing industries. Berylliosis tends to present with noncaseating granulomas on histology.   
❌ Talc :
Incorrect: Talc pneumoconiosis, now rare, resulted from deposition in the lungs in those who worked as talc millers. This disease typically causes granulomatous inflammation on histology.  
❌ Coal dust :
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to coal dust results in coal miners’ pneumoconiosis. Prolonged coal dust exposure results in macrophages laden with carbon, with subsequent inflammation and fibrosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is evaluated for 3-months of muscle weakness. The patient reports that the weakness is most prominent in the shoulders and hips. She works as a barber and is having difficulty keeping her arms raised while cutting hair. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 117/68 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respiratory rate is 11/min. Physical examination is notable for weakness and tenderness to light palpation in the large muscles of the extremities. No rashes are observed on the patient’s body. A proximal thigh muscle biopsy is performed. What cellular type and infiltration pattern would be most likely found on muscle biopsy?
questions.solution:
Polymyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness. The pelvic and shoulder muscles are most commonly affected. This weakness can present with difficulty rising from a chair, lifting one’s arms, climbing stairs, or combing one’s hair. Sometimes, the patient’s muscles may be tender or painful. In severe cases, the muscles of the pharynx and esophagus are involved, resulting in dysphagia. Skin findings are absent in patients with polymyositis.  

Polymyositis is an autoimmune condition which occurs when cytotoxic (CD8+) T-cells are inappropriately activated by normal muscle proteins. The cytotoxic T-cells attack muscle cells, resulting in their apoptosis. The specific antigenic targets in polymyositis include tRNA synthetases, also called Jo-1, a nuclear protein known as Mi-2, and components of the signal-recognition particle (SRP) which helps with proteins trafficking within the cell. The destruction of muscle cells can lead to muscle weakness and can cause muscle enzymes, such as aldolase and creatine kinase to spill into the blood, resulting in elevated laboratory values.  

Muscle biopsies are often performed in the work-up of polymyositis and reveal endomysial infiltration (infiltration of the sheath surrounding individual muscle fibers) by CD8+ T-cells.  




Option Analysis

❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern CD4+ lymphocytes  Perimysial :
Incorrect: Perimysial infiltration by CD4+ T-cells would be observed in dermatomyositis. This condition typically presents with proximal muscle weakness and skin findings (e.g., heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, etc.) While the patient has proximal muscle weakness, the absence of skin findings on physical examination makes dermatomyositis less likely. 
❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern CD4+ lymphocytes  Endomysial:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is characterized by CD4+ T-cell infiltration. However, dermatomyositis presents with a perimysial infiltration pattern. This means that the lymphocytes infiltrate the connective tissue sheath that groups muscle fibers into bundles.
❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern  CD8+ lymphocytes Perimysial :
Incorrect: Infiltration by CD8+ lymphocytes would be observed in polymyositis. This condition presents with proximal muscle weakness but no cutaneous findings, which is consistent with the patient’s presentation. However, polymyositis presents with an endomysial infiltration pattern. This means that the lymphocytes infiltrate the connective tissue that ensheath individual muscle fibers. 
✅  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern  CD8+ lymphocytes  Endomysial  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Cellular Type  Infiltration Pattern  Eosinophils Perimysial :
Incorrect: Eosinophilic infiltration may be observed in vasculitides such as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome). Vasculitides can also present with cutaneous symptoms and potentially muscle weakness secondary to systemic inflammation. However, Churg-Strauss syndrome and similar conditions also present with respiratory tract symptoms, as well as renal involvement.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parent because of abnormal pigmentation on his face. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and has been developing normally. The patient’s biological mother developed breast cancer at the age of 41. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows several blue-gray to brown spots in the perioral region, as shown in the image below:  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

A genetic condition is suspected, and the patient undergoes a surveillance colonoscopy, which reveals numerous polyps in the small intestine and colon. Which of the following best describes the histological characteristics of the polyps seen on colonoscopy?

choices.text: Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle lined by normal intestinal epithelium
Serrated epithelial surface with proliferation of the basal portion of the crypts
Polypoid mass of inflamed and reactive mucosal tissue
Serrated luminal structure with mild dysplasia
Finger-like projections lined by dysplastic epithelium

questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation and a family history of cancer, likely has Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS). Patients with PJS are predisposed to developing multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps. Although these polyps are most commonly benign, they may grow progressively and become symptomatic or undergo malignant transformation.    

Hamartomas are disorganized, tumorlike growths composed of mature cell types normally present at the site at which the polyp develops. Polyps in PJS most commonly develop in the small intestine, although they can also present in the stomach and colon. On gross evaluation, the polyps are large and pedunculated. Histologic examination will reveal a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.  


Option Analysis

✅ Arborizing pattern of smooth muscle lined by normal intestinal epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Serrated epithelial surface with proliferation of the basal portion of the crypts:
Incorrect: Hyperplastic polyps are the most common non-neoplastic polyps in the colon. The serrated surface contour can look similar to sessile serrated adenomas, and therefore they need to be differentiated due to the malignant potential of the latter. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to a different type of colonic polyp.
❌ Polypoid mass of inflamed and reactive mucosal tissue:
Incorrect: Inflammatory pseudopolyps are irregularly shaped patches of colonic mucosa that are the result of recurrent mucosal ulceration and regeneration. This type of polyp is typically seen in patients with localized or diffuse inflammation, such as in the case of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This patient lacks the features of IBD, however, making this type of colonic polyp unlikely.
❌ Serrated luminal structure with mild dysplasia:
Incorrect: Serrated polyps are often flat or sessile and are characterized by a saw-tooth appearance on histology. These polyps are often neoplastic with mild degrees of dysplasia. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to a different type of colonic polyp.
❌ Finger-like projections lined by dysplastic epithelium :
Incorrect: This histological description describes a villous adenoma, which has a very high likelihood of undergoing malignant transformation. This patient with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, however, is predisposed to the formation of a different type of colonic polyp.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his son due to an “inability to take care of himself.” The patient is unable to prepare food, bathe himself, or take daily medications. According to the son, his father has had difficulty remembering recent events, such as his grandson’s birthday party last month, but he is able to recall events that occurred many years ago, such as his own wedding. Eight months ago, the patient was forced to give up driving after he got lost in his own neighborhood on numerous occasions. Which of the following pathologic findings is most likely to be present within the neurons of this patient’s brain?

choices.text: Intracellular aggregates of improperly cleaved precursor protein
Round eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions due to viral infection
Brownish-yellow granular material composed of lipid and protein

questions.solution:
Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common cause of irreversible dementia in elderly patients. AD typically manifests with an insidious onset of impaired higher intellectual function, impaired memory, as well as alterations in mood and behavior.

The fundamental abnormality in AD is the accumulation of amyloid-beta (Aβ) plaques and tau protein tangles in specific regions of the brain. These events result in neuronal inflammation, dysfunction, and death.

Aβ plaques are created when the transmembrane protein amyloid precursor protein (APP) is improperly cleaved, resulting in insoluble fibrils that eventually aggregate and form extracellular amyloid plaques. As a result, patients who have abnormal APP processing (e.g. presenilin mutations), impaired Aβ clearance (e.g. ApoE4 allele), or elevated production of APP (e.g. trisomy 21), are at increased risk of developing AD.

Tau, on the other hand, is a microtubule-associated protein present in neuronal axons. In patients with AD, these proteins become hyperphosphorylated and give rise to intracellular neurofibrillary tangles (indicated by the black arrow). The hyperphosphorylated tau is no longer able to stabilize microtubules, leading to cytoskeleton damage and neuronal injury.



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperphosphorylated microtubule-associated proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intracellular aggregates of improperly cleaved precursor protein:
Incorrect: The transmembrane protein amyloid precursor protein (APP) is normally neuroprotective. However, in patients with Alzheimer disease, there is improper enzymatic cleavage of this protein. The abnormal proteins eventually aggregate and form extracellular, not intracellular, plaques.
❌ Alpha-synuclein-positive cytoplasmic inclusions:
Incorrect: Neurons contain a protein called alpha-synuclein, and in Lewy body dementia, this protein is misfolded within the neurons. The misfolded alpha-synuclein then aggregates to form Lewy bodies that deposit inside neurons and appear as eosinophilic inclusions under microscopy.
❌ Round eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions due to viral infection:
Incorrect: Negri bodies are cytoplasmic inclusion bodies that occur due to rabies virus accumulation within the neurons. Patients typically present with hydrophobia, central nervous system symptoms (e.g., confusion, hallucinations, agitation), and eventually coma and death.
❌ Brownish-yellow granular material composed of lipid and protein:
Incorrect: Lipofuscin, commonly known as the “wear-and-tear pigment,” is an insoluble intracellular material that accumulates in a variety of tissues (e.g., heart, liver, brain) with aging. It is not injurious to the cell but is indicative of past free radical injury.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of severe generalized pruritus and blisters. The pruritus began a month ago, followed by multiple tense blisters over his body two weeks later. Some of the blisters ruptured, causing moist erosions. Past medical history is significant for Parkinson disease and hypertension. Current medications include levodopa/carbidopa and lisinopril. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple 1 to 3 cm tense bullae as shown:  


Reproduced from Flickr  
Which of the following histological findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an eczematous prodrome followed by the appearance of multiple tense, pruritic bullae all over the body is suffering from bullous pemphigoid (BP), a chronic, relapsing-remitting autoimmune blistering skin disease.

BP results from a type II hypersensitivity reaction where IgG antibodies are formed against the hemidesmosomal proteins (bullous pemphigoid antigen 2, collagen type XVII) of the basement membrane, causing the separation of dermis and epidermis and resultant subepidermal blisters. It is associated with neurological disorders (e.g., Parkinson disease, dementia, bipolar disorder) and malignancies. It typically presents in older adults with a pre-bullous prodrome of urticaria or eczema-like pruritic skin lesions that can last for weeks to months. This is followed by the development of severe pruritic, tense bullae (negative Nikolsky sign) typically in the flexural surfaces, groin, and axilla, but the condition can involve the whole body. In contrast to pemphigus vulgaris, mucosal involvement (e.g. intraoral) is less common. Biopsy of the lesion would reveal eosinophilic spongiosis and subepidermal blisters (unlike intraepidermal blisters in pemphigus vulgaris).

Direct immunofluorescence is highly sensitive and shows a linear pattern at the dermal-epidermal junction. Treatment is by topical or systemic corticosteroids.  

Option Analysis

✅  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This skin biopsy shows a “saw-tooth” shaped dermo-epidermal junction (presence of lymphocytes) and a thickened stratum granulosum – characteristic of lichen planus. It usually presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. In oral mucosa, it manifests as Wickham striae (reticular white lines). As seen in this patient, the tense pruritic bullae would be seen in a bullous pemphigoid.   
❌  Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect:  This histologic slide demonstrating hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and long rete ridges is suggestive of verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts. The condition usually presents with cauliflower-like papules with a rough, papillomatous, and hyperkeratotic surface, unlike the tense pruritic blisters seen in this patient.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This histologic image shows fibrins and neutrophils at the dermal papillae and subepidermal microabscesses, which are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis. This is an autoimmune skin disorder prevalent among gluten-sensitive individuals which presents with intensely pruritic groups of papules and vesicles on extensor elbows or knees. Tense widespread bullae preceded by a prodrome of pruritus is typical of bullous pemphigoid.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This histologic image shows dysplastic keratinocytes with “keratin pearls” involving the full thickness of the epidermis suggestive of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It usually appears as 0.5-1.5 cm indurated or firm plaque, papule, or nodule with or without hyperkeratosis and ulceration. Tense pruritic bullae indicate an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist for a routine well-visit. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses an intrauterine device for contraception. A decision is made to perform a routine pap smear. The region sampled during the pap smear is shown below. Which of the following best describes the region sampled in the pap smear and its corresponding histological epithelium?
questions.solution:
The cervix is the lower, cylindrical part of the uterus that opens into the vagina. Histologically, the cervix is different from the rest of the uterus and has a mucosa that does not shed during menstruation. The cervical mucosa can be separated into three distinct regions: the endocervix, the transformation zone, and the ectocervix.    

- The endocervical mucosa forms the walls of the cervical canal and has a mucus-secreting simple columnar epithelium.   

- The ectocervical mucosa is present in the part of the cervix that protrudes into the upper vagina and surrounds the external os, which is the lower opening of the uterus.     This mucosa will have a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium that’s continuous with the vagina.   

- The transformation zone is the region between the endo- and ectocervix. There’s an abrupt change from columnar cells to squamous cells within the transformation           zone called the squamocolumnar junction.   

The exact location of the squamocolumnar junction will change or shift depending on the age of the individual as well as changes in the size of the uterus during menstruation. The transformation zone is the ideal site to collect cells from during a Pap smear or Pap test.  

Figure shows the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix, with abrupt transition. The ectocervix, with its 
stratified squamous epithelium, is visible on the left. Simple columnar epithelium, typical of the endocervix, 
is visible on the right. A layer of connective tissue is visible under both types of epithelium.  

Option Analysis

❌ Endocervix; simple columnar epithelium only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Endocervix only is not commonly sampled in pap smears.
❌ Ectocervix; stratified squamous epithelium only  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Ectocervix only is not commonly sampled in pap smears.  
✅ Transformation zone; squamocolumnar junction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Uterus; simple columnar epithelium  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Uterine tissue is not commonly sampled in pap smears.  
❌ Vagina; stratified squamous epithelium  :
Incorrect: This answer choice is incorrect. Vaginal tissue is not commonly sampled in pap smears.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old male is brought to the emergency department due to acute-onset shortness of breath and wheezing. The patient has no smoking history and works as an accountant. Despite aggressive medical intervention, the patient passes away in the hospital due to respiratory failure. Autopsy examination is performed, and sputum analysis reveals numerous crystalloids composed of eosinophil proteins; one is shown below:  


 Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Further histopathological examination is also likely to reveal which of the following findings?

choices.text: Spiral-shaped desquamated epithelium on sputum analysis
Nodules surrounded by whorls of concentric collagen fibers on lung biopsy
Elastase-mediated alveolar septal destruction on lung biopsy
Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells on lymph node biopsy
Dust-laden macrophages with dense collagen deposition on lung biopsy

questions.solution:
This patient presented with shortness of breath and has Charcot-Leyden crystals on sputum analysis. He likely had respiratory failure secondary to an acute asthma exacerbation.     

Charcot-Leyden crystals can be found in patients with asthma. These crystals are hexagonal, double-pointed, and formed from the breakdown of eosinophils.    

Patients with asthma may also have Curschmann spirals, which are mucous plugs containing whorls of shed epithelial cells. These plugs can be dangerous, as they can not only block air exchange but can also prevent inhaled medications from reaching the site of inflammation.  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia



Option Analysis

✅ Spiral-shaped desquamated epithelium on sputum analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nodules surrounded by whorls of concentric collagen fibers on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: Silicotic nodules demonstrate concentrically arranged hyalinized collagen fibers surrounding an amorphous center. This “whorled” appearance of collagen fibers is characteristic of silicosis. However, this patient lacks risk factors (e.g. history of working in mining or glass manufacturing) that would place him at risk of developing silicosis.
❌ Elastase-mediated alveolar septal destruction on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: Emphysema causes destruction of alveolar parenchyma due to increased neutrophil-elastase activity. However, this patient’s sputum analysis reveals Charcot-Leyden crystals. This patient most likely has an underlying diagnosis of asthma, as opposed to emphysema.
❌ Peribronchial noncaseating granulomas with giant cells on lymph node biopsy:
Incorrect: This histopathological finding is classically seen in sarcoidosis. However, this patient’s sputum analysis reveals Charcot-Leyden crystals. This patient most likely has an underlying diagnosis of asthma, as opposed to sarcoidosis.
❌ Dust-laden macrophages with dense collagen deposition on lung biopsy:
Incorrect: This finding may be seen in patients with coal workers pneumoconiosis. However, this patient has no history of being exposed to large quantities of coal dust that would place him at risk of developing this condition.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a sudden onset of acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain. Two hours ago, the patient felt a sudden, acute, sharp pain in the lower abdomen, followed by nausea and vomiting. Medical history is unremarkable. Serum b-hCG is negative. On physical examination, right adnexal tenderness is noted. Doppler ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ovarian torsion, as well as the presence of an ovarian mass. The patient subsequently undergoes ovarian cystectomy and detorsion. Which of the following features, if found on histopathological analysis, indicates a malignant entity?
questions.solution:
Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that constitute up to 20% of ovarian tumors. They typically occur in the first 2 decades of life. The majority of teratomas are benign cystic teratomas while the immature, malignant subtype is rare. In general, the younger the patient, the greater the likelihood of the lesion being malignant.  

Malignant (immature) teratomas, also called teratoblastoma, or embryonal teratoma, are often seen in young patients with a mean age of 18 years. Grossly, they appear bulky and solid with areas of necrosis. Similar to mature teratomas, they may contain mature tissue such as hair and teeth. On microscopy, their hallmark is the presence of immature elements or minimally differentiated tissue such as muscle, nerve, or other tissues. The most common finding is immature neural tissue. Patients with immature teratomas often present with similar symptoms to other ovarian neoplasms including abdominal enlargement or pain, ovarian torsion, or they may be asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally. In some cases, alpha-fetoprotein or lactate dehydrogenase may be elevated. Similar to other tumors, the prognosis depends on grade and stage at the time of diagnosis.


Option Analysis

❌ Hair follicles:
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, bronchial or gastrointestinal epithelium, as well as other tissues. While malignant transformation is possible, the presence of well-differentiated tissues (e.g. hair) indicates a benign lesion.
❌ Tooth-like tissue  :
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. The tumors are mostly unilateral and may be filled with sebaceous secretions, hair, teeth, bone and cartilage, bronchial or gastrointestinal epithelium, as well as other tissues. While malignant transformation is possible, the presence of well-differentiated tissues (e.g. tooth) indicates a benign lesion.
✅ Immature neural tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid tissue:
Incorrect: Struma ovarii is a type of specialized teratoma in which mature thyroid tissue is found within the ovary which may cause hyperthyroidism. The majority of cases of struma ovarii are benign, and the presence of thyroid tissue does not indicate malignancy.  
❌ Sebaceous glands:
Incorrect: Benign (mature) cystic teratomas are typified by the presence of differentiated (mature) tissues derived from all three germ cell layers: ectoderm, endoderm, and mesoderm. Sebaceous glands typically arise from mature ectodermal tissue; well-differentiated tissue is invariably benign and malignant transformation is very unlikely.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic due to anxiety. Over the past few months, the patient has felt more stressed and has had an occasional feeling that his heart was racing, which he attributed to work stress. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland is noted. Examination of the patient’s lower extremities reveals the following finding:

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following will most likely be seen on histological examination of the patient’s thyroid gland if a biopsy is performed?

choices.text: Tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid
Chronic inflammation with germinal centers and occasional Hurthle cells
Granulomatous inflammation, giant cells, and extravasation of colloid
Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and occasional calcifications

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of hyperthyroidism including anxiety, tachycardia, palpitations, and diffuse goiter. Although laboratory tests are required for confirmation, the lower extremities show pretibial myxedema, a unique finding of Graves disease.  

Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, is an autoimmune condition caused by the production of autoantibodies to the TSH receptor (TRAb). These antibodies imitate the action of TSH and activate the receptor, leading to increased thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion, as well as a diffuse goiter (thyroid growth).  

Patients typically present with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, in addition to specific findings unique to Graves disease including periorbital edema, exophthalmos, and pretibial myxedema. Thyroid function tests typically show decreased TSH and elevated free T3 and T4 levels. In some patients only T3 is increased. Diagnosis can be made clinically in patients with obvious symptoms. In patients with more subtle presentations, measuring thyroid receptor antibodies and performing a thyroid nuclear scan can assist in diagnosis.  

Macroscopically, Graves disease is characterized by diffuse hypertrophy and hyperplasia of thyroid follicular cells. Microscopically, tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid are seen. In contrast to papillary carcinoma, the papillae lack fibrovascular cores. Germinal centers and lymphoid infiltrates consisting of predominantly T cells can be found throughout the interstitium.

Option Analysis

✅ Tall, crowded follicular epithelial cells forming small papillae and scalloped colloid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chronic inflammation with germinal centers and occasional Hurthle cells:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis, the most common cause of hypothyroidism. Patients usually present with fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, weight gain, and bradycardia.
❌ Granulomatous inflammation, giant cells, and extravasation of colloid:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis, an inflammatory condition of the thyroid gland that usually follows a viral infection. It is characterized by neck pain, a tender goiter, and a predictable course of hyperthyroidism, then euthyroidism, hypothyroidism, and eventually restoration of normal thyroid function.
❌ Fibrosis and extracellular amyloid deposit:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with Riedel thyroiditis, a manifestation of IgG4-related systemic disease. Patients usually present with a fixed, hard (rock-like), and painless goiter, as well as tracheal compression when the goiter becomes too large. Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism may occur.
❌ Empty-appearing nuclei with central clearing and occasional calcifications:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with papillary thyroid carcinoma, the most common cancer of the thyroid. Patients usually present with a thyroid nodule rather than diffuse goiter and do not have signs of hyperthyroidism. On histology, it is characterized by cells with nuclear clearing (“Orphan Annie eye”), nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies.

questions.text:
A 29 year-old African-American man comes to the emergency department complaining of fatigue, jaundice, back pain, and dark urine for the last 5 days. He recently returned from a trip to Kenya, during which time he took malaria prophylaxis medication. The patient’s medical history is non-contributory. However, he states that his maternal uncle had similar symptoms when treated with specific types of antibiotics. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 126/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Which of the following is most likely seen on this patient’s peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution:
This African-American patient with anemia, recent history of malaria prophylaxis, and family history of a maternal uncle with similar symptoms, has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by decreased levels of the enzyme G6PD. Males are almost exclusively affected by the disease, and females are carriers of the disease. It is most common in individuals of African, Mediterranean, and Asian descent.  

G6PD deficiency leads to hemolysis by making erythrocytes more susceptible to damage caused by free radicals. Free radicals, which are products of metabolism, can destroy erythrocytes but are normally neutralized in the body by a molecule called glutathione. For this to occur, glutathione must be in the reduced state where it can donate protons and electrons to the free radicals and convert them to H2O2. However, this reaction causes glutathione to become oxidized, and for it to be reused, it must be converted back to the reduced state. This is done by an enzyme called glutathione reductase, which uses NADPH to reduce oxidized glutathione and converts NADPH into NADP+. To replenish the NADPH and allow for more glutathione to be reduced, G6PD reduces NADP+ back to NADPH. Therefore, low levels of G6PD, as in this patient, would lead to low levels of NADPH, decreased activity of glutathione reductase, decreased levels of reduced glutathione, and increased susceptibility to hemolytic episodes caused by free radicals.  



Some common triggers of G6PD include oxidant stressors, such as infections, metabolic acidosis, fava beans, soy products, red wine, antimalarials (primaquine and chloroquine), anti-inflammatories (aspirin and ibuprofen), quinidine, and sulfonamides (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).



Peripheral blood smear of patients with G6PD deficiency shows degmacytes, also known as bite cells. This finding occurs due to removal of Heinz bodies from erythrocytes in the spleen by splenic macrophages.    

G6PD deficiency actually protects against Plasmodium falciparum that causes malaria, because it makes parasite-infected erythrocytes more susceptible to oxidants, which will also kill the malaria parasites.  

Option Analysis

❌ Target cells:
Incorrect: Target cells (also called codocytes) are associated with HbC disease, asplenia, thalassemia, and liver disease. This patient with anemia following use of malaria prophylaxis has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.


Reproduced from:
❌ Schistocytes:
Incorrect: Schistocytes, which are caused by mechanical damage to erythrocytes, are characteristic of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. This patient with anemia following use of malaria prophylaxis has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.


Reproduced from:
✅ Degmacytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dacrocytes:
Incorrect: Dacrocytes, also known as teardrop cells, are associated with myelofibrosis. This patient with anemia following use of malaria prophylaxis has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.


Reproduced from:
❌ Acanthocytes:
Incorrect: Acanthocytes, also known as spur cells, are associated with liver disease and abetalipoproteinemia. This patient with anemia following use of malaria prophylaxis has glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.


Reproduced from:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of cough, dyspnea, and weakness. He describes difficulty getting up from a seated position and often needs assistance when rising from the couch. The weakness is worse when he wakes up and improves after he finishes his morning exercise and walks around. Medical history is significant for appendectomy 10 years ago and smoking 1.5 packs per day for 35 years. Physical examination reveals decreased tendon reflexes in the upper and lower extremities. An x-ray of the chest shows flattening of the diaphragm and elongation of the mediastinum, as well as a 2-cm nodule near the hilum. Biopsy of the nodule is most likely to yield which of the following histological findings?

choices.text: Columnar cells containing mucus, and positive staining for mucin
Epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a concentric rim of CD4+ lymphocytes
Small dark cells, and positive staining for synaptophysin
Thin cells, keratinized complexes and intercellular bridges

questions.solution:
A pulmonary nodule in a patient with a significant smoking history requires evaluation for malignancies of the lung. This patient's history of muscle weakness that improves with activity is consistent with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), a disorder that results from the production of autoantibodies that cross-react with calcium channels at presynaptic terminals of the neuromuscular junction. In conjunction with the finding of a nodule near the hilum, the presence of LEMS is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung. These tumors are characterized by small cells with minimal cytoplasm (due to an increased nucleus:cytoplasm ratio in a rapidly proliferating cell) that stains positive for markers such as synaptophysin, chromogranin, and neuron-specific enolase. Small cell carcinoma of the lung is also associated with other paraneoplastic syndromes, including ectopic production of ACTH (Cushing syndrome), SIADH (vasopressin), and antibodies against neurons (paraneoplastic myelitis, encephalitis, subacute cerebellar degeneration).  

Option Analysis

❌ Columnar cells containing mucus, and positive staining for mucin:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with lung adenocarcinoma, which is usually located in the periphery of the lung. Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with adenocarcinoma of the lung include hypertrophic osteoarthropathy (digit clubbing); however, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is not associated with it.
❌ Undifferentiated pleomorphic giant cells:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with large cell carcinoma, which is usually located in the periphery of the lung. It has a poor prognosis and is usually treated with surgery alone, rather than chemotherapy. Additionally, large cell carcinoma of the lung may result in paraneoplastic production of serum hCG, resulting in gynecomastia in men.
❌ Epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells, surrounded by a concentric rim of CD4+ lymphocytes:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with sarcoidosis, which is characterized by noncaseating granulomas. It presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, not unilateral. Also, it is not associated with Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the most likely cause of the patient's muscle weakness.
✅ Small dark cells, and positive staining for synaptophysin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thin cells, keratinized complexes and intercellular bridges:
Incorrect: These histological findings are consistent with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. It is highly associated with smoking and often presents with centrally located tumors. A possible outcome is hypercalcemia of malignancy due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein, but it is not associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents for evaluation of right groin pain, which he rates as a 6 out of 10 in severity. He states the pain has progressively worsened over the past month. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 81/min, and blood pressure is 121/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a right testicular mass that does not transilluminate or decrease in size when the patient lies flat. Laboratory testing reveals the following:

 Laboratory Value  Result  Normal Range 
 Placental alkaline phosphatase  0.92 ng/mL  < 1.85 ng/mL 
 α-fetoprotein  15 ng/mL  10-20 ng/mL 
 ꞵ-hCG  63 ng/mL  < 15 ng/mL 


With additional work-up, he is diagnosed with testicular cancer and undergoes a right radical orchiectomy. After resection, the testicular mass is observed to contain multiple areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. Histological analysis of the mass would most likely reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm
Presence of cells arranged in glandular and papillary structures
Presence of cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos
Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel
Follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a painful testicular mass with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, as well as elevated ꞵ-hCG levels. He most likely has a pure embryonal carcinoma of the testicle.

Embryonal carcinomas are a type of germ cell tumor that occurs most frequently in individuals between ages 25-35 years. Pure embryonal carcinomas are rare and are commonly mixed with other types of germ cell tumors. Embryonal carcinoma usually presents as a painless, unilateral testicular mass, but it can sometimes be painful.

On gross examination, this type of tumor is usually hemorrhagic and necrotic. Under the microscope, it consists of immature, primitive cells which tend to arrange in glandular and/or papillary structures. In pure tumors, laboratory testing will show elevated ꞵ-hCG levels but normal placental alkaline phosphatase and α-fetoprotein levels. In contrast, in mixed tumors, α-fetoprotein levels may be elevated along with ꞵ-hCG.





Option Analysis

❌ Cells with clear and watery-appearing cytoplasm:
Incorrect: This answer describes cells with a “fried-egg” appearance, which can be found in testicular seminomas. However, testicular seminomas are generally painless. Moreover, they tend to present with elevations in placental alkaline phosphatase, not ꞵ-hCG.
✅ Presence of cells arranged in glandular and papillary structures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos:
Incorrect: Koilocytes are cells with enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halos. This histological presentation can be found in cervical cells infected with human papillomavirus (HPV).
❌ Rings of malignant cells surrounding a central blood vessel:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Schiller-Duval bodies, which are found in testicular yolk sac tumors. Yolk sac tumors present with markedly elevated α-fetoprotein (AFP) levels, whereas this patient’s AFP level is within normal range.
❌ Follicle-like structures filled with eosinophilic material:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Call-Exner bodies, which are found in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors are a type of ovarian cancer that most often affects middle-aged women.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of a rash on her elbows. The rash appeared three months ago and is intensely pruritic, often awakening her during sleep. She has tried multiple over-the-counter emollients and ointments with minimal improvement. A review of systems reveals mild abdominal pain and greasy, voluminous stools for the past year. The remainder of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows groups of papules and vesicles on the elbows bilaterally as shown:  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following findings will be seen on direct immunofluorescence microscopy of biopsy specimens of these lesions?

choices.text: Linear IgG deposits at epidermal-dermal junction
Reticular IgG deposits in intercellular space
Granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae
Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction
Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with intensely pruritic, papulovesicular eruptions on her elbows associated with a history of abdominal pain and greasy voluminous diarrhea (most likely due to celiac disease) is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), an autoimmune dermatological disease.

Gluten sensitivity in susceptible individuals leads to IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminases found in the gastrointestinal tract. These antibodies can sometimes cross-react with epidermal transglutaminases causing deposition of IgA-transglutaminase complexes in the dermis, triggering the development of multiple pruritic papules and vesicles grouped in “herpetiform" arrangements. The most common sites are elbows, dorsal forearms, knees, scalp, back, and buttocks. In addition to celiac disease, dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with autoimmune thyroiditis, type I diabetes mellitus, and pernicious anemia. Moreover, it is highly prevalent in HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.

Histopathology of the lesions shows fibrins and neutrophils at the dermal papillae and subepidermal microabscesses. Direct immunofluorescence is the gold standard for diagnosis and reveals granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae. Treatment options include a gluten-free diet and dapsone.  



Option Analysis

❌ Linear IgG deposits at epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Linear IgG deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction on direct immunofluorescence are characteristic of bullous pemphigoid. They result from a type II hypersensitivity reaction where IgG antibodies are formed against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. The condition typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the papulovesicular eruption in this patient.  
❌ Reticular IgG deposits in intercellular space  :
Incorrect: Direct immunofluorescence revealing reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which IgG antibodies are formed against desmoglein. It usually manifests as flaccid bullae, ulcers, and mucosal erosions. The presence of papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces is atypical.  
✅ Granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction are typical for bullous dermatosis, a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. Although it also manifests with papules and vesicles (similar to this patient), the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms (indicative of gluten-sensitive enteropathy) is characteristically absent in bullous dermatosis.  
❌ Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junctions are characteristically found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). These patients have a malar rash (sparing nasolabial folds) and discoid lesions, along with constitutional symptoms, arthritis, photosensitivity, and other systemic diseases, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office for the evaluation of a rash on her knees bilaterally. The rash has been present for the past two months with intermittent itching, which has not improved with over-the-counter topical ointments. Past medical history is significant for inflammatory bowel disease, which is treated with 5-aminosalicylic acid. The rest of the history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a silver, scaly, erythematous plaque on the knees bilaterally that bleeds mildly on removing the scales. Which of the following histological findings are most likely to be seen on skin biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with silver, scaly, erythematous plaques on the knees with occasional pruritus, together with a positive Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed). This presentation is suggestive of psoriasis, an autoimmune skin disease that results from T helper cell activation and immature proliferation of keratinocytes.

Psoriasis usually presents with a well-defined, erythematous plaque with overlying silvery scales that bleeds when scraping off. It is found to be associated with psoriatic arthritis, nail pitting, and is more prevalent in those with comorbidities such as diabetes, hypertension, and inflammatory bowel disease. Diagnosis is usually clinical, but biopsy is required when the diagnosis is unclear. Classic histopathological findings of psoriasis include:

  •  Hyperkeratosis: increased thickness of stratum corneum 
  •  Parakeratosis: retention of nuclei in stratum corneum 
  •  Acanthosis (image A): epidermal hyperplasia 
  •  Munro microabscesses (image B): collection of neutrophils in the stratum corneum of epidermis  
  •  Thin or absent stratum granulosum 
  •  Dilated and tortuous dermal capillaries 
  •  Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate 

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

First line treatment options include topical corticosteroids (e.g. diflorasone) and vitamin D analog (e.g., calcipotriene, calcitriol).  

Option Analysis

❌ Separation of epidermal cells:
Incorrect: Acantholysis, the separation of epidermal cells, is typical of pemphigus vulgaris, which results from IgG antibodies against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. It typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the silver, scaly plaques on knees (extensor surface) as seen in this patient.
❌ Increased thickness of stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Hypergranulosis, the increased thickness of stratum granulosum, is characteristic of lichen planus, which presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. Silvery-scales on the lesion are not commonly seen.
✅ Increase thickness of stratum corneum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Squamous cell dysplasia:
Incorrect: Squamous cell dysplasia is seen in actinic keratosis, which presents as small (less than one centimeter), erythematous macules or papules on sun-exposed areas. Silver scaling on plaques is not seen.
❌ Thinning of epidermis:
Incorrect: Epidermal thinning and progressive dermal thickening is typical of scleroderma, which usually presents with skin thickening and hardening, mainly involving the fingers, hands, and face. Silver, scaly, pruritic plaques on the extensor surfaces would be atypical.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to an abnormal calcification that was observed on routine screening mammography. She is currently asymptomatic, and medical history is remarkable only for hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. The patient does not smoke or use alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a fixed, non-tender, palpable lump is noted in the left breast. There are no skin changes or nipple discharge. The biopsy results are shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with abnormal mammography results and a non-tender, fixed mass, all raising concerns for an underlying malignancy. The biopsy results show an intraductal lesion with central necrosis, characteristics of a comedo-type ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or comedocarcinoma.  

A comedo-type DCIS is a distinct, microinvasive subtype of breast cancer characterized by extensive necrosis, high-grade tumor cells, and aggressive behavior. The lesion plugs the lactiferous ducts, and examination of transected ducts yields toothpaste-like necrotic tissue when pressure is applied. Microinvasive breast carcinoma refers to invasive carcinoma of the breast with an invasive focus no larger than 1 mm. The majority of these are DCIS types. Microinvasive lesions are usually treated with breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy. However, mastectomy is often preferred in patients with a large comedo-type DCIS component and high-grade lesions due to the risk of recurrence.   

Option Analysis

❌ Intraductal papilloma  :
Incorrect: Intraductal papilloma is a benign tumor of papillary cells within the lactiferous ducts. Patients typically present with unilateral, painless, bloody nipple discharge. On histology, it is composed of a fibrovascular core with overlying epithelial cells. Although mostly benign, it is associated with a slightly increased risk for cancer. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Lobular carcinoma in situ:
Incorrect: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is noninvasive breast cancer which arises from the terminal duct lobular unit, spreads into the lobules, and does not cross the basement membrane. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
❌ Invasive lobular carcinoma:
Incorrect: Invasive lobular carcinomas are the 2nd most common type of invasive breast cancer. Patients often present with a palpable mass and/or mass on imaging. On histology, invasive lobular carcinomas are similar to LCIS and often show characteristic cells aligned in a “single-file.”  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons
✅ Comedocarcinoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medullary carcinoma:
Incorrect: Medullary carcinoma is an uncommon type of breast cancer, comprising ~2% of invasive breast cancers. On physical examination and imaging, it is characterized as a well-circumscribed tumor that is difficult to distinguish from benign tumors such as fibroadenoma. On histology, it is composed of large, anaplastic cells growing in sheets with adjacent lymphocytes and plasma cells. This patient’s histology results favor another diagnosis.  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of weight loss and nightly fevers for the past four months. The patient has noticed lumps on his neck and under his arms that fluctuate in size. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals fixed, non-tender cervical masses and enlarged axillary lymph nodes. A biopsy of an enlarged lymph node is performed, with subsequent staining for BCL-2, as demonstrated below:  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Further testing is most likely to reveal which of the following?

choices.text: Overactivation of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of painless waxing-and-waning lymph node enlargement, plus biopsy immunophenotyping revealing a high expression of BCL-2. Together, these findings are diagnostic for follicular lymphoma (FL). The majority of FL cases result in a genetic rearrangement that results in an inappropriate overexpression of the BCL2 protein, an inhibitor of apoptosis, causing proliferation of a single B-cell.  

Measurement of immunoglobulin light chain (i.e., kappa or lambda) expression by flow cytometry is an additional test that aids in the diagnosis and monitoring of B-cell lymphomas. Normal, reactive B-cell lymphocyte populations (such as during an active infection) exhibit expression of both kappa and lambda light chains at an expected ratio.

Neoplastic cells, in contrast, exhibit monotypia (overexpression of either kappa or lambda) because malignant cells arise from a genetic transformation and overproliferation of a single cell. Therefore, B-cell lymphomas originating from a proliferating single cell line often exhibit an expansion of either kappa or lambda light chain-expressing cells. This clonal expansion is termed monoclonal (or monotypic) light chain restriction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated kappa:lambda ratio   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Polytypic light chain expression   :
Incorrect: Normal and reactive B-cell lymphocyte populations exhibit proportionate expression of both kappa and lambda light chains. This proportionate expression of light chains results in polytypic (as opposed to monotypic seen in lymphomas) light chain expression.   
❌ Overactivation of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2   :
Incorrect: Activating mutations of the epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2), a receptor tyrosine kinase, is observed in some breast cancers. The BCL-2 positive staining of this patient’s lymph node, however, is instead indicative of follicular lymphoma.   
❌ Preserved nodal architecture   :
Incorrect: Reactive follicular hyperplasia (i.e., in the setting of an active infection) results in preserved nodal architecture, whereas follicular lymphoma results in diffuse disruption of nodal architecture.   
❌ Abundance of debris-laden macrophages   :
Incorrect: Debris-laden macrophages (i.e. “tingible-body” macrophages) are observed in reactive follicular hyperplasia during an active infection. Macrophages assist in the clearance of debris from apoptotic B-cells. Follicular lymphoma, however, results in cells that can evade apoptosis, causing a relative absence of macrophages.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is evaluated at the clinic for a pre-employment physical. He has a family history of sickle cell trait. A peripheral smear was performed, which is shown below as part of the workup. Which of the following best matches the function of the cell that is pointed with an arrow in the picture?
questions.solution:
The arrow in the peripheral blood smear above is pointing towards eosinophils. Eosinophils leukocytes contain many granules. These cells have a bilobed nucleus, and granules stain eosinophilic in the peripheral blood smear film.  

Eosinophils have many functions. First of all, these cells are the main defense against helminthic infections. Also, eosinophils are partly involved in allergic responses.  


Option Analysis

✅ Defends against helminthic infections  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Carries oxygen to tissues  :
Incorrect: Erythrocytes (red blood cells) are responsible for carrying oxygen to tissues and carbon dioxide to the lungs. Erythrocytes on peripheral smear have a pink or red color, biconcave shape, with central pallor.  
❌ Responsible for primary hemostasis  :
Incorrect: Platelets are anucleate cells in the blood responsible for primary hemostasis. They appear slightly basophilic in peripheral blood smears and have a small diameter (smaller than erythrocytes).  
❌ Defend against bacterial infections  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils are a major cell responsible for defending against bacterial infections by phagocytosing bacteria. Neutrophils have nuclei with 2-5 lobules and contain many granules.  
❌ Defend against viral infections   :
Incorrect: Lymphocytes are the primary cells responsible for defending against viral infections. These cells have no granules and contain a large, round, blue-to-purple nucleus that fills most of the cytoplasm.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of liver parenchyma. Under histological examination, the liver parenchyma is divided into hexagonal hepatic lobules containing the central vein in the center and the portal triad at the periphery. Each hepatic lobule is divided into three different zones. The circled zone in the picture is most susceptible to which of the following injuries?
questions.solution:
The liver parenchyma is divided into hepatic lobules, consisting of a central vein in the center and the portal triad (bile duct, hepatic arteriole, and portal venule) at the periphery. Each lobule receives a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and the portal vein, and the blood drains from the periphery to the central vein through the hepatic sinusoids.    

Each hepatic lobule is divided into 3 main zones:  
  1.  Zone 1 (periportal zone): This zone surrounds the portal triad and receives the highest oxygen supply. This zone is most resistant (not susceptible) to ischemic injury. Zone 1 is most susceptible to viral hepatitis and cocaine injury.  
  2.  Zone 2 (intermediate zone): This zone is located between zone 1 and zone 3 and is susceptible to injury from yellow fever.  
  3. Zone 3 (the pericentral zone): This zone surrounds the central vein in the center of the hepatic lobule. Because hepatocytes in this zone are furthest from the blood supply, they receive a lesser oxygen concentration than in zone 1 and 2. Therefore, zone 3 is the earliest to be affected by ischemia. Additionally, this zone contains high concentrations of metabolic enzymes (e.g. cytochrome P450 enzymes), and is also most affected by metabolic toxins (e.g.- alcohol). 

Option Analysis

✅ Ischemia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatitis A virus:
Incorrect: Zone 1 (the periportal zone) is most susceptible to viral hepatitis, not zone 3.
❌ Yellow fever:
Incorrect: Yellow fever affects mostly zone 2 (the intermediate zone).
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Zone 1 is the most susceptible for injury from cocaine.
❌ Hepatitis C virus:
Incorrect: Zone 1 (the periportal zone) is the most susceptible to viral hepatitis, not zone 3.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, and severe abdominal pain. The pain began 6 hours ago and has become more severe over the last 2 hours. She noticed vaginal spotting this morning. Past medical history is significant for two rounds of ovulation induction therapy in the past six months. Her last menstrual period was six weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 90/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Transabdominal ultrasound shows free fluid in the pelvis and does not detect an intrauterine gestational sac. Emergency exploratory laparoscopy is performed, and the mesosalpinx is incised to remove the pathological specimen involved. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histological examination of the specimen?

choices.text: Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands

questions.solution:
This patient presented with symptoms of amenorrhea, pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and history of ovulation induction therapy. She most likely has a ruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.    

Ectopic pregnancy is an extrauterine pregnancy and commonly occurs in the uterine tubes. It should be suspected in women of reproductive age with risk factors for a tubal pregnancy, including the previous history of tubal pregnancy, IUD use, sterilization, and history of tubal disease. Laboratory investigations would reveal a rising beta hCG level, and imaging could reveal an extra ovarian adnexal mass/ extrauterine gestational sac on transvaginal ultrasound.    

The fallopian tubes are situated in the upper margin of the broad ligament of the uterus and are divided anatomically into 4 divisions; the infundibulum, the ampulla, the isthmus, and the intramural or interstitial part of the tube. The isthmus forms the medial one-third of the tube. The ampulla forms the lateral two-thirds and is the site of fertilization. The infundibulum forms the lateral end of the uterine tube and is attached to the tubal pole of the ovary.    

Due to its close proximity to the ovary, ovarian torsion or rupture are often considered in the differential diagnosis of an acute abdomen in a woman of reproductive age. However, these differentials are unlikely to cause abnormal vaginal bleeding or amenorrhea. A transvaginal ultrasound can further aid in distinguishing ovarian pathologies from a tubal pregnancy. Ovarian torsion on a pelvic ultrasound would reveal an adnexal mass with the absent flow on a doppler USG.  



Option Analysis

✅ Simple ciliated columnar epithelium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium :
Incorrect: Simple cuboidal epithelium covers the epithelial surface of the ovary. Although ovarian torsion would necessitate an oophorectomy, it is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.   
❌ Simple squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: The peritoneum is lined with simple squamous epithelium (mesothelium) and is rarely the site of an ectopic pregnancy.  
❌ Stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium :
Incorrect: The vagina and the ectocervix are lined with stratified squamous non keratinized epithelium and cervical ectopic pregnancies are rare. A tubal ectopic pregnancy is much more likely to be encountered.   
❌ Simple cuboidal epithelium with hair follicles and sebaceous glands :
Incorrect: Mature teratomas on histology reveal simple cuboidal ovarian epithelium with tissues from multiple germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm). They are commonly found in women between the ages of 20-30 and can cause ovarian torsion. Ovarian torsion is unlikely to present with amenorrhea and vaginal bleeding.

questions.text:
Two biopsies were taken from the lymph nodes of two different children to examine the changes in the follicles present in the outer cortex. The first specimen (Specimen A) and second specimen (Specimen B) are shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the difference in appearance between the follicles in specimen A and specimen B?


Source: histologyguide.com

choices.text: Follicles in specimen B contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen A contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen B contain active T lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen B represent a metastatic cancer

questions.solution:
The lymph nodes are encapsulated immune organs that are scattered throughout the body. In the outer cortex of these lymph nodes are the lymphoid follicles. These follicles are the site of B-cell proliferation and maturation and can be divided into two types:
  • Primary follicles: These follicles are found in Naive lymph nodes. They are dense and inactive.


  • Secondary follicles: These follicles are found in activated lymph nodes. Once B lymphocytes get activated, they start proliferating and maturating. In addition, a germinal matrix forms in the center of the secondary follicle, and it is the site where B-cells transform into plasma cells. These germinal matrices give the secondary follicles a pale appearance.


Option Analysis

✅ Follicles in specimen B contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
See Main Explanation.
❌ Follicles in specimen A contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
Incorrect: Specimen A follicles are primary follicles that are dense and quiescent, while in specimen B, they are secondary follicles that are active and pale due to the presence of a germinal matrix in the center of the follicle.
❌ Follicles in specimen B contain active T lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
Incorrect: The follicles are the site of B-cell localization and maturation, while T-cells are found in the paracortex (the region between the follicles and the medulla).
❌ Follicles in specimen B represent a metastatic cancer:
Incorrect: The specimen in picture B represents an activated secondary follicle with a pale germinal matrix in the center. This is due to the activation of B lymphocytes, which are not cancerous cells.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of liver parenchyma. It is found to be divided into hexagonal-shaped hepatic lobules. At the periphery of each lobule, the structures below are identified. Which of the following best describes the function of Label A in the image?

choices.text: Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the portal vein
Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery
Lymphatic drainage from the hepatic parenchyma

questions.solution:
The liver parenchyma is organized into hexagonal-shaped lobules called hepatic lobules. These lobules are the functional unit of the liver. Each lobule receives a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and the portal vein, and the blood is drained into the centrally located central vein. The lobule contains many hepatocytes that perform a variety of functions.  

At the periphery of each hepatic lobule, there is the portal triad. The portal triad consists of a portal venule, hepatic arteriole, and bile ductule. The portal venule supplies blood from the portal vein, and is identified with its narrow lumen and thin walls. The hepatic arteriole, on the other hand, has thicker walls and narrower lumen and supplies blood from the hepatic artery. Finally, the bile ductule, which is responsible for collecting bile from the bile canaliculi, is identified by its prominent simple cuboidal epithelium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the portal vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Collect bile from the hepatocytes  :
Incorrect: The bile ductule (Label B) located in the portal triad is responsible for bile collection from the bile canaliculi that collects bile produced by the hepatocytes.  
❌ Provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery:
Incorrect: The hepatic arteriole (Label C) provides blood supply to the hepatocytes from the hepatic artery  
❌ Lymphatic drainage from the hepatic parenchyma:
Incorrect: There are lymphatic vessels (Label D) located in the portal triad that are responsible for lymphatic drainage. However, they have a narrower lumen than the portal venule.
